story:
Bref résume

Soutenez  notre  atelier  de  couture  des jeunes  mamans  , chefs  de ménage ,  de  Kindu  en  RDC  Regroupées  dans  une  association  locale  dénommée  Solidarité  des  femmes  pour  un  développement  intégral , en  sigle  SOFEDI  , les  mamans  chefs  de  ménage  ont  initié  un  atelier  de  couture  pour  se  prendre  en  charge et de permettre à la population de sa région d’atteindre les objectifs du millénaire pour le développement par la création de l’emploi  . Elles  ont  seulement   trois  machines à coudre.

Ce dont nous avons besoin et ce que vous obtenez

Par  ce  Projet, nous  voulons,

- Soutenir  l’emploi  existant  mais  aussi  créer   des  nouveaux  emplois  

- Promouvoir  l’auto prise  en  charge  des  jeunes  mamans  chef  de ménage et des jeunes filles  et  contribuer à  leur  bien  être

Les  différentes  guerres  qui  ont  secoué  notre pays  ont  laissé beaucoup  des  filles  mères  devenues  aujourd’hui chef  de  ménage

Nous  avons  besoin de  votre  soutien

Ce  don  nous  avons  besoin :

- Huit  machines  à coudre  simple  et accessoires

- Deux  machines  pour  broderie, fil  simple

- Une  machine  pour  broderie, gros  fil

- Une boutonneuse

- Un  kit  d’accompagnement  constitué  de :  fil à  coudre , ciseaux , mètre  ruban , aiguilles …..

Désignation

Prix unitaire

Prix total

Huit  machines  à coudre  simples

187, 4$  

1499,2$

Deux  machines  pour  broderie, fil  simple 

715$

1430$

Une  machine  broderie  gros  fil

-

913$

Boutonneuse : 

-

89$

Kit  d’accompagnement 

-

217$

Total  4148,2$

 L'impact.

Avez les trois machines que nous avons, treize ménages de sept personnes au moins s’assurent leur repas journaliers et la scolarisation de leurs enfants. L’atelier de couture renforcé contribuera à aider d’autres femmes et ménages à se pendre en charge (formation à la couture, broderie…) 

 Risques et défis

Le plus grand risque c'est la vol qui peut survenir à tout moment. Et pour y surmonter, nous avons un gardien permanent.

 D'autres façons d'aider

 Vous pouvez nous retrouvez sur facebook

story:
Short Story

The sound installation, Line of Breath, took place on April 8th and 9th, 2016 on the Tijuana/San Diego political fence. This coming June, the project will be exhibited at a 2016 US elections art exhibition in Brooklyn, NY by having a sound installation consisting of a 8ft x 8ft metal fence. The help that I'm asking for will go toward the construction and installation of the fence to ensure that the Tijuana/San Diego border fence is well represented.

The breakdown of how the money will be utilized is below.
#lineofbreath


~~~~~ If you have any questions, please feel free to send them to icruzchong@gmail.com, thank you. ~~~~~

Long Story

My name is Isabella Cruz-Chong. I am an interdisciplinary artist and designer raised in Tijuana, Mexico and based in Brooklyn, NY. I am currently an MFA candidate in the Design and Technology program at Parsons School of Design. 

My thesis project, Line of Breath, is a sound installation on the Tijuana/San Diego political fence in an attempt to manifest a liminal state and give life to this often neglected in-between. The sound recordings of my breath are physically attached to the metal fence, transforming the fence into one speaker. The installation took place on April 8th and 9th in Tijuana, Mexico. 

This past month, the project was selected to be exhibited in June at a great gallery in Brooklyn, NY where the exhibition's theme will be the 2016 US Elections. I am excited that the Tijuana border fence can be shown in this context given its importance to both countries and their communities.  

The project will be exhibited with an 8ft x 8ft free-standing fence made of corrugated metal sheets with puck transducers and custom speakers. This sound installation will also be accompanied by video documentation of the work process and the installation in Tijuana.

The help that I'm asking for will go toward the construction and installation of the fence to ensure it properly represents the Tijuana/San Diego border fence and its effects. 
 



How The Money Will Be Used

Materials
Corrugated Steel Panels (4 @ 24" x 96")
Cold Rolled Steel bar (2 @ 1/2" x 12')
Muriatic Acid
Airplane Cable
Crimps and Mounting Hardware
Steel Filler Rod, Gas and Tungsten for TIG welding
Shop plywood, construction materials for jigs and acid baths

Labor
Design Assist / Prototyping: @ $50/hr
material research / sourcing - 2 hrs
muriatic acid tests - 2 hrs
panel assembly mockup - 2 hrs
$300

Base Fabrication
@ $60/hr
design - 1 hr
cutting and welding - 2 hrs
muriatic/ finishing - 3 hrs
$360

Sheet Fabrication
@ $60/hr
muriatic / finishing - 4 hrs
welding or epoxy - 2 hrs
drilling holes for mount - .5 hrs
$390

Installation
@ $50/hr
transportation - 1 hr
install in gallery - 3 hr
$200

Total for Labor : $1250
Material Estimate: $400
Subtotal: $1650
Indiegogo Platform fee: ~$132
Total: $1782

Goal

The goal is to build and install a metal fence that can effectively reference the Tijuana/San Diego border fence to bring awareness of this division and its effect on the Tijuana/San Diego community.


Challenges

This is the first time I will be exhibiting an art installation of this size. I am lucky and grateful to have close friends and professionals helping me throughout the process to make sure the piece is exhibited successfully! 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you believe in the project but can't contribute you can help by getting the word out by using the Indiegogo share tools. 

FOREVER THANK YOU!

story:
What is Spoken Perceptions?



Spoken Perceptions is an interactive poetry showcase that features five of Savannah's most talented spoken word artists. On May 20th and 21st 8pm at Non-Fiction Gallery, these poets words will be projected onto screens in the gallery space in real time. Motion media designers have created unique animations that spawn with every word spoken. The following is an example of those animations created by one of our designers, Amy Wallace.


Finally, the audience will be able to interact with those words using  Microsoft Kinect technology. Thus the art of the performer becomes the art of the audience.

Where do the poems end up after audience interaction? This is where...


Spoken Perceptions is also the M.A. Arts Administration Final Project for its Creative Director and Project Manager, Camille Jenkins. Camille first imagined this interactive performing arts experience in August of 2015. Since then she has worked every day on this project, collaborating with over 20 artists, designers, and poets on her journey to turn this dream into a reality.

However, Spoken Perceptions was created not just for Camille, but for the entire Savannah community and beyond. This project has given a chance for those multitude of designers, artists, and poets to shine. This project strives to create a thought provoking, deeply personal, and yet universal event that asks all of us to contemplate the real impact of the words we say. 

In a world where rhetoric flies off the tongue without a care and people sometimes speak before they think (ourselves included), Spoken Perceptions celebrates the belief that words have power and that they truly can take on a life of their own. Thus why not honor and explore that transformative power? Perhaps this exploration will lead to our own personal evolution.

“Words mean more than what is set down on paper. It takes the human voice to infuse them with shades of deeper meaning.”

― Maya Angelou, I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings

“I know nothing in the world that has as much power as a word. Sometimes I write one, and I look at it, until it begins to shine.”

― Emily Dickinson

Your Support Turns Dreams into Reality


Funding Need

Spoken Perceptions needs $1,855 to cover all of the expenses mandatory in order to put on an event of this magnitude for our community. Main expenses include:

  • Venue Space Rental: $600
  • Projection Costs: $480
  • Production Design: $235
These are just some of the costs related to putting on a multimedia event. Other costs include: shipping, Kinect related technology, office supplies, printing, and more.
Your Support
Your support ensures that our team can afford to make Spoken Perceptions a night to remember. All funds raised will only be used on costs directly related to the project. As a thank you for your support we are offering the following perks!

PERK LEVELS!

Spoken Supporters $10

Thanks for your support! You receive a shout out on Spoken Perception’s Facebook event page!

Allegorical Allies $25

We couldn’t do it without allies like you! Enjoy the aforementioned shout out plus a haiku written just for you.

Interactive Idealists $50

Thank you for your interaction! As a token of our gratitude you get the shout out, haiku, and a  digital copy of the filmed show.

Perceptive Patrons $100

Perception is key and we perceive you to be a pretty benevolent donor. Please accept a shout out, haiku, a digital copy of the filmed show, and your name listed in our end of show credit sequence.

Deconstructionist Dreamers $250

Words may have elusive meanings but, your support speaks for itself. In addition to the shout out, haiku, copy, and the listing, our talented motion media designers will create a unique animated gif of your name. 

Also!

For every $450 raised, we will share one unique animation that was created for Spoken Perceptions: Interactive Poetry Showcase!

AS PROMISED!

We have made over $1,800 therefore we are sharing four unique animations that were created for Spoken Perceptions. Here they go...

Animation by Rachel Allison Johnson

Animation by Amy Wallace

Animation by Jennifer Estridge

Animation by Rachel Allison Johnson

Just in Case

If Spoken Perceptions does not make its funding goal, then all remaining costs will be absorbed by the Project Manager and Creative Director, Camille Jenkins. However, with your support we will be able to focus on the event itself and not worry about last minute budget setbacks that might affect the show. With your support, Spoken Perceptions can flourish into the unique and exciting event it is meant to be.

Show Statement

For those wanting to go deeper into the concept of Spoken Perceptions, I welcome you to read the official show statement:

Beyond definitions, beyond even the words themselves, what are the real meanings of the words we speak? What are we really telling someone when we say the phrase, “I love you”? How do you feel when someone says that phrase to you?

Spoken Perceptions examines the ownership of words and the symbiotic relationship between performer and audience through the art of poetry. Words are morphed by thought, meaning, and interpretation from speaker to designer to performer. Often people identify with words in a way that the speaker may never have imagined. We take from their thoughts, what they dreamed into fruition, and we create our own reality, or from another perspective, our own dream. We the audience, become the carrier and owner of these words. The audience is now free to figuratively, and in this case literally, morph that thought.

This project redefines the role of an audience. It allows the audience to be more than a spectator but, an actual participator. The projected dreamcatcher collects words that the audience has interacted with. By the end of the poem the dreamcatcher holds a new version of the poets words filtered through the perception and interaction of the audience. The art of the performer has become the art of the audience.

Evolution of a Thought


This journey started as a simple thought: Words often take on their own unique meaning from person to person. From this thought came a question: "How can a visual representation of this evolution occur?" This lead to another question from Camille: "Could I turn this this question and thought into a whole performing arts event for my Masters in Arts Administration?" Then came the answer: "Yes! Let's dare to dream!"

Now almost eight months later, Camille can definitely say that she has no regrets following her dream. Has it been easy? Not always. But, has it been fulfilling, exciting, and rewarding? Yes! This journey has led her to work with numerous talented artists, designers, and poets with, who out their genius, this project would not be possible. 

From her motion media designers: Amy Wallace, Jennifer Estridge, and Rachel Allison Johnson (who also designed the amazing images you see on this page) to her amazing interactive designer, Rian Burbridge, to the sound designers, production designers, poets, filmmakers and more, Spoken Perceptions is with out a doubt, a team effort. It is an effort which all team members have dedicated countless hours, creativity, and energy into making a reality.

It is an exciting time to see all this hard work come together. We are ecstatic that you are an integral part of this journey.

Thank You

Thank you so much for your love and support! Even if you can't donate today we ask everyone to please share our campaign with those you know. Any and every form of support matters. 


From Camille and the Spoken Perceptions team,

Peace and Love

story:
THEATER  :  A French American project in DANCE THEATER and video based on Sarah Kane's 4.48 Psychosis .

Throughout my career, I have been very blessed to work with directors and choreographers such as Georges Lavaudant, Raimund Hoghe, Yves Beaunesne , Anatoli Vassiliev , Jean- Marie Patte, Frederic Fisbach , Helene Vincent , Christophe Perton , Robert Moses Kin , Benoit Jacquot , Frederic Berthes , Moise Toure ...   Those creations  allowed me  also to travel to multiple places around the world such as India, France, Spain, Italy, Germany, USA (San Francisco, Boston, New York, Los Angeles...I also directed Othello by Shakespeare , Three sisters by Tchekov , The lover by Marguerite Duras , Phedre in India by Jean Christophe Bailly .

Being  granted the "Villa Medicis" allowed me to focus more on dance . I created a  dance theatre piece : “Life or Theater” after Charlotte Salomon ’s paintings. (performed at ODC Theater in San Francisco and at MAHJ in Paris ). 4:48 is in direct continuation with "Life or Theatre". This time I am focusing on how the body is able to translate, through dance and words, the trouble of the mind.

En parralèle à une carrière de comédienne avec des metteurs en scène tels que Georges Lavaudant, Raimund Hogue, Yves Beaunesne, Anatoli Vassiliev, Jean Marie Patte, Frederic Fischbach, Helène Vincent, Christophe Perton, Benoît Jacquot, Federic Berthes, Moïse Touré... mon exploration de la danse s’est poursuivie avec Peter Goss, Mary Carbonara, Wayne Mc Greggor, Alonzo King. Celle-ci m’a encouragée à rechercher la sensation de liberté et d’émotion brute qui s’exprime dans le language du corps. J’ai aussi mis en scène “les trois soeurs” de Tchekov, “L’Amant” de Marguerite Duras, Phèdre en Inde” de Jean Christophe Bailly, Par mon travail j'ai pu voyager de part le monde, en Inde, France, Espagne, Italie, Allemagne, USA.

EN 2014 j'ai reçu  la Villa Medicis   hors les murs et me suis installée à San Francisco pour developper un spectacle en danse theâtre d'après l'oeuvre de Charlotte Salomon "Life or Theatre", joué à ODC Theatre, San Francisco et présenté au MAJH, Paris.  "Black and white 448 psychosis" est le second volet de 'Life or Theater ' , Ce projet mêle  le mouvement , le texte et la video . 

www.astridbas.com 

 What arouses my creativity is to mix dance and theatre in the same pieces. In parallel to this, mixing in plastic arts, paint, sound and video projection has enabled me to fully satisfy my need to express emotion. Sarah Kane's writing in "Psychosis 4.48" allows movement and open interpretation to body language.


« Psychosis 4.48 » est le second volet de mon travail basé sur «Life or Theatre ». Cette fois je me concentre sur la manière dont le corps humain peut traduire les troubles de la pensée à travers la danse et les mots.

Ma créativité nait dans le lien de la danse et des mots. Y mêler les arts plastiques, la peinture, le son et la projection video me permet de pleinement satisfaire l’expression de mon émotion. L’écriture même de « 448 Black and white psychosis"  permet le mouvement et l’interprétation du corps. 


Freedom and feminine figures are two focuses that entice my creative flow. Women who want to rebel  and speak against violence and captivity is an act  that inspired me into this creation . 

In 1999 the author committed suicide. She wanted to speak about the world around her . She was quite young, the same age as Charlotte Salomon who spoke through her paintings. I am creating a sense of confinement but the piece is about memory and hope.

On November 4th we showed 30mn of the piece at Gibney Art center in NY. Your help will allow us to  finish the piece and open a window on the fragility of the human being . And I hope light in the darkness . Why I named it  

"Black and white psychosis" .


                                            Astrid Bas is an actress and director. 

                                                      

She acted in severals productions in France, Italy, Spain, India, New York, Usa (New York , San Francisco , Los Angeles) In France she worked with Georges Lavaudant , Jean Marie Patte , Raimund Hoghes,  Yves Beaunesne, Louis do de Lencquesaing, Anatoli Vassiliev, Frederic Fisbach, Christophe Perton , Helene Vincent ... She made movies with Benoit Jacquot , Patrick  Volson , Jean Dominique de la Rochefoucauld ,Edward Niermans , Frederic Berthes .

She directed   Platonov and Three sisters by Tchekhov  ( Odeon Ateliers Berthier ) , The Lover by Marguerite Duras ( Theatre de la Colline , Phedra in India , with the dancer Mallika Sarabbai in Delhi and Bombay .Life or theater after Charlotte Salomon's paintings , performed at ODC theater (San Francisco and MAHJ , Paris)

           

                 Christine Bonansea is a dancer and consulting choreographer.

Selected for professional program in French National Choreographic Dance Centers with Catherine Diverres, Regine Chopinot, Mathilde Monnier (Exerce 99), she completed her professional training and choreographic studies.

Over the last 10 years, she explored visual arts as well as physical performing techniques in collaboration with artist specialist from various field (musician composer, visual artist, filmmaker). She’s been challenging the dynamics of live performance within the diversity of environment that she experienced in Europe, USA and Africa as an interpreter and choreographer.

She’s teaching advanced modern dance classes, improvisation techniques and contact improvisation in different art spaces and Dance Centers (Dance New Amsterdam-NYC, Cornel University, Kunst-Stoff arts-SF, The Garage-SF, Lycee Francais-SF, Ponderosa-Germany, Dakar -Africa).                                                              

                                                 

                       Lana Boy is a French-American actress/director and writer.

Lana Boy is a 20 year old actress who performed for the first time at the age of 8  in the play "Alice in Wonderland" as the Chechire Cat. She then pursued her work in Bangkok (Thailand) where she played in multiple plays such as Twelth Night by Shakespeare, Metamorphoses de Mary Zimmerman, and many other. With her IB diploma in hand, she then moved to Paris to join the Cours Florent  where she completed 3 years of acting studies and then worked as an editor and theatre assistant to multiple teachers. She then directed more than 9 short films and is now living in New York. She met Astrid a coupe of weeks ago and is now in collaboration with her work on Sarah Kane as a assistant director in New York and Paris.

                                               Sandra Cheres is a painter and artist

Sandra Cheres will be will be opening a gallery in December to present the work with Astrid Bas. 

                                                         

                   Fanny Caranco is an assistant director working on the project.
story_txt:
THEATER  :  A French American project in DANCE THEATER and video based on Sarah Kane's 4.48 Psychosis .Throughout my career, I have been very blessed to work with directors and choreographers such as Georges Lavaudant, Raimund Hoghe, Yves Beaunesne , Anatoli Vassiliev , Jean- Marie Patte, Frederic Fisbach , Helene Vincent , Christophe Perton , Robert Moses Kin , Benoit Jacquot , Frederic Berthes , Moise Toure ...   Those creations  allowed me  also to travel to multiple places around the world such as India, France, Spain, Italy, Germany, USA (San Francisco, Boston, New York, Los Angeles...I also directed Othello by Shakespeare , Three sisters by Tchekov , The lover by Marguerite Duras , Phedre in India by Jean Christophe Bailly .



Being  granted the "Villa Medicis" allowed me to focus more on dance . I created a  dance theatre piece : “Life or
Theater” after Charlotte Salomon ’s paintings. (performed at ODC Theater in San Francisco
and at MAHJ in Paris ). 4:48 is in direct continuation with "Life or Theatre". This time I am focusing on how the body is able to translate, through dance and words, the trouble of the mind.
En parralèle à une carrière de comédienne avec des metteurs
en scène tels que Georges Lavaudant, Raimund
Hogue, Yves Beaunesne, Anatoli Vassiliev, Jean Marie Patte,
Frederic Fischbach, Helène Vincent, Christophe Perton,
Benoît Jacquot, Federic Berthes, Moïse Touré... mon
exploration de la danse s’est poursuivie avec Peter Goss,
Mary Carbonara, Wayne Mc Greggor, Alonzo King. Celle-ci m’a
encouragée à rechercher la sensation de liberté et d’émotion
brute qui s’exprime dans le language du corps. J’ai aussi mis en scène “les trois soeurs” de Tchekov,
“L’Amant” de Marguerite Duras, Phèdre en Inde” de Jean
Christophe Bailly, Par mon travail j'ai pu voyager de part le
monde, en Inde, France, Espagne, Italie, Allemagne, USA.



EN 2014 j'ai reçu  la Villa Medicis   hors les murs et me suis installée à San Francisco pour developper un spectacle en danse theâtre d'après l'oeuvre de Charlotte Salomon "Life or Theatre", joué à ODC Theatre, San Francisco et présenté au MAJH, Paris.  "Black and white 448 psychosis" est le second volet de 'Life or Theater ' , Ce projet mêle  le mouvement , le texte et la video . 

www.astridbas.com 










 What arouses my creativity is to mix dance and theatre in the
same pieces. In parallel to this, mixing in plastic arts,
paint, sound and video projection has enabled me to fully
satisfy my need to express emotion. Sarah
Kane's writing in "Psychosis 4.48" allows movement and open
interpretation to body language.

















« Psychosis 4.48 » est le second volet de mon travail basé
sur «Life or Theatre ». Cette fois je me concentre sur la
manière dont le corps humain peut traduire les troubles de la
pensée à travers la danse et les mots.
Ma créativité nait dans le lien de la danse et des mots. Y
mêler les arts plastiques, la peinture, le son et la projection
video me permet de pleinement satisfaire l’expression de mon
émotion. L’écriture même de « 448 Black and white psychosis"  permet
le mouvement et l’interprétation du corps. 







Freedom and feminine figures are two focuses that entice my creative flow. Women who want
to rebel  and speak against violence and captivity is an act  that inspired me into this creation . 














In 1999 the author committed suicide. She wanted to speak about the world around her . She was quite
young, the same age as Charlotte Salomon who spoke
through her paintings. I am creating a sense of confinement but the piece is about memory and hope.







On November 4th we showed 30mn of the piece at Gibney Art center in NY. Your help will allow us to  finish the piece and open a window on the fragility of the human being . And I hope light in the darkness . Why I named it  
"Black and white psychosis" .

                                            Astrid Bas is an actress and director.                                                       
She acted in severals productions in France, Italy, Spain, India, New York, Usa (New York , San Francisco , Los Angeles) In France she worked with Georges Lavaudant , Jean Marie Patte , Raimund Hoghes,  Yves Beaunesne, Louis do de Lencquesaing, Anatoli Vassiliev, Frederic Fisbach, Christophe Perton , Helene Vincent ... She made movies with Benoit Jacquot , Patrick  Volson , Jean Dominique de la Rochefoucauld ,Edward Niermans , Frederic Berthes .
She directed   Platonov and Three sisters by Tchekhov  ( Odeon Ateliers Berthier ) , The Lover by Marguerite Duras ( Theatre de la Colline , Phedra in India , with the dancer Mallika Sarabbai in Delhi and Bombay .Life or theater after Charlotte Salomon's paintings , performed at ODC theater (San Francisco and MAHJ , Paris)                             Christine Bonansea is a dancer and consulting choreographer.Selected for professional program in French National Choreographic Dance Centers with Catherine Diverres, Regine Chopinot, Mathilde Monnier (Exerce 99), she completed her professional training and choreographic studies.Over the last 10 years, she explored visual arts as well as physical performing techniques in collaboration with artist specialist from various field (musician composer, visual artist, filmmaker). She’s been challenging the dynamics of live performance within the diversity of environment that she experienced in Europe, USA and Africa as an interpreter and choreographer.She’s teaching advanced modern dance classes, improvisation techniques and contact improvisation in different art spaces and Dance Centers (Dance New Amsterdam-NYC, Cornel University, Kunst-Stoff arts-SF, The Garage-SF, Lycee Francais-SF, Ponderosa-Germany, Dakar -Africa).                                                                                                                                      Lana Boy is a French-American actress/director and writer.Lana Boy is a 20 year old actress who performed for the first time at the age of 8  in the play "Alice in Wonderland" as the Chechire Cat. She then pursued her work in Bangkok (Thailand) where she played in multiple plays such as Twelth Night by Shakespeare, Metamorphoses de Mary Zimmerman, and many other. With her IB diploma in hand, she then moved to Paris to join the Cours Florent  where she completed 3 years of acting studies and then worked as an editor and theatre assistant to multiple teachers. She then directed more than 9 short films and is now living in New York. She met Astrid a coupe of weeks ago and is now in collaboration with her work on Sarah Kane as a assistant director in New York and Paris.                                               Sandra Cheres is a painter and artistSandra Cheres will be will be opening a gallery in December to present the work with Astrid Bas.                                                                             Fanny Caranco is an assistant director working on the project.

story:
History

Hello. My name is Dave Bloom. I'm a local Tattoo Artist from Cincinnati, OH. Art has always been my calling. As a kid, I was artistic and knew this was my dream job. Later in life, tattoos showed me where to take my art skills and make it my career. 

As an artist, I will be teaming up with Ashley Padgett, a Northern Kentucky University Alumni with a Bachelor Degree in Entrepreneurship. She will be managing the marketing and day-to-day business operations.

Goals

After 14 years in the industry, I have learned the pros and cons of the business. Now I want to make my mark in the industry as an owner and artist. Our plan are to open the business in early 2016. Our hope is to raise $3,500 towards remaining fixtures, county licensing fee, marketing, and other fees. 

This is where you fine people enter the picture. We are asking for your support. Each person who gives us support will be rewarded with a special perk. (Review Perks section) Any additional funds will go towards our marketing budget.

Thank you all in advance for your involvement. With your help, we can make this dream a reality. Please share this with your friends. Moral support is also valuable to us.


Thank you,

Dave Bloom

Ashley Padgett

story:
What is crimsonSTEAM?

crimsonSTEAM is a fully-articulated steampunk optional arm. These are gorgeous limited-run pieces of art intended for use with SD and SD13 (large) sized BJD's.


crimsonSTEAM is designed by me, and will be modeled by Matthew Kaemmerer, an artist with over 5 years of experience with 3D modeling. We'll be making a master cast with this 3D model, and then casting the arm in high-quality resin.

What We Need

We'll be using these funds for the 3D printing, casting, and physical production of these arms. 3D printing and casting isn't cheap—which is why we need your help to make these optional arms a reality!

The Goodies

crimsonSTEAM Supporter ($5)
Supporters will receive:

  • a huge thank-you and call out on the crimsonSTEAM blog. Please let us know if you'd like us to include a link to your blog or site!

crimsonSTEAM Fan ($25)
Fans will receive:

  • a huge thank-you and call out on the crimsonSTEAM blog AND
  • a packet of three 6x4 postcard-sized illustrations of crimsonSTEAM from yours truly!


crimsonSTEAM Preorder ($80)
Preorder your arm today! Preorders include:

  • all of the above PLUS
  • a high-quality resin-cast SD-sized crimsonSTEAM arm



crimsonSTEAM Deluxe Preorder ($140)
Treat Yourself! Deluxe Preorders include:

  • all of the above PLUS
  • detailed hand-painting for your new, awesome crimsonSTEAM arm! You can pick whatever colors you'd like.

The Impact

Steampunk arms are only the beginning. If our project is successful, we have plans to make more BJD pieces, such as cybernetic android arms, and faerie arms, as well as new sizes such as arms for MSDs and tinies. If you don’t have an SD-sized doll, keep in touch for updates from crimsonSTEAM.

Excited Already?

Even if you can't donate to this one of a kind piece of art, you can still help! Spread the word to your doll friends and family, and help us make this incredible arm a reality!

Any Questions?

If you have any questions about the preorder process, please check out our FAQ in the blog. If your questions are not answered in the FAQ, feel free to message me via Indiegogo, or via our e-mail at thecrimsonprojectbjd@gmail.com.

story:
Short Summary

We're a collection of over 30 Photography, Video and Digital Imaging students from the Northern Centre of Photography, University of Sunderland. We have worked hard over the past three years and this June, we will be presenting the final exhibition of our degree. We want to make it one of the best yet and need your help to achieve this. 

As part of the exhibition, we want to publish a high quality exhibition catalogue to showcase a diverse range of artists work. We need your help to raise the funding for a limited run of catalogues. These catalogues will not only serve as a keepsake from the exhibition but will also help us to gain much needed exposure in the art world as recent graduates. Your funding will help us to send our work to numerous galleries and curators with the aim of generating interest in our practices.


What We Need & What You Get

We are looking for a minimum of £500 in order to fund the exhibition catalogues. We would be grateful for any donation, big or small, but there are a few perks we would like to offer you in exchange for your support. 

The first offer, for a donation of £10+ is a limited edition print from one of the over 30 artists exhibiting in the show. The print will be signed by the artist and be an exclusive edition of 5. These will be high quality, A5 ink jet prints which will be posted to your given address after the fundraising ends.
The second offer, for a donation of £20+ is a signed A4 print and a copy of the limited run catalogue signed by a selection of participating artists. 
The catalogue is part of a limited run, this will be an exclusive opportunity for you to own a piece of work by these emerging artists. 
If we do not achieve our target goal, the funds raised will still go towards the catalogue and all the donors will still receive their perks as agreed. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Any help at all will be incredibly helpful! If you are unable to contribute to our target goal, we would greatly appreciate you to share our social media sites to gain even more interest in our degree show. The links are as follows:

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/SyncExhibition

Twitter: @SyncExhibition

Instagram: @syncexhibition


We would like to invite you all to the opening night of the exhibition which will be held at Priestman Building, City Campus in Sunderland on June 12th. The celebrations will begin at 5.30pm so please come and enjoy the work and meet the exhibiting artists.

story:
For English version click here 

 

Point and shoot. Vanishing Berlin ist ein sehr persönlicher Blick auf die Stadt, in der ich geboren und aufgewachsen bin. Seit jeher ein passionierter Flaneur und Beobachter, dokumentiere ich seit vielen Jahren flüchtige Sehenswürdigkeiten, quer durch alle Bezirke. Vor allem Brachen, Ladenfronten und Brandmauern. Orte, die Berlin charakterisieren und die gleichzeitig in rasantem Tempo aus dem Stadtbild verschwinden. 

Dank des Vertrauens von +220 Unterstützern konnte ich ein außergewöhnliches, professionell gestaltetes Fotobuch produzieren. Erscheinungstermin der Erstauflage Ende September 2016, inzwischen ist eine zweite Auflage des Titels erhältlich (ISBN: 978-3000560408). Ich möchte das Vanishing Berlin Projekt auch in Zukunft fortführen und weiterentwickeln und freue mich weiterhin über jede Unterstützung.

Die schnellste und unkomplizierteste Möglichkeit Vanishing Berlin Art zu bestellen, ist diese "In demand" Kampagne bei Indiegogo - einfach entsprechenden "Perk" auswählen. Ihr könnt mir aber gerne auch eine e-mail schicken (alexsteffen@berlin.de) und Eure Bestellung per Banküberweisung bezahlen. Das Buch gibt es inzwischen auch bei Amazon. Für diejenigen, die das Buch erst sehen wollen, gibt es eine Liste mit Buchhandlungen und Concept-Stores meines Vertrauens. 

Einzelhändler können das Buch zu handelsüblichen Konditionen bestellen. Bei Interesse am Vertrieb des Vanishing Berlin Buchs bitte eine e-mail an mich, 

 


Markise. Flottwellstraße, Schöneberg, 2009 / Awning. Flottwellstraße, Schöneberg, 2009

 

Reclaim Your City. Der Ausverkauf der Innenstädte, die Verdrängung von Sub- und Kiezkultur und damit verbunden ein Grundgefühl des Verlusts sind ein weltweites Phänomen. Das Bild vieler Großstädte ist heute geprägt von seelenloser Architektur, Konformität  und steigenden Mieten. Vanishing Berlin dokumentiert Orte, an die wir uns mit Wehmut erinnern werden, obwohl wir nicht einmal ahnten, dass wir sie jemals vermissen würden. Das Buch markiert für mich den Ausgangspunkt für die weitere Auseinandersetzung mit den aktuellen Entwicklungen des städtischen Raums.

 

Gartencenter Alfred Bajon. Spandauerdamm, Spandau, 2013 / Garden centre Alfred Bajon. Spandauerdamm, Spandau, 2013

Nichts Hält Ewig. Viele der Fotos vermitteln den Eindruck, als seien sie bereits vor Jahrzehnten aufgenommen worden. Tatsächlich sind alle Bilder im Zeitraum zwischen 2009 und 2016 entstanden. Mein Interesse gilt dem zeitgenössischen Blick. Nicht die Abbildung der Vergangenheit steht im Fokus, sondern der Prozess der Veränderung. Dem Betrachter stellt sich bei jedem Bild die Frage: Gibt es dieses Motiv noch oder ist es schon verschwunden? 

„Das Neue an den Fotos ist, dass die Bilder durchreisen, „in transition“ sind. Als wäre die Stadt eine Karte, die man einmal liest und dann wegwirft, weil man sie ohnehin nicht vergisst, ob man will oder nicht. Obwohl Vanishing Berlin aus Bruchstücken untergegangener Zeiten besteht, die uns zuzwinkern, die scherzen und grummeln, als wäre es das erste Mal, entsteht ein Bild von einer Stadt, die sich selbst aufgebraucht hat (...). Manchmal wird auch ein anderes Berlin sichtbar, rufen die Bilder eine Erinnerung an eine Art Halbwelt wach, eine verwüstete Landschaft, in der jeder jederzeit landen könnte. (...)" Friedhelm Böpple im Nachwort zu Vanishing Berlin

Reclaim Your Memory. Die Fotos im Buch sind mit anekdotischen Erinnerungen aus meiner Kindheit und Jugend sowie kurzen Notizen zum Zustand der Stadt montiert. Vanishing Berlin lädt den Leser damit auf eine Reise in die eigene Vergangenheit ein.

Schöneberger Serengeti Die Nachmittage verbrachte ich oft mit Erkundungstouren auf meinem Bonanza-Fahrrad. Das Einzugsgebiet reichte vom Winterfeldtplatz, von den Straßenkämpfen damals oft in Rauch und Tränengas gehüllt, über den Christiane F. Babystrich in der Einemstraße bis zum Freigelände am Lützowplatz. Vom Hotel Berlin bis zur Kreuzung Tiergartenstraße erstreckte sich eine riesige Brache, bewachsen mit hohem Gestrüpp, übersäht mit Glasscherben und benutzten Kondomen. Inmitten dieser urbanen Steppe, von der aus man einen schönen Blick auf die Skyline der West-City hatte, stand nur ein einziges Haus, die Taverne. Eine große, karge Baracke, in der zwielichtige Pils-Trinker in Fransenlederjacken Westernabende oder Skatturniere abhielten. Auf dieser Brache wurde mit dem „Frühlingsfest“ alljährlich die Berliner Rummelsaison eröffnet. Jahrzehnte später markieren postmoderne Botschaftsgebäude und die CDU-Parteizentrale hier das Gelände.

 

Traumhäuser im Brachland. Kommandantenstraße, Mitte, 2009 / Dream houses in a Wasteland. Kommandantenstraße, Mitte, 2009

 

Nothing is true, everything is permitted. Warum das Ganze und warum jetzt? Nach jahrelanger intensiver Beschäftigung mit dem Projekt war es mir wichtig, mit dem Vanishing Berlin jetzt an die Öffentlichkeit zu gehen – bevor die totale Besetzung mit Gegenwart die Motive in Geschichte verwandelt. Hier eine Auswahl von Links zur Berichterstattung über das Vanishing Berlin Projekt:

Tagesspiegel: Die Stadt als Abenteuerspielplatz
Berliner Morgenpost: "Dieses Berlin wird es bald nicht mehr geben"
MitVergnügen: "Dieses Berlin verschwindet – und der Fotograf Alexander Steffen hält den Wandel fest"
ze.tt: "Diese Fotos zeigen, wie eine Stadt langsam ihre Seele verliert"
Lolamag: "Documenting the Changing Face of Berlin"


Brache. Chausseestraße, Mitte, 2013 / Wasteland. Chausseestraße, Mitte, 2013

Keine Atempause, Geschichte wird gemacht. Es geht voran. Das Buch bleibt nicht allein. Weitere Ausstellungen, Editionen sowie Text- und Videoarbeiten zu Vanishing Berlin sind bereits in Planung. Ich werde mich in Zukunft weiter mit gleichgesinnten Künstlern, Fotografen und Autoren austauschen und die Arbeit auch auf internationaler Ebene fortführen.

 


Fassade auf der Roten Insel. Leuthenerstraße. Schöneberg,  2009 / Facade in the Red Island district, Leuthenerstraße. Schöneberg,  2009

Für wen ist Vanishing Berlin? Das Buch richtet sich an jene, die Berlin ihre Heimat nennen, auf der Durchreise ins Herz geschlossen oder längst wieder verlassen haben. An Eingeborene, Zugereiste und Touristen. An Buchliebhaber sowie an Fotografie-und Kunstinteressierte. An Historiker, Melancholiker und Stadtentwickler. An Beatniks, Hipster und Flaneure. An Gentrifizierte und Gentrifizierende. In Berlin und überall.

Support your local neighborhood. Warum solltest du Vanishing Berlin unterstützen? Aus Liebe zu Berlin und seinen Ureinwohnern. Aus Interesse an authentischer und unkonventioneller Fotografie. Um den Hauch der Geschichte zu spüren und nicht zuletzt wegen der tollen Perks. 
 

Die Angebote (Perks):


Perk: Vanishing Berlin Book  (Dummy) 144 pages, 160 colour images. Format: 20 x 24 cm, limited offset hardcover edition / limitierte gebundene Erstauflage im Offsetdruck, Text from Friedhelm Böpple & Alexander Steffen, design by Detlev Pusch

 


Perk: Vanishing Berlin Fine Art Print (13x18cm / 18x24cm / 30x40cm).  Signed, stamped and  limited to 10 copies per image and size / signiert, gestempelt und auf 10 Exemplare pro Größe limitiert (see selection in the gallery/Auswahl siehe Galerie). Including wooden frame & Passepartout /inklusive Holzrahmen und Passepartout.

 

 



Perk: Vanishing Berlin Woodprint / Holzdruck (20 x 11 cm).  Signed, stamped and  limited to 10+3 copies per image / signiert, gestempelt und auf 10+3 Exemplare limitiert


Perk: Vanishing Berlin Silk Screen Poster  / Siebdruck (76,2 x 111, 8 cm) Signed, stamped and  limited to 20+3 copies / signiert, gestempelt und limitiert auf 20+3

Style kommt nicht mit der Post. Wer steht hinter dem Projekt? Für die Gestaltung des Fotobuchs habe ich den mehrfach ausgezeichneten Buchdesigner Detlev Pusch gewinnen können. Der Fotograf Alex Janetzko hat mich bei der Bildbearbeitung unterstützt. Das Nachwort stammt von Autor und Lebenskünstler Friedhelm Böpple. Die Journalistin Fiona Ehlers hat mit mir ein ausführliches Interview zum Projekt geführt. Konrad Lauten hat mich zum Thema Crowdfunding beraten. Der Videotrailer zum Projekt kommt aus der Feder von Paul Ott. Gemeinsam mit der Kuratorin und Galeristin Annemarie Laber (Projektraum 102) habe ich meine ersten Ausstellungen organisiert. 

Besonderer Dank für Inspiration und Zuspruch geht überdies an Maike Bildhauer, William S. Burroughs, Barbara Dechant, Ali Ghandtschi, Fehlfarben, Nicolai Max Hahn, Diethelm Kaiser, Anne Marburger, Ede Müller, Heiner Müller, Frank Kusche, Klaus Lemke, Isabel Ott, Patrick Paetzold, Alex Reuter, Uka Roesch, Thomas Rusch, Kathrin Schafroth, Isabella Steffen, Robert und Karina Sparmann, Jörg Sasse und Hans von Trotha & Alle Unterstützer der Vanishing Berlin Crowdfunding Kampagne.

Außerdem möchte ich mich bei den vielen Initiativen, wie z.B. "Stadt von Unten" und "Bizim Kiez" für ihren unermüdlichen und kreativen Widerstand gegen die Übermacht der Investoren und die komplett verfehlte Immobilien- und Stadtentwicklungspolitik der vergangenen Jahre bedanken. Der Ausverkauf und die Verdrängung müssen gestoppt werden. Berlin braucht einen Plan B.

Alexander Steffen (*1967) geboren und aufgewachsen in West-Berlin. Kindheit in einer Wohngemeinschaft in Schöneberg. Politik-Studium an der Freien Universität Berlin. Ausbildung im Fotoverlag Dirk Nishen am Tempelhofer Berg und in London. Begegnung mit Allen Ginsberg und seinen Reality Sandwiches. Redakteur einer Fotobiografie über William S. Burroughs. Nach dem Mauerfall unterwegs in den Techno Clubs und Ruinen von Berlins neuer Mitte. Von 1999 bis 2005 Betreiber der Galerie und Agentur transition in der Oranienstraße in Kreuzberg. Seit 2005 Mitarbeiter der Berlinale. 2009 Beginn des Vanishing Berlin Projekts.

 

Point and shoot. Vanishing Berlin provides a very personal perspective on the city in which I was born and raised. Being a passionate flâneur and observer, I have been photographing transient landmarks all over Berlin for many years, focusing mainly on wastelands, storefronts and brick walls. These places characterise Berlin, but equally they are vanishing at an unprecedented pace. 

Thanks to the kind support of +220 backers, I was able to publish a first edition of Vanishing Berlin, an extraordinary, professionally-designed photo book (release date : End of September 2016). Meanwhile there is a second edition available (ISBN: 978-3000560408) I want to continue and enlarge the Vanishing Berlin project in the near future. For that I appreciate any further support.

The easiest way to order a copy of the book or Vansihing Berlin Art is to use this Indemand website on Indiegogo. Simply choose your favourite "Perk" and pay via creditcard or Paypal. If you like you can order also via e-mail (alexsteffen@berlin.de) and use banktranfer. You can also order the book via Amazon. For those of you who want to touch and feel the book first,  here is a list of bookstores and shops of my choice. If you want to distribute the book, just let me know. For resellers I am happy to offer commercial conditions.

 


Linoleum Pannier. Kreuzberg, 2016

Reclaim your city. City centres being sold out, underground scenes and neighbourhood identities being displaced, the associated underlying feelings of loss; all these are worldwide phenomena. Today the faces of many cities are characterised by soulless architecture, conformity and surging rents. Vanishing Berlin captures the places that we will remember wistfully, though we did not think we would ever miss them.

 


Rütli-Brache. Neukölln, 2015

Nothing lasts forever. Many of the photos look as if they were taken decades ago. In fact, all the images were captured between 2009 and 2016. I am interested in the contemporary; it is not the depiction of the past that I wish focus on, but the process of change. For the viewers each picture should raise the question: Does this place still exist or has it already vanished?

“What is new about the photos is that these images are passing through, they are “in transition”, as if the city is a map to be studied and tossed aside, because we know we will never forget it anyway – whether we want to or not. Though Vanishing Berlin is made of fragments of a dying past that flirt, joke or mumble to us, as if engaging with us for the first time, the picture that arises is one of a city that has been consumed by itself (…). At times yet another Berlin comes into view, images that conjure up memories of a kind of demi-monde, a desolate landscape in which anyone could end up at any time (…)” From the afterword to Vanishing Berlin by Friedhelm Böpple.

 


Yorckbrücken. Kreuzberg, 2014

Reclaim your memory. The photos are accompanied by anecdotes from my early childhood and youth as well as by brief notes on the current state of the city, creating a montage of images and words. Vanishing Berlin invites the readers to journey into their own past.
The Serengeti of Schöneberg.  I often spent the afternoon exploring the neighbourhoods on my High Riser. My cruising radius stretched from Winterfeldtplatz, which at the time was often engulfed in smoke and tear gas from street fights, to Christiane F’s teenage streetwalker patch in Einemstraße, to the open area at Lützowplatz. An enormous wasteland, covered with high scrub, pieces of broken glass and used condoms, which stretched from the Hotel Berlin to the junction with Tiergartenstraße. Amidst this urban scrubland, which overlooked the skyline of the city’s west, there was only one single building. The Tavern was a big, bleak barrack in which dodgy beer drinkers in fringed leather jackets came together for Country & Western evenings and skat tournaments. In July of every year this wasteland hosted the Spring Festival, kicking off the annual Berlin funfair season. Decades later, postmodern embassy buildings and the headquarters of the German conservative Christian Democratic Union (CDU) mark the landscape.

 


Sexothek Kino. Neukölln, 2014

Nothing is true; everything is permitted. What is the point anyway and why now? After years of intensive engagement with this project it is time to take Vanishing Berlin into the public eye – before these spaces become totally occupied by the present and are turned into history. 

The book is not an isolated project. Further exhibitions and editions, as well as both text- and video-based works are already in the pipeline. Creating a dialogue and exchanging ideas with like-minded artists, photographers, and authors will continue to be an important part of my work, and I have already taken the first steps to ensure this project is brought to the international stage.

Who is the target group of Vanishing Berlin? The book is for all Berlin lovers. For natives, newcomers and tourists. For booklovers, for photography and art freaks. For historians, melancholics and urban developers. For beatniks, hipsters and flâneurs. For victims and perpetrators of gentrification. In Berlin and elsewhere.

Why should I support Vanishing Berlin? Out of a love for Berlin and its inhabitants. Out of a passion for authentic and unconventional photography. Out of a desire to sense the vestiges of history. And last but not least for the extraordinary perks. 

Where does your money go? Your money will be used exclusively for furher Vanishing Berlin projects.   

 


Garagen. Prenzlauer Berg, 2015

Alexander Steffen (*1967) was born and raised in West-Berlin. He grew up in a shared flat in Schöneberg, studied Political Sciences at the Freie Universität Berlin, trained at Dirk Nishen publishing house. Discovered Allen Ginsberg and Reality Sandwiches. Edited a photobiography of William S. Burroughs. Spent time exploring the techno clubs and ruins of Berlin’s new centre after the fall of the wall. Was director of the art gallery transition from 1999-2005. Has been working for the Berlin International Film Festival (Berlinale) since 2005. 2009 marks the start of the Vanishing Berlin project.

© Alexander Steffen alexsteffen@berlin.de /Instagram / Facebook / Website

Perk: Vanishing Berlin Fine Art Print (13x18cm / 18x24cm / 30x40cm).  Signed, stamped and  limited to 10 copies per image and size / signiert, gestempelt und auf 10 Exemplare pro Größe limitiert (see selection in the gallery/Auswahl siehe Galerie). Including wooden frame & passepartout /inklusive Holzrahmen und Passepartout.

 




Perk: Vanishing Berlin Woodprint / Holzdruck (20 x 11 cm).  Signed, stamped and  limited to 10+3 copies per image / signiert, gestempelt und auf 10+3 Exemplare limitiert


Perk: Vanishing Berlin Silk Screen Poster  / Siebdruck (76,2 x 111, 8 cm)Signed, stamped and  limited to 20+3 copies / signiert, gestempelt und limitiert auf 20+3
story_txt:
For English version click here  Point and shoot. Vanishing Berlin ist ein sehr persönlicher Blick auf die Stadt, in der ich geboren und aufgewachsen bin. Seit jeher ein passionierter Flaneur und Beobachter, dokumentiere ich seit vielen Jahren flüchtige Sehenswürdigkeiten, quer durch alle Bezirke. Vor allem Brachen, Ladenfronten und Brandmauern. Orte, die Berlin charakterisieren und die gleichzeitig in rasantem Tempo aus dem Stadtbild verschwinden. Dank des Vertrauens von +220 Unterstützern konnte ich ein außergewöhnliches, professionell gestaltetes Fotobuch produzieren. Erscheinungstermin der Erstauflage Ende September 2016, inzwischen ist eine zweite Auflage des Titels erhältlich (ISBN: 978-3000560408). Ich möchte das Vanishing Berlin Projekt auch in Zukunft fortführen und weiterentwickeln und freue mich weiterhin über jede Unterstützung.Die schnellste und unkomplizierteste Möglichkeit Vanishing Berlin Art zu bestellen, ist diese "In demand" Kampagne bei Indiegogo - einfach entsprechenden "Perk" auswählen. Ihr könnt mir aber gerne auch eine e-mail schicken (alexsteffen@berlin.de) und Eure Bestellung per Banküberweisung bezahlen. Das Buch gibt es inzwischen auch bei Amazon. Für diejenigen, die das Buch erst sehen wollen, gibt es eine Liste mit Buchhandlungen und Concept-Stores meines Vertrauens. 
Einzelhändler können das Buch zu handelsüblichen Konditionen bestellen. Bei Interesse am Vertrieb des Vanishing Berlin Buchs bitte eine e-mail an mich, 
 
Markise. Flottwellstraße, Schöneberg, 2009 / Awning. Flottwellstraße, Schöneberg, 2009
 
Reclaim Your City. Der Ausverkauf der Innenstädte, die Verdrängung von Sub- und Kiezkultur und damit verbunden ein Grundgefühl des Verlusts sind ein weltweites Phänomen. Das Bild vieler Großstädte ist heute geprägt von seelenloser Architektur, Konformität  und steigenden Mieten. Vanishing Berlin dokumentiert Orte, an die wir uns mit Wehmut erinnern werden, obwohl wir nicht einmal ahnten, dass wir sie jemals vermissen würden. Das Buch markiert für mich den Ausgangspunkt für die weitere Auseinandersetzung mit den aktuellen Entwicklungen des städtischen Raums.
 
Gartencenter Alfred Bajon. Spandauerdamm, Spandau, 2013 / Garden centre Alfred Bajon. Spandauerdamm, Spandau, 2013

Nichts Hält Ewig. Viele der Fotos vermitteln den Eindruck, als seien sie bereits vor Jahrzehnten aufgenommen worden. Tatsächlich sind alle Bilder im Zeitraum zwischen 2009 und 2016 entstanden. Mein Interesse gilt dem zeitgenössischen Blick. Nicht die Abbildung der Vergangenheit steht im Fokus, sondern der Prozess der Veränderung. Dem Betrachter stellt sich bei jedem Bild die Frage: Gibt es dieses Motiv noch oder ist es schon verschwunden? 

„Das Neue an den Fotos ist, dass die Bilder durchreisen, „in transition“ sind. Als wäre die Stadt eine Karte, die man einmal liest und dann wegwirft, weil man sie ohnehin nicht vergisst, ob man will oder nicht. Obwohl Vanishing Berlin aus Bruchstücken untergegangener Zeiten besteht, die uns zuzwinkern, die scherzen und grummeln, als wäre es das erste Mal, entsteht ein Bild von einer Stadt, die sich selbst aufgebraucht hat (...). Manchmal wird auch ein anderes Berlin sichtbar, rufen die Bilder eine Erinnerung an eine Art Halbwelt wach, eine verwüstete Landschaft, in der jeder jederzeit landen könnte. (...)" Friedhelm Böpple im Nachwort zu Vanishing Berlin

Korsett Engelke, Kanstraße, Charlottenburg, 2009 / Engelke’s Corseterie, Kanstraße, Charlottenburg, 2009Reclaim Your Memory. Die Fotos im Buch sind mit anekdotischen Erinnerungen aus meiner Kindheit und Jugend sowie kurzen Notizen zum Zustand der Stadt montiert. Vanishing Berlin lädt den Leser damit auf eine Reise in die eigene Vergangenheit ein.

Schöneberger Serengeti Die Nachmittage verbrachte ich oft mit Erkundungstouren auf meinem Bonanza-Fahrrad. Das Einzugsgebiet reichte vom Winterfeldtplatz, von den Straßenkämpfen damals oft in Rauch und Tränengas gehüllt, über den Christiane F. Babystrich in der Einemstraße bis zum Freigelände am Lützowplatz. Vom Hotel Berlin bis zur Kreuzung Tiergartenstraße erstreckte sich eine riesige Brache, bewachsen mit hohem Gestrüpp, übersäht mit Glasscherben und benutzten Kondomen. Inmitten dieser urbanen Steppe, von der aus man einen schönen Blick auf die Skyline der West-City hatte, stand nur ein einziges Haus, die Taverne. Eine große, karge Baracke, in der zwielichtige Pils-Trinker in Fransenlederjacken Westernabende oder Skatturniere abhielten. Auf dieser Brache wurde mit dem „Frühlingsfest“ alljährlich die Berliner Rummelsaison eröffnet. Jahrzehnte später markieren postmoderne Botschaftsgebäude und die CDU-Parteizentrale hier das Gelände.

 
Traumhäuser im Brachland. Kommandantenstraße, Mitte, 2009 / Dream houses in a Wasteland. Kommandantenstraße, Mitte, 2009
 
Nothing is true, everything is permitted. Warum das Ganze und warum jetzt? Nach jahrelanger intensiver Beschäftigung mit dem Projekt war es mir wichtig, mit dem Vanishing Berlin jetzt an die Öffentlichkeit zu gehen – bevor die totale Besetzung mit Gegenwart die Motive in Geschichte verwandelt. Hier eine Auswahl von Links zur Berichterstattung über das Vanishing Berlin Projekt:

Tagesspiegel: Die Stadt als AbenteuerspielplatzBerliner Morgenpost: "Dieses Berlin wird es bald nicht mehr geben"MitVergnügen: "Dieses Berlin verschwindet – und der Fotograf Alexander Steffen hält den Wandel fest"ze.tt: "Diese Fotos zeigen, wie eine Stadt langsam ihre Seele verliert"Lolamag: "Documenting the Changing Face of Berlin"

Brache. Chausseestraße, Mitte, 2013 / Wasteland. Chausseestraße, Mitte, 2013
Keine Atempause, Geschichte wird gemacht. Es geht voran. Das Buch bleibt nicht allein. Weitere Ausstellungen, Editionen sowie Text- und Videoarbeiten zu Vanishing Berlin sind bereits in Planung. Ich werde mich in Zukunft weiter mit gleichgesinnten Künstlern, Fotografen und Autoren austauschen und die Arbeit auch auf internationaler Ebene fortführen.
 
Fassade auf der Roten Insel. Leuthenerstraße. Schöneberg,  2009 / Facade in the Red Island district, Leuthenerstraße. Schöneberg,  2009
Für wen ist Vanishing Berlin? Das Buch richtet sich an jene, die Berlin ihre Heimat nennen, auf der Durchreise ins Herz geschlossen oder längst wieder verlassen haben. An Eingeborene, Zugereiste und Touristen. An Buchliebhaber sowie an Fotografie-und Kunstinteressierte. An Historiker, Melancholiker und Stadtentwickler. An Beatniks, Hipster und Flaneure. An Gentrifizierte und Gentrifizierende. In Berlin und überall.

Perk: Vanishing Berlin Silk Screen Poster  / Siebdruck (76,2 x 111, 8 cm)Signed, stamped and  limited to 20+3 copies / signiert, gestempelt und limitiert auf 20+3

Perk: Vanishing Berlin Marmorgram  / Marblegram (10 x 10 cm Fotodruck auf Marmor/Print on marble) Signed, stamped and  limited to 20+3 copies / signiert, gestempelt und limitiert auf 20+3

story:
Since its beginning as a powerful voice of the Egyptian revolution, graffiti and street art have mainly appeared on city walls. “New Walls” is a public arts project in which Egyptian artists will meet international muralists to paint the homes of the village of Tunis in Al Fayoum.

Egyptian street artists are now faced with politically polarized streets, and our project offers them an alternative canvas to explore. It's chance to re-energize and refresh the street art scene in Egypt and to explore street art themes beyond the political.


The "New Walls" project in the village of Tunis - famous for its pottery, natural sights, and beautiful houses - is an experiment to transform an Egyptian village into an open-air street art museum. It is the perfect place for such a project as it is home to many artists and a vibrant community of craftsmen and women.

In the period of 22-28 November 2015 (one week before the annual Tunis pottery festival), we will realize our project. The participating artists will have the chance to visit the village, discover its walls, and make connections with the locals.



Egypt

- Ammar Abo Bakr             - Art Trip                                    - Aya Tarek

- Israa El-Naggar                - El Moshir                                  - El Mozza

- El Teneen                           - Maghraffiti + Emmy             - Mona Lisa Brigades

- Nemo                                  - Zeft


Spain                                     - Gonzalo Borondo                   - BTOY

Tunis/France                  - Sunra                                         - El Seed (unconfirmed) 

Lebanon                               - Ali Rafei 


The idea is to exchange knowledge with other artists from Egypt and in the regional street art scene. The meeting of the group of artists will help them explore and share concepts, techniques, and applications.

Since many Egyptian street artists have been away from the streets for sometime now, this is also a clear invitation for them to come together in a new setting and face new open walls.

New Walls is a pilot project so documentation of the process and the outcome is very important to us. We will constantly post updates throughout social media, and we will film the process of transforming Tunis wall by wall. This material will help anyone who plans to put together a similar project in the future to learn from what worked for us and to avoid our mistakes.


   

    



El Teneen              -    Curator
Shady Ghaly        -    Coordinator in Tunis
Amna Magdy       -    Campaign Coordinator
Rowan El Shimi  -    Video Mastermind  

We would like to thank 

-Mohamed Gomaa, the pottery artist  in Vazat gallery, our campaign partner.

-Maurice Louca for letting us use Al Mashoub audio track in our campaign video 

- Ali Azmi our campaign advisor.

story:
About

Launched: September 7, 2020

Black women and women of color, rarely get the support they need in the start-up world to thrive. Especially in light of the turbulent social climate that exists today, we need to highlight underrepresented voices more than ever.

NAL Media is an online networking platform for underrepresented artists to connect and gain access to mentorship. For years, the media industry has determined success is equivalent to who you know. As a result, artists with few connections and resources to succeed, are often silenced. Our solution, is a platform dedicated to mentorship and resources to provide clear steps for artists of all forms to succeed.

In our launch, we paired 33 mentors in the media industry, with 33 underrepresented artists. Artists are based all over the United States and internationally in Mexico. Our efforts have already helped so many artists gain access to conquer the gatekeeping that exist in media. 

Your contribution will help us do the following: 
  • Launch the final product of our beta platform 
  • Connect underrepresented artists with mentorship 
  • Help supply monetary funds to support the work of underrepresented artists 
  • Provide financial stability for the company in our first year 

What We Need 

In our first year, we've determined we need a total of $76,350 to support continued product developments and our mobile-app rollout:

  • Salary of Owner-Manager: 1,000

  • Salary 1: 750

  • Salary 2: 300

  • Salary 3: 300

  • Advertising: 3,000

  • Special Project: 5,000

  • IOS Apps: 532

  • Web Development: 8500

  • Employee Expansion: 5000

  • Promotional Cost: 1000

  • Supplies: 1805

  • Insurance: 1500

  • Taxes and Insurance: 7625

  • Merchandise: 10000

  • Maintenance: 1500

  • Legal and other professional fees: 15000

  • Miscellaneous: 13,358

The Impact

Your contribution will help us continue to disrupt the gatekeeping that exists in the media industry. Below are a few testimonials from our current mentees:

  • Thank you all for creating this platform! It is difficult to know how to navigate the entertainment and media industry, especially as a person of color who does not have the connections to the “right” people. I can’t wait to meet more people in the industry and follow their journey on the NAL Media platform and hopefully through the Mentorship Program.

  • I believe this program will equip the selected candidates with resources to improve our approach to being our creative selves without compromising our creative vision through corporate red-tape. If “diversity drives innovation” the talent pool should also reflect that. I would also like the opportunity to build connections with other creatives so we could be the future to enforce said change. This is a great initiative and I would love to be able to learn and grow with this organization. I'm a great collaborate and live by the motto "create. execute.win." I hope we can do that together!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share with friends and family on social media!

story:
THE ARTIST

Nicki is an artist living in Columbus, Ohio, where she tells the stories of place and transformation through  sculpture, installation, and performance.  She loves that her art is not only for herself, but it is also influenced and connected to the community where she lives and works. Although currently entrenched in Ohio, she has exhibited her artwork across the US and has been featured in many online and physical publications. She recently won a spot to exhibit artwork in the Springfield Museum of Art in Springfield, Ohio. She needs your help creating Packed; her newest large scale installation, which will debut at the Museum on October 5th, 2019. 

 

THE PROJECT

Packed is crafted from 150 laser cut cardboard homes which directly reference a real-world pocket of a neighborhood very close to where she lives, just outside Columbus, Ohio. The individual cardboard homes, each roughly measuring 12 inches x 12 inches, will be piled on top of each other within the Museum to create an expansive landscape of  tumbled architecture. Most of the homes will remain unadorned and dark inside, contrasting with a select few that will have lighting installed within. Those sparsely spaced homes will be perched throughout the mountainous piles, guiding viewers through the installation like small, hopeful beacons leading the way. Conveying the duality of this curious, beautiful, engineered neighborhood. 

 

HOW YOU CAN HELP

Nicki is an artist invested in creating artwork with her own two hands, but in order to produce this project in the time allotted, she decided that laser cutting her cardboard would be most efficient. Turns out, laser cutting is EXPENSIVE.  But, determined to bring her project to life, and not finding any reasonable alternatives, she took a risk, sourced a great local laser cutter and pulled out her Discover card.  Everything is cut, and assembly has already begun, but her Discover bill is stressing her out. Please consider helping Nicki pay off her laser cutting charge, and support her in creating this piece dedicated to the homes we choose to live in, the spaces we occupy, and lives we lead within them. 

 

DOLLARS AND CENTSTS

$1200 is all Nicki needs to pay off her laser cutting charge. She is a working artist with a full-time job, but this project is definitely out of budget. Her already stressed finances cannot bear the burden of this debt for long.  By contributing to her campaign, you are allowing her the time and energy to focus on completing her project for the Museum, rather than spending her efforts picking up extra shifts to pay it off. 

Every little bit helps! Even if Nicki doesn't raise all $1200, every penny raised will go towards her laser cutting bill regardless. And hey, everything is already laser cut, so there's no chance that the project will fail should it not reach it's goal!

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN CONTRIBUTE

Even if you are unable to support her with a financial contribution, please share Nicki's artwork and campaign with your friends and family. Every action you take helps spread the word about her project and grows her audience so she can continue to make art for herself and for the community.  And she can't wait to see you at the Springfield Museum on October 5th for the opening!!

story:
Hello beautiful people,


My name is Yeva Deli. I am an actress and a singer, originally from a beautiful country called Lithuania, but currently based in the UK. I started singing when my mom brought me to a singing lesson at the age of 6 - since that day music leads me in life. 


In 2014, I graduated from the Lithuanian Academy of Music and Theatre gaining a BA degree in acting on screen. This gave me knowledge and experience of how to work in front of a camera.

In 2018, I released my first original song called Raabta and made a music video in Iceland to fulfil the song with a beautiful, cinematic story.

Raabta song was played on BBC Wiltshire, Lithuanian National Television and it also won the best music video award at the  Music Festival in Spain. I couldn’t describe how much all of this means to me, as this song was my first! Once again huge thanks to everyone who helped me to realise this!

Today we have a new project with a social theme - “UNDER THE SURFACE”, which will involve an EP that I'm recording together with the founders of a Lithuanian recording studio “Rhyme to Rise” - Nerijaus Ramanauskas (NRJuice) ir Ričardas Mikalauskas (Richard Mika) and a set of music videos for the songs on the EP. The songs on this EP will be centered around different forms of violence and long lasting emotions and psychological states that it can cause. During the writing process, we were thinking of how we could start a discussion and dive deeper into those emotions. Why do we feel them, how do they affect us and are they in our power to control?  Who’s fault is it when a person can’t handle it anymore and becomes cruel to himself or others? These situations can be very complicated.. We decided to create 4 music videos analyzing these moments. Together with a talented director Lakkys Kac, one of the greatest lithuanian actresses Monika Vaičiulyte and a magnificent make up artist Elena Permogorskaya we will create a visual journey with metamorphism and symbolism, inviting everyone to see those situations from a different angle.

UNDER THE SURFACE - will start a discussion about these emotions and conditions that we often hide under a mask and will bring them into the light.

We need support to rent technical equipment and for marketing to allow us to reach a bigger audience in Lithuania and abroad. Every little bit helps and means not only money but a gesture which shows us that these kinds of topics are important and that together we can start a different way of communication.

One cup of coffee today for the art.

story:
Hi.  I'm Matt.

I'm a physicist, an artist, an engineer, a father, and a Burner.

Three years ago, at Burning Man, I stopped and asked myself: if I wanted to create art without boundaries, without regard for practicality, or possibility, or cost, what would I create?  Torch Song was the outcome of that process.

Giant flaming electronic metal art is difficult, and ambitious, and absurd.  And it is our monument to the absurd world we have all been thrust into.  We have made so much progress over the last three years.  We've built a prototype, assembled a team, and started production.  And we need your help to take it across the finish line.  And if you're interested in getting involved in the project, head down to the Come Help Us section below to find out how. 

Absurd Times and Dangerous Art

We recognize that the world has gotten a lot scarier for a lot of people since we embarked on this project.  And, while we like our art dangerous, we don't like our world that way.  So, we will be donating 10% of the net proceeds from our fundraiser to the ACLU, to help keep the world a safe place for expressing dangerous ideas.

Why We Need Your Help

Shit's expensive, man.  I've invested thousands of dollars into Torch Song already, and every penny was worth it.  And in addition to the raw materials like metal, electronics, and propane, we'll need to transport it and power it as well.

But, more than your money, much much more, we need your support.  And your friends' support, and your friends' friends' support.  Because we want to make art for our community, and our world.  And we want you to be able to say that you helped out.

Some of the Perks

Stickers!  Who doesn't love stickers?

Hoodies!

And, our custom designed pendant!

 

Our Progress

Torch Song started out in my basement, building prototype after prototype after prototype, trying to get the exact effect I wanted.  And, some of those prototypes did not work out well.

But after a lot of sweat and a few singed eyebrows, we got to where we are today.  Each Torch Song unit uses high-torque planetary gear motors to drive a flame head shuttle along a set of rails:

The flames are powered by propane, and ignition comes from silicon-nitride hot surface ignitors

 

So far, we've built nine frames (the skeleton of each unit), and three of them almost completely ready.

Come Help Us Build Torch Song

We're at The Box Shop most weekends, welding, cutting, drilling, and toiling, and we'd love your help.  Visit and like our Facebook page to find out about events and build days.  Email us or join our build team mailing list to volunteer.  And visit our Torch Song 3D simulator to help us write programs to run on Torch Song.

story:
This campaign is to produce and promote the 39th annual wall calendar featuring my latest paintings, and the funds for printing have been raised! Now we're into a stretch goal to underwrite additional production costs and to promote it, and I hope you'll contribute to the extended goal !

Times have changed, and the traditional publishing and distribution system is no longer viable for work like mine. I want to reach a wider audience through the magic of people-powered networks and social media.    

A little background: my watercolors are painted in a non-traditional manner. I’ve been exhibiting professionally since 1974, had an 80-piece retrospective at the Berman Museum, and was a member of an arts delegation to China in 2006. There are 2 published monographs documenting my work: In Bloom (1994) and Blueprints for Paradise (2005.) I’ve always used my art making to support many nonprofit causes for peace, violence prevention, social justice, the environment, and women's issues including doing workshops with battered women recovering from trauma. 

I am blessed to have a career doing something I love: creating things that bring pleasure, healing and inspiration to others.  One way I do this is by publishing a calendar that makes art affordable and accessible. Incredibly loyal customers send me heartwarming stories about what my work means to them. Your contribution will help me to keep producing it for them – and you – and  help  expand my audience and spread more delight!

My initial goal was to raise $10,000 to pay for scanning, photography, layout, printing, binding, and packaging the 2019 edition, and you made that happen! I purposely made that goal very conservative. There are still more costs that need to be covered, hence the stretch goal. I'd love to raise an additional $5,000.

Your contribution and support means a great deal to me. In addition to the getting a copy of the calendar, there are other perks I hope you’ll like, so please explore (and use the drop-downs to see all that’s included in each one.)

In addition to contributing, spreading the word about this campaign is the most helpful thing you can do! Personal recommendations and referrals are invaluable, And it’s easy to use Indiegogo’s share tools.

Visit my website www.sarasteele.com and join my mailing list! Make an appointment to visit my studio! And write to me: I’m always open to suggestions of places to exhibit, sell and license my work. 

Thanks!

Sara Steele,
Working to make the world happier one painting at a time.
story_txt: This campaign is to produce and promote the 39th annual wall calendar featuring my latest paintings, and the funds for printing have been raised! Now we're into a stretch goal to underwrite additional production costs and to promote it, and I hope you'll contribute to the extended goal !Times have changed, and the traditional publishing and distribution system is no longer viable for work like mine. I want to reach a wider audience through the magic of people-powered networks and social media.    A little background: my watercolors are painted in a non-traditional manner. I’ve been exhibiting professionally since 1974, had an 80-piece retrospective at the Berman Museum, and was a member of an arts delegation to China in 2006. There are 2 published monographs documenting my work: In Bloom (1994) and Blueprints for Paradise (2005.) I’ve always used my art making to support many nonprofit causes for peace, violence prevention, social justice, the environment, and women's issues including doing workshops with battered women recovering from trauma. I am blessed to have a career doing something I love: creating things that bring pleasure, healing and inspiration to others.  One way I do this is by publishing a calendar that makes art affordable and accessible. Incredibly loyal customers send me heartwarming stories about what my work means to them. Your contribution will help me to keep producing it for them – and you – and  help  expand my audience and spread more delight!My initial goal was to raise $10,000 to pay for scanning, photography, layout, printing, binding, and packaging the 2019 edition, and you made that happen! I purposely made that goal very conservative. There are still more costs that need to be covered, hence the stretch goal. I'd love to raise an additional $5,000.Your contribution and support means a great deal to me. In addition to the getting a copy of the calendar, there are other perks I hope you’ll like, so please explore (and use the drop-downs to see all that’s included in each one.)In addition to contributing, spreading the word about this campaign is the most helpful thing you can do! Personal recommendations and referrals are invaluable, And it’s easy to use Indiegogo’s share tools.Visit my website www.sarasteele.com and join my mailing list! Make an appointment to visit my studio! And write to me: I’m always open to suggestions of places to exhibit, sell and license my work. Thanks!Sara Steele,Working to make the world happier one painting at a time.

story:
Short Summary

OH, hey there.  My dad, 21st century luddite and isolationist, has asked me to help him have an artshow that will do justice to the culmination of his life's work.  His work is incredible, detailed, palpable.  I would like him to have the recognition he deserves.  As a full-time teacher and grad student I don't have a lot of time to arrange a lot of little shows (that tend to take large commissions), so my goal is to raise money to have his artwork professionally and uniformly matted and framed, in preparation for a gallery show next Spring at the [ac2] space.  

 

This project is immensely important to both him and me.  My father has never had a show, not only because navigating the logistics of it is overwhelming for him, but also because he has never really wanted to let go of the work.  As fellow artists know, letting go of a work is the perhaps the most difficult, yet also the most imperative part of the artistic process.  Letting go is possibly the whole point of making art.  Yet all these many years he has clung to his paintings, drawings and collages, agonizing over details and never seeing them as complete.  From my perspective, art seemed more a source of pain and frustration than an outlet or a cathartic release.  And it is only now that my father feels he is ready to show himself--through his art--to the world, despite whatever imperfection or inconsistency may remain.

 

What We Need & What You Get

I've looked into several galleries in Albuquerque and Santa Fe.  A majority of them don't accept work from unknown artists.  Those that do are often very small spaces that offer little exposure and take a significant commission on work sold.  As this is my father's life's work and his first show, I'm not willing to give away at least half of it just for the space.  Months and, in some cases, years have been poured into a two-dimensional representation.  Should someone wish to purchase a piece I feel it is only fair that my father recieve all of the profit.  

I have found a large space downtown that does not take a commission, but does require a $200 deposit and asks that the pieces be professionally framed and matted.  Funds will go to securing a space and having his art matted and framed.  Additional funds will go to publicity.  

The Impact

The magnitude of this project is limitless, it extends from the inward depths of a father and a daughter, to radiate out and into the depths of other human beings in the world.  It means the fulfillment of connection, the conclusion of an interpretation that, up to this point, remained visible and audible to only one man.  

As we are starting from nothing, every little bit is appreciated. ... to reflect an inner form of perception in motion, a representation of--as I see it--cognition before differentiation common to all beings in the world.
