story:
Bill Day has been one of America's top political cartoonists for more than thirty years. He's won a room full of awards, and his syndicated cartoons are read by millions of newspaper readers across the country. He's also unemployed, and is close to losing his house.

Day was the cartoonist for The Detroit Free-Press, and then The Commercial Appeal in Memphis, Tennessee, up until March of 2009 when he was laid-off as part of a slew of newsroom cuts made at the height of the economic recession. After three years of searching for a new newspaper, Bill now works at a bike shop during the day to pay the bills; the money he earns fixing bicycles isn't enough for him to afford his mortgage, so Bill is close to losing his house and being unable to continue to draw the great cartoons he's become known for.


Background

Political cartoons are more popular than ever. Cartoons are quick, bite-sized pieces of visual commentary that work great in print and on the Web. Cartoons spread across social networks like Facebook and Twitter like wildfire, look great on tablets and on smart phones, and can easily reach millions of readers in the click of a few buttons.  Editorial cartoons are part of state-mandated testing in 8th and 11th grade, and a part of the weekly homework for millions of students in America.

Editorial cartoonists are still widely syndicated in newspapers across the country and have a huge audience, but national syndication pays only a small fraction of what cartoonists made from traditional newspaper staff jobs, and as newspapers decline, cartoonist jobs have been cut, making editorial cartoonists an endangered species. The rate of editorial cartoonists leaving the profession has accelerated in recent years and months.

An important and popular part of the public debate is in danger of being lost. Today there are less than 70 editorial cartoonists in America who have staff jobs; a few years ago there were twice that number.  Cartoonists have been losing their jobs in tandem with newsroom journalists, but since there were fewer cartoonists to start with, the diminished numbers threaten the viability of our art form and it's role in the public debate.

You can help stop the decline of our profession, by saving one important voice at an important time.  You can keep Bill Day working, and we'll make sure his work continues to be a part of the public debate, seen by millions or readers.
 
Goals

Our goal is to raise $35,000, to be paid as a "salary" to Bill to draw at least four editorial cartoons a week, every week, for an entire year. Bill's cartoons cover national issues, everything from the Presidential election to Wall Street, the dysfunctional Congress and our corrupt political system. We'll produce two eBook collections of his cartoons - "2012: A Year in Cartoons" and "2013: A Year in Cartoons" that will chronicle the events of the year through the spectrum of Bill's sharp wit and pen tips.

And if we're able to raise more; $70,000 or $100,000, we will keep Bill working at the important job of drawing political cartoons for the next 2-3 years.  All donated funds will be kept in a segregated fund for Bill's salary; CagleCartoons.com will not share in any of it; all of the funds, after Indiegogo's share and expenses, will go to Bill, in exchange for his commitment to continue his great work, and to provide the donors with great premiums, including Bill's original artwork.

Our unique American art form needs you.  Bill needs you.  Please, save our profession, save Bill and keep an important, progressive voice in the public debate by donating to keep Bill drawing for the next year and beyond.

For press inquiries, or to interview Bill Day, call (805) 969-2829 or email cari@cagle.com.

More of Bill Day's great political cartoons:

story:
Hi, my name's Lilly and I am 12 years old. I love animals, nature, and video games.  More than anything else, I love making arts and crafts. My mom says she could tell that I would be an artist by the time I was 2 years old because I never got tired of crafting. My favorite types of art are sculpting, drawing, and painting but I'm always interested in trying new styles.  If you look at the photo gallery, you should be able to see some of the things I've done in the last year.

I work on my art almost every day.  Sometimes I use youtube videos or library books but I'd really like to take some art classes and get some new art supplies.  I think that working with an artist would really help me improve my skills. If I am able to take a class, I think I'll stick with pencil drawing for now but I might want to try painting or sculpting later this year.

It would make me really happy if you could help me take classes.  As a thank you, I'd love to send you some of my original art work.  Please check out the "perks" section to see what I'm offering.

From my mom:
We have enrolled Lilly in many art classes over the years but, unfortunately, can't afford any right now. Last year our small business burned down.  We lost almost everything and we're not recovering very quickly.  Lilly's dad had to take a crappy retail job and I've started working from home (in addition to homeschooling the kids) but our income is still 50-75% of what it used to be.   We just don't have any money in the budget for art classes but I agreed to help Lilly try and raise some and this is what we came up with.

The amount she's asking for should cover one basic class and supplies for about 6 months.

Thank you for contributing and/or sharing!

story:
My name is Joe Bencharsky, and I am trying to help my fiance Jennifer recover from breast cancer and start a new career.

Jennifer is a nuno-felting artist who has taught and studied with some major artists in the field. We met as she was starting a new life after a divorce that forced her to walk away from all she had and start anew. Within our first year together, we did some traveling and she talked to me about her desire to teach felting in areas that had a long tradition of access to natural fibers (Wools, silk etc.) but had underdeveloped economies and industry. These artistic skills coupled with teaching some business skills, would enable local people to develop viable products that reflected their local traditions and cultures and have a demand on a world market.

Nuno-felting (sometimes called wet felting) is actually an ancient technique of binding together natural fibers using water and pressure. It can be used to make shelters, clothing, and wonderful artwork. It has great versatility and potential in helping people create functional products as well as unique and desirable products for resale.

In March of 2012 Jennifer was diagnosed with an aggressive form of breast cancer and has been undergoing treatment. The good news is that she is cancer-free following chemo, surgery, and radiation therapies.  However, she still has a few months of chemo therapy to go, and has been suffering with a side-effect of chemo that has caused her full-body pain and left her functionally disabled for the past year. Doctors say she has a good possibility of recovering from this reaction, but it can take 18 months or more and she has been living on pain medication to try and control the pain that has left her unable to drive or have much stamina for daily functioning.

Since she has been unable to work, she has been very depressed on top of her pain, but she has started doing some small felting projects as she can, which lifts her spirits and gives her some join and possibility of starting to be productive.

However, the process of nuno-felting is physically demanding as she has to apply pressure and roll the fibers hundreds of times using the weight of her body. They do have machines that do this which are made to order, but they cost several thousand dollars. My intention was to purchase a machine for her as a birthday surprise this year so that she could start making pieces that she could sell in order to raise funds, and then expand her desire to teach to under developed areas once she recovers enough to travel.

I have communicated with the manufacturer of the machine and they have offered a generous discount, and I am contributing what I can to the effort, but I am falling a bit short on my resources and need a slight financial boost to make this project happen, so I am trying to raise money for her machine and for a website to showcase and sell her artwork. This will put her on a path of activity and self-sufficiency that will then lead to her being able to fulfill her desire to teach and help others to find their way to economic independence as well as also teaching other cancer survivors a way to express themselves through this amazing art and find a positive way to reconnect with their lives and the world at large. Jennifer believes in not being defined as a cancer survivor, but wants to help others with the insights she has had during the experience.

I thank you for your assistance in spreading the word, and I am confident that putting together many small donations will help in Jennifer's noble goals as well as helping her through this difficult time and finding her way to being a positive contributor to society.

story:
Making History

Midburn is history in the making! The first ever Burning Man event in Israel!

{Breaking news: we've hit the papers in Israel}

Much more than a regional Burning Man event, Midburn is also creating a hub for artists with workshops, a space to create, assistance with materials, and help with tools. But we need your help!



HELP US make it more than just a festival!

HELP US make and sustain ART.

We’ve raised 75,000$ from the Israeli community, we need 18,000$ to complete the vision! 

Your support can help us complete the goal!

About Midburn

Tickets have been sold, theme camp registrations are in, and performers abound. From June 3-7th 2014, 2500 people will be populating the desert, filling it with art, celebration, creation and unique experiences.  

About The Artwork

We have more than 30 artists working on projects at different stages, more than 250 volunteers working on the event. Projects are underway and they are going to be GYNORMOUS!

How Can You Help?

Your small contribution makes a big impact. Literally.

With a few dollars you support our artists, help us transform our festival into a full-on art extravaganza, and assist us in maintaining a local Burning Man Artists community.

We’ve raised $75,000 from the Israeli community, we need $18,000 more to bring it all to life! The money will be dedicated to:

  • Materials and tools for contributing artists.

  • Maintaining our current "generator" - a joint work space where burners can gather and work together, teaching each other and sharing ideas.

  • Development and maintenance of running workshops in various disciplines including wood, metal, Arduino for Burners and Burning Man Virgins.

What’s In It For You?

It’s all about the art and the experience. Our perks aren’t just about great prizes (like signed artwork and limited edition jewelry!) but they are also about making you a part of our event. Have your name and wish written on our first temple when you fund artist materials, receive  a 3D printed model of the temple, or receive a complete photo journal of this years art creations.

Our Temple:


Other Ways You Can Help

If contributing doesn't work for you, that's okay! There are other ways to help:

  • Sign up for email updates, and we'll give you a heads up when we open.

  • Share this campaign with your friends.

  • If you know artists who might want to join us, please let them know!

  • Write a blogpost about it!

story:
Who are we?


madein-ec.com is the initiative for the creation of an online store, which markets all kinds of crafts and products created in Ecuador. 

As one of the most renowned products worldwide, very few know of his fibula origin, our first product will PAJATOQUILLA HAT, or better known as Panama hat. 

The story goes that Pajatoquilla hat, made in some villages as jipijapa, Montecristi mainly located in coastal region of Ecuador, they are known worldwide as Panama hats. 


Its name comes from the fact that reached significance during the construction of the Panama Canal when thousands of hats were imported from Ecuador to the use of construction workers. When Theodore Roosevelt visited the canal used this hat, which increased its popularity. 

Glorified during the nineteenth century, the Panama has since been considered the prince of straw hats. The national hero and emblematic figure, Eloy Alfaro helped finance his liberal revolution of Ecuador through the export of "panama". The reputation of the hat was established by Napoleon III, Edward VII, and some other fans. 


We want to fund us, with one of the Ecuadorian products sold worldwide, which unfortunately is not recognized as made in Ecuador, but as Panama hats. 

What wonders pajatoquilla as hats, which are made in Ecuador we launched our online store to madein-ec so that all products and handicrafts, are made by Ecuadorian conosidas as hands. 

Quality is a hotly contested issue when dealing with hats pajatoquilla more conosidos as Panama hats. There are two main processes in its creation: weaving and blocking. The best way to gauge the quality of the structure is to count the number of fibers per square inch. Less than 300 would be considered poor quality. The rarest and most expensive are 1,600 to 2,000 fibers per square inch, and it is not surprising that these are sold at very high prices. Many quality levels between 300 and 1600 are given. Currently, although the Panama continues today providing a livelihood for thousands of Ecuadorians remain only a dozen weavers capable of making some straw hats called superfine of montecristi. 


Today, Panama hats are made not only in Ecuador, but in many other Latin American countries but Ecuador is still the leading exporter and the best quality.

Less than 300 would be considered poor quality. The rarest and most expensive are 1,600 to 2,000 fibers per square inch, and it is not surprising that these are sold at very high prices. Currently, although the Panama continues today providing a livelihood for thousands of Ecuadorians remain only a dozen weavers capable of making some straw hats called superfine of montecristi. Today, Panama hats are made not only in Ecuador, but in many other Latin American countries but Ecuador is still the leading exporter and the best quality.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Christine Longoria and I'm a ceramic artist. I started working in clay 7 years ago, not realizing the role it would play in my life. It's a unique way that I communicate and process what's going on in my head. However, since finishing school and moving to LA, I haven't had access to a studio. I work for a small non-profit called Povertees, which is an organization that helps homeless people escape the cycle of poverty in downtown LA. It's been a huge change from my life in San Francisco, but I love what I do and the community I get to be a part of through it. However, it doesn't quite pay the bills, so I want to try my hand at selling my art. My goal for this campaign is to raise $1,600, which will kick start my way back into sculpting. The barriers I'm facing are (1) that I can't afford a studio membership, and (2) that I can't physically get to the studio because I don't have a car and the closest studio is in neighboring city Eagle Rock. So my solution is to convert my unused laundry room into a small studio space, and to get a firing membership at the studio, which is cheaper and allows me to use their kilns a couple times a month. The $1,600 will cover the cost of materials and membership for 4 months, along with the funds to create a studio in my laundry room. With this initial investment, I believe I will be able to launch myself into a freelance art career. With your hand in mine, help me make this dream a reality. 


What I Need & What You Get

Here's a breakdown of the costs:

  • Firing membership: $125 a month = $500 for 4 months
  • Materials: I'll use about 1 bag of clay per week, and each bag of costs about $10, so thats $160 for clay for 4 months. Glazes, stains, and tools will cost me $200 to have an adequate supply.
  • Studio = I will need $250 to turn my laundry room into a workspace. With that I will make a work table, shelving, and storage. 
  • Shipping and Handling  = In order to ship all the artwork out that you buy, I'll need at least $350 (ceramic work is heavy and won't be cheap to ship). 
  • Indiegogo takes 4% of what I raise, and other transaction fees take another 4%, so for this subtraction I want to allow for an extra $140.
  • TOTAL = $1600

Rewards:

Look to the right for the full list of rewards! All original pieces made by me. 


The Impact

With your hand in mine, I will be able to start making art again. Realistically, there is no way I will be able to do it on my own. And having had so much interest in my art over the years, I want to go out on a limb and try to pursue it. Since I was a little girl, I've always wanted to be an artist, so it would be a dream come true to make a living off this truly unusual skill that I have. 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't at a place to contribute financially, I can still use your help! Please share this page and any of my pictures on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, etc. The more people who hear about this the more likely I am to meet my goal!

story:
I'm an artist living in Brooklyn.  I graduated in 2013 from SUNY Purchase School of Art and Design. My entire life I've known I was meant to be an artist. My first interest was in graphic novels, and through the years that interest has sharpened to include graphic novels  illustrated with fine linoleum cut prints.  My first lino cut book was about the environmental impacts of hydrofracking;  my second featured  two stories about  travelers and their experiences.  This second book was called “Cities of the Interior” and  was picked up by the  Booklyn Artist  Collective soon after it was completed.
Since  “Cities of the Interior” I've  decided to create  another linoleum cut book, in a limited edition of twenty hand-printed, hand-bound, numbered copies, 16 pages, pamphlet stitched. It will be called “Couchsurfing Tuscana” and will tell the story of an surreal hiking experience I had while backpacking summer 2013.
I crunched the numbers and determined that I could achieve that goal on a tight budget of  $600.00. This would cover the ink, special papers for the pages and covers, and the linoleum blocks themselves.
I was left feeling pretty worried. I don't have anything close to that kind of money. I moved to Brooklyn in October and have been living hand to mouth the whole time, working miscellaneous jobs as I find them and taking an occasional freelance illustration commission. I’m glad for the work but it doesn’t leave me the money to actually create new art for my own projects.
That’s why I’m on indiegogo.com asking for your help in making my next project a reality. Thanks for looking at my campaign, and thanks for considering a contribution. No contribution too small – or too large

What is needed

  • 150.00 Arches Cover paper (for the pages) 

  • 200.00 St Armand Dark Linen Paper (for the cover)

  • 200.00 Art-quality linoleum (16.00 per block x 12 blocks)

  • 20.00 Miscellaneous 


Other Ways You Can Help

You’re already helping, just by reading about this campaign. But, if you can’t afford a contribution, you can still help by sharing this with your friends and anybody else who might want to help bring some art into this world. Thanks again.

*****UPDATES*****

Wow, already over halfway to our goal! 

I am so filled with gratitude for every person who has invested in my artwork. 

To show my appreciation, I have decided that anyone who donates, no matter what the size of the donation, will receive a hand written thank you note with a sketch, regardless of whether I reach my goal or not.

story:
The Project

My name is Moriah Ella Mason.  I'm an American Jew and a performing artist in Pittsburgh, PA.  "Ten Plagues/Eser HaMakot" is a performance and installation piece I have created to confront my discomfort with the current reality of Israel, a state I have been taught to see as my spiritual homeland.  

The piece is inspired by a portion of the Passover seder in which we recount the Ten Plagues God rained upon Egypt to convince Pharaoh to free the slaves. Upon recounting each plague we take a drop of wine out of our goblet and place it upon our dinner plate.  It's a form of prayerful empathy - an understanding that our joy in freedom is diminished by the suffering of the Egyptians.

 For this installation, I am identifying Ten Plagues of Palestine - Death, Injury, House Demolition, Checkpoints, Refugees, etc.  For each plague I am researching a numerical estimate which will be written on the wall.  Below each plague and number will be paper plates stained with one drop of red wine for each number. For example, if the estimate of house demolitions is 28,000, then there will be 28,000 drops of wine on paper plates surrounding that plague.  The performance is the simple, but time consuming task of placing the overwhelming number of drops of wine on the paper plates. The installation is what remains as the task is finished. It's a long duration performance that will be done in parts.

For me it represents that my joy in Israel as a Jewish homeland is diminished by the suffering of the Palestinians.  I am trying to learn how I can experience pride in the Jewish people and even in the idea of Israel as a spiritual homeland without subscribing to the political realities of Zionism.   I hope to spark a different conversation about what homeland means, what Zionism is and can be, and how we all measure and compare suffering and incorporate these stories into our ethical backgrounds regardless of our religious or ethnic identity.  I also hope that by sharing my journey that it will embolden others to look more into the conflict in Israel/Palestine without succumbing to the fear that by questioning Israeli policy they are being anti-Semitic.  Judaism and Jewish identity is bigger and more complicated than any one political belief and I'm trying to make that complication visible.

The piece will open at Bunkerprojects in Garfield on Penn Ave. as part of the the First Friday Unblurred Gallery Crawl.  The evening will end with performances by local poets and musicians on social justice themes related to the injustices in Palestine.  The exhibit will close a week later with a panel and facilitated discussion with anti-Zionist Jews and Mid-east studies students and scholars.  I will also be making and providing short zines with some additional context for the piece - my personal reflections and compilations of my research.  


Putting together a large installation takes some serious dough!  Here's the costs I'm working with:

$150 for the many, many paper plates needed

$150 for the books and articles bought for research

$20 for a big box of wine

$150 for the gallery fee, so we can afford to keep on the lights

$200 for the zine printing

$50 so I can make flyers to help spread the word

Total = $720 

I'm asking for $750 to account for the 4% fee that Indiegogo takes.


In exchange for your dough I have many thanks to offer and some great perks as well - going with the dough theme, I am excited to get started on baking lots of delicious challah and hamantaschen!  My challah, in particular, is legendary.  Believe me, you don't want to miss it!

But most importantly you'll get the satisfaction of supporting an original art piece, opening up conversations around one of the most difficult and intractable issues of our times.  


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate money right now, there are still ways you can help.

Do you have access to a printer? Would you be willing to print flyers or zine copies?  Can you spread the word about this campaign and the piece?

story:
Summary

About 2nd Floor Rear

  • 2nd Floor Rear is a 24-hour festival of art in experimental contexts, apartment galleries, and ephemeral and migrant projects, celebrating Chicago’s vibrant community of alternative and DIY art spaces. 
  • 2nd Floor Rear aims to uphold Chicago’s long history of scrappy, yet self-aware modes of creative production, and to embrace improvisation and makeshift solutions as a means of navigating the complexity of lived experience. 
  • Each February, this yearly festival connects artists with new audiences, helps underfunded and under-appreciated alternative spaces get some exposure, and enlivens a dreary winter weekend at the peak of  Chicago’s bleakest season.

How 2nd Floor Rear Works

  • It works like this: for a full 24-hour period, Saturday to Sunday, some kind of art event, installation, or happening will be going on somewhere in Chicago’s northwest neighborhoods, about 15 minutes or less from any blue line station.
  • 2nd Floor Rear is 25% the Creative Director and a small contract staff of designers, documentarians, and administrators, 75% Chicago artists from various disciplines, who independently run their own events and projects. While 2FR staff, advisors, and the Creative Director select proposals, scour the city for spaces, curate the timeline, and do most of the boring stuff (like raise money), it’s the artists, curators, and event producers who do the real work.
  • When we say “events”, we mean this in the broadest possible sense. Past artworks, events, and happenings ranged from late-night studio square dancing to a guerrilla sculpture garden, a site-specific installation in an underpass, and a nomadic gallery in a handbag. This year, events could be sing-alongs, dance parties, feasts, storytelling...  We tend to take our cues from the proposals we receive, so just about anything goes. 

About 2nd Floor Rear 2015

  • This year we want to bring you art, performances, gatherings, happenings, installations, and events that warm you, that draw you in, that make you want to stay.  We want you to experience the intimate, the meditative. We want you all to feel present and connected even in your winter fugue states. We want a safe place for audience and artist to be vulnerable and wildish. We want things to resonate--to find you again days later while you're waiting in line at the Walgreens checkout counter. The premise of this year's festival is ultimately more of a feeling than an idea. It's Chicagoans’ annual substitution of “stay warm” for “see you later”. It’s also the hypnotic quiet at winter’s core that makes the season’s deep melancholy savorable. Read more about the concept driving this year's festival here.


What We Need & What You Get

The Budget

  • Creative labor = 79% (for design, documentation, and administrative assistance)
  • Programming assistance = 11% (Extra dough for rentals, incidentals, honoraria, and other costs associated with events.)
  • Volunteer and artist hospitality = 6% 
  • Materials = 5% 

The Perks

  • $1 = Subliminal Hug
  • $5 = Custom Tweet + Facebook Status Update
  • $15 = Handmade Thank-you Card
  • $35 = Warm-in-the-Winter Festival Readiness Kit
  • $50 = Real Art from a Real 2FR15 Artist
  • $100 = New BFFs (invitation to our party)
  • Biggest single donation = Become a Local Legend
See "Perks" for perk descriptions.

The Fallbacks

We believe that creative labor is valuable labor, and should be paid labor. While nobody’s going to get rich off this, offering our contract staff small stipends is, for us, a matter of integrity. The less money we have, the fewer people we can hire. If we don't reach our goal, we'll have to significantly reduce the number of proposals we can accept and make do with fewer documentarians. 

The Festival

Did we mention that your contributions help keep the festival free? For the fourth year in a row, there are no tickets to buy, no cover charge, and we want to keep it that way.


Impact

Why do we do this?

  • Chicago has a robust, little-known history of showing art in “apartment galleries” and small, seemingly random venues. We started 2nd Floor because we wanted there to be a designated moment to highlight these spaces and practices. Other people sign up year after year because they believe in the festival. For creative folks, it's an incentive to make work, try new things, and experience culture, free from institutional strictures and commercial mandates. 

Who is festival for?

  • It’s for you. It’s for us. It’s for all the creative folks in Chicago who want to make good work, who want to experiment, who want to share their practice with new audiences.

  • It's for our fellow hardcore Chicagoans who need a good reason to leave the house and offset the wintertime cabin fever.

  • It’s for capital-U "Us"--producers of art and culture who dare to make something happen far from cultural epicenters like NY and LA. It’s for people who are interested in the kinds of creative activity that happens outside of the spotlight; when people make work to please themselves, their friends, their colleagues, and each other, and not their managers, gallerists, or the market. It’s for people who believe in art worlds, not “the art world”; who believe that creativity and culture are just too real and wild and sneaky to be beholden to any one, narrowly-defined location, conception of what art is, or socioeconomic structure.


Risks & Challenges

So, what could go wrong?

  • Scenario A--We don't get enough money to cover the costs mentioned above.

  • Scenario B--Stuff happens: inclement weather, programmatic changes, participants or locations fall through, the apocalypse picks that weekend to wreak havoc on earth...

How would we address said things going wrong?

  • Scenario A--We tighten our belts and make do with less. This will likely mean reducing the number of events in order to minimize staff. Between our summer fundraiser with Threewalls and application fees, we will have almost enough to cover 1st priority expenses, but it'll be tight. AND we'll have nothing to spend on the events themselves, which will be tough on the artists and organizations producing events, and way less fun for the audience. 

  • Scenario B--We'll handle it. We'll make adjustments as needed. This is 2nd Floor Rear's fourth year running, and we've got this. Money is biggest obstacle.


Other Ways You Can Help

Donate your space

Got some space (a business? an empty lot? a room in your apartment?) that you wouldn't mind donating for a couple hours or more? Is it a 15-minute walk or less from a north-side Blue Line station? We'd love to fill it up with festival programming. Email us with details at itsaponyprojects@gmail.com.

Donate your time 

Want to volunteer? We'll need plenty of help before the festival running errands, distributing posters, making things, and more. Our event producers might also need help running events on the 7th and 8th. Just email us with some details about yourself and how you'd like to help at itsaponyprojects@gmail.com

Spread the word

Post about our Indiegogo on all your social medias. Tell your friends about it. Tell your friends, parents, colleagues, strangers, and then tell them that even small amounts go a really, really long way with us. And tell everyone about 2nd Floor Rear 2015! You can find us online at 2ndfloorrear.org, and on Facebook at www.facebook.com/2ndfloorrear. 


Special thanks to Greg Reigh for his video wizardry.

costs mentioned above.

Scenario B--Stuff happens: inclement weather, programmatic changes, participants or locations fall through, the apocalypse picks that weekend to wreak havoc on earth...

How would we address said things going wrong?




Scenario A--We tighten our belts and make do with
less. This will likely mean reducing the number of events in order to minimize
staff. Between our summer fundraiser with Threewalls and application fees, we
will have almost enough to cover 1st priority expenses, but it'll be tight. AND
we'll have nothing to spend on the events themselves, which will be tough on
the artists and organizations producing events, and way less fun for the
audience. 




Scenario B--We'll handle it. We'll make adjustments
as needed. This is 2nd Floor Rear's fourth year running, and we've got this.
Money is biggest obstacle.




Other Ways You Can Help

Donate your space
Got some space (a business? an empty lot? a room in your apartment?) that you wouldn't mind donating for a couple hours or more? Is it a 15-minute walk or less from a north-side Blue Line station? We'd love to fill it up with festival programming. Email us with details at itsaponyprojects@gmail.com.

Donate your time 
Want to volunteer? We'll need plenty of help before the festival running errands, distributing posters, making things, and more. Our event producers might also need help running events on the 7th and 8th. Just email us with some details about yourself and how you'd like to help at itsaponyprojects@gmail.com

Spread the word
Post about our Indiegogo on all your social medias. Tell your friends about it. Tell your friends, parents, colleagues, strangers, and then tell them that even small amounts go a really, really long way with us. And tell everyone about 2nd Floor Rear 2015! You can find us online at 2ndfloorrear.org, and on Facebook at www.facebook.com/2ndfloorrear.   Special thanks to Greg Reigh for his video wizardry.

story:
(Lee aquí esta campaña en español)

Short Summary

We are a pair of cousins from Bogotá, Colombia. Zas is a graffiti artist and graphic designer. Laura is an academic researcher with an editorial background. We both love books and we sure love to make them. We share a common interest for graffiti and street art, and we realized that there are a lot of graffiti painted in the streets of most cities around the world, but there are few books about why graffiti artists are doing what they do. We know that there is a lot of repression and that graffiti is considered a crime in almost every city. Nevertheless, graffiti is everywhere. 

We decided to make a book about artists' motivation to make graffiti. We found a common feeling generated by a discontent with the city environment and its everyday life policies that calls to creative action, and we decided to call that feeling 'romantic'. Our book is a bilingual (Spanish and English) compilation of texts, fragments, songs, essays and drawings on diverse subjects that express this common feeling from the point of view of graffiti artists. Our compilation does not include photographs of graffiti, for that we hope you go out to the streets to see graffiti for yourself.



The task of making a bilingual edition has been carried out with the aim of spreading our selection in cities around the world while trying to maintain consistency with the global nature of graffiti. Contents has been selected following the criteria mentioned before, with sincerity and passion being the most important elements. The selection includes texts and fragments by authors from Colombia, Mexico and the U.S., such as Stink Fish, Caz Dos, Zas, Saber, The Vapors Magazine, Promoe, amongst some others.  

The book is almost ready, we only need your help to print it. We are doing all the edition work for free and we don't want to make any profit from it, we are only interested in spreading the word so people get to know more about graffiti, about what is happening in the streets of their cities. We want to share it with as many people as possible. That is why our book is free.

The distribution is going to be made in the same way that most indie publishing projects are: hand-to-hand distribution, shipping to other countries with the help of some friends, local distribution at libraries, cultural centers and so on.


What We Need & What YOU Get

We only need enough money to produce 500 books (1,200 USD). This includes the cost of paper, screen printing the covers, offset printing of internal pages, bookbinding and ISBN registration.

The rest of the money is to produce your great rewards and the shipping charges.


If we don´t reach our goal we still plan to produce our book. But if we exceed the amount of our goal we will be able to make you an even better book, as we could afford  higher quality paper, better bookbinding and print more copies.

IMPORTANT: Even if our book is free of charge, we only can afford sending the printed version to backers of 60 USD or higher. But don't worry everyone will have our digital version. Check out the rewards to know more about it.


The Impact

We hope that people begin to think more about graffiti,  and maybe they get to understand beyond just glancing at it in the streets. For now graffiti is staying in our cities, and it is receiving more attention than ever from galleries, fashion designers, advertising agencies and city governments, but graffiti is also considered a crime often leaving artists treated as criminals. How we can reconcile this? Graffiti challenges many established policies but, at the same time, creates amazing productions full of ideas and color that change the grey and static environment of our cities. What does that mean? 

We hope that people reading our book see that graffiti is more than "drawings" on a wall.  Graffiti has significance in each of our lives because of its presence in the cities we inhabit and because it give us ways to intervene directly in the design of our cityscapes.


Risks & Challenges

We have already told you the book is almost ready and we're making it happen even if we don't reach our goal, right? So, the only risk is all the printing houses in Bogotá ran out of ink, and in that case we still can send you the digital version of the book.

Just in case we don't reach our goal, the rewards can take some time to get to your place because we will have to organize our shipping in a different way. But don't worry, we promise your reward will get to you before June 2015. 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Help us make noise about the campaign. Share it with everybody as graffiti artists do with their work. (See the share tools.)
  • Send us along thoughts/feedback.

story:
my name is highcastle.
three years ago, i sold everything i owned except my bicycle and camera equipment and rode 2300 miles from austin to new york to start a new life as an art photographer. i specialize in erotic art nudes shot on traditional film stock and instant film stock. my work is inspired by filmmakers who explore frank sexual themes in creative ways. my theory is that human sexuality is a viable topic for artistic expression and exploration.

my goal for this project is to take everything ive learned over the past few years and turn it into the vanity side project (VSP), a magazine dedicated to nude and erotic art nudes and the culture that has arisen from art photographers and the models that collaborate with them. issue zero of the vanity side project will showcase the art model luba and photographs of her shot in the spring of 2014

my goal is to raise $2,500; this money goes towards the publication of 100 copies of VSP, processing costs for film shot during my recent excursion in california, including images of luba, shipping costs for all perks, and provide me a balance for future issues of VSP. by donating, you can earn prints, copies of the magazine, and other perks.  and while my goal is to raise $2500, anything over that will allow me to make more copies for sale in local shops and allow me to create additional work!

the goal of my work is to present real human beings engaged in owning their own sexuality, to create art out of the interaction between photographers and their subject, and to explore the boundaries between art and reality, between storytelling and truth. my hope is that my work creates a conversation about why we choose to view something that is so natural and a huge part of the human condition as something to keep private or that is dirty.

with your help i create works of art that transcend what we consider dirty, naughty or even pornographic and create a safe place for myself and likeminded artists to build a dialogue about sex and human nature.

i urge everyone who appreciates my work to give what they can. and if you cant, then at least spread the word. tweet this. facebook it. blog about it on your tumblr or other blogging platform. get the word out and help me create more work for you and others to enjoy!

story:
What is Big Bang Bazaar?

Big Bang Bazaar is an Indie Art, Crafts and Vintage Bazaar.

Most of you know us as a super awesome and fun event....but this July we are expanding to a store front! 

Indie Craft Exchange is located in Downtown Sanford! 

What will the store offer?

  • Upcycle Craft Supplies - We buy and sell unused supplies and new or used craft tools. These are items that others just didn't have a use for...think GameStop...but for CRAFT SUPPLIES!  No need to pay crazy craft store prices!!! Fabric, beads, stickers, yarn, art supplies, and MUCH MUCH MORE!
  • Local Art - we have art work and crafts from local artists and BBB vendors available for purchase in store!!! 
  • Workshops and Classes - Want to learn a new craft??? You can learn here!!! 
  • After School and Summer Programs - We will be offering fun kid's classes for your little ones! 

    Why we need your help! 

    So...here's the deal! We need your help! It's just not easy (or cheap) to open a store. We need you! Your contribution helps us make this dream a reality! 

    • Stores are expensive! We need help with rent, utilities, staff and inventory for the first few months. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Can't help monetarily? That's ok! We still appreciate the support! Here's what you can do...

    • Donate your unused supplies! (we need inventory!)
    • Help us with your blood, sweat and tears! (you can paint, price, clean, organize, etc!) We appreciate any help you want to give! 
    • Spread the word of this campaign through Social Media!

story:
Startwork, in few words...

Startwork.me makes Celebrity, Art and Charity work together. Basically, we truly believe that any value (such as notorietey) can generate an extra-value by itself (ie. donations), but only if this is for a good cause. Let us explain the concept:

  1. A celebrity performs an artwork (a painting) on a given topic
  2. We film the performance and interview the celebrity
  3. The celebrity activates his/her fanbase by promoting the artwork on Twitter, Facebook...
  4. Fans order tickets to win the artwork + the autographed DVD of the performance ("Don't believe me when I tell you Madonna painted this for me? OK, here's the proof!")
  5. 1 ticket = 1 chance to win the artwork (price will be ranged from 5 to 10€, depending on the celebrity's notoriety)
  6. 1 ticket = 1 donation to a charity organization (choosen by the celebrity or among Startwork's partners)

We'll start the project first with celebs based in France, because we're located in Paris and have already initiated contacts with french stars (especially in media, sport and music areas). Obviously, our team can easily move out, especially if we find opportunities in collaborating with non-french famous people.


How we'll use your money

  • 15% will go for the painting material: Canvas, oil paints, brushes, easel...
  • 60% will be used for the performance shooting and the video edition: That's the major part of funds we're looking for, especially because we have to pay a dedicated video staff (2 cams, 1 microphone, lightning, makeup, cattering for the artist...)
  • 25% will be spent in Advertising & PR to promote the project and to reach major medias


Other ways for helping us...

Money isn't everything. We listed below some additional ways to help us making Startwork a success:

  • Share our project page to your IndieGogo network.
  • Follow us on social sites: (@Startworkme +Startwork fb.com/Startwork.me)
  • Any other idea you'll suggest!

Thanks for your help.

story:
Our Story

The Passion for Freedom Festival – www.passionforfreedom.co.uk – celebrates and encourages freedom of speech and artistic expression at the time when different voices undermine value of one secular law for all citizens in a democratic society.

The Festival is evolving from an art competition which previous edition took place in November 2010 and has drawn over 400 viewers to UNIT24 Gallery in London Southbank by Tate Modern. The exhibition has presented works by award winning international artists: Anna Sundt, Svitlana Grebenyuk, Roberta Coni and Maja Wolna. The visitors were moved by the Cannes nominated ‘Little Bride’ documentary by Leszek Dobrucki. The event has drawn attention of numerous international groups which promote freedom of speech and secular law. There have been numerous articles and interviews that followed the successful exhibition.

At 2011 Festival we are presenting works selected from an Open Call to international art community and works and publications selected for its significance in protecting the freedom and democracy in our society.

 

The Impact

Civitas estimates that there are at least 85 Sharia courts in Britain that implement and enforce the Sharia law, mainly covering issues such as divorce. Considering the severe disadvantage women are in the first place, (and the many that are unaware of their rights under British law) that proceedings are not recorded and that there is no legal accountability, it’s clear that activism and action is needed. Fuelled by this need for action and legal equality, the artwork for the Passion for Freedom Festival aims to promote awareness about importance of secular law in a democratic society. It strives to give artists the voice to express views on topics that some find to difficult to discuss. Be it out of political correctness or fear of repression.

 

‘I really loved the phrase of exhibition’s curator: “There are regimes that are afraid of art, but artists are not afraid of regimes’...that’s the way I want to use my art.’ Roberta Coni, one of the PfF winners, 2010

 

‘Meaningful art. I have found it here at the festival. A high quality event!’ Leszek Dobrucki, ‘Little Bride’ director

‘The show is amazing. I am impressed with the artists’ maturity and approach to the subject matter. I wasn’t aware of Sharia courts in Britain until now. It is really disturbing.’

 John student at St. Martin's College of Art, London

What We Need & What You Get

The non-profit festival is run by a very small group of passionate people committed to protecting our freedom and equality in modern, democratic society. They spend their own money and time to make it happen. Although we are supported by One Law for All organization and few generous private donors we are striving to develop the Festival and deliver the message to the wider international community.

If everyone who ever came to the Passion for Freedom have given $15 we’d reach this modest goal.

 

What We Need:

$2700 - This will allow us to pay for the design and print of our catalogue. It is beautifully designed, full-colour-keepsake that includes pictures and bios of all participating artists. It is also an important document for us to use throughout the year in grant proposals, for marketing purposes, and as a historical document.

$1400 – This will allow us to pay UNIT24 Gallery to give us the whole space (ground floor and the upstairs space) to exhibit, promote and discuss works presented during Passion for Freedom Festival.

$1000- This will pay for the cost of food, drinks and service for our Private View, which is followed by the Passion for Freedom awards and the film screening/performance during PV.

$500 – Van hire to transport works

$400 – This will pay for the invitations to the Private View

TOTAL: $6000

What you get

See the PERKS column to the right!

 

·         Badges (3) - $20

·         Postcards (6) - $80

·         Poster (A2) - $150

·         One Law for All Conference Participation - $350

·         VIP dinner with Maryam Namazie - $850

·         Honorary Sponsor (mentioned/logo in the Festival catalogue)- $1500

 

Other ways to help

There are many more ways in which you can help with the Festival. Here are just a few more:

1) Forward this page and spread the word to everyone in your address book!

2) Click here and ‘like’ our page on Facebook

3) Follow us on Twitter - @P4Freedom

4) Sign up to volunteer during the festival – to work at the info tables, to help move furniture, to pick up food for the volunteer staff. Email info@passionforfreedom.co.uk  with 'Volunteer' in the subject line.

5) We gladly accept in-kind donations of food, drinks or other services

story:
Little Myrtle is our first children's book!

I've always wanted to illustrate a children's book...He always wanted to become a published children's book author.  Little Myrtle is a dream come true for both of us.
 
We love Myrtle! She is love and she's full of the beauty of life!  And, to our team, she's like family.  The book was certainly a family effort.  Paul Trefz is the author of the children's poem which I interpreted into collage based on the drawings of Paul's young daughter.  The children featured in the song are our children and god children.  Over the past year, we have worked on the illustrations, design and layout of the book. 

An amazingly positive response from the public!

We had a short run of the book printed this Spring and quickly sold them all!  In the process, we were able to get the feedback of more than 500 individuals in Philadelphia...And they loved Myrtle as much as we do!  We found that the book made people smile and even chuckle out loud; children were anxious to get their hands on it. 
 
Adults wanted to talk about the moral of the story or they were inspired to tell us about their own dreams of creating  a children's book.  Most surprising was that people we met while vending were so grateful for our presence. We realized that beyond creating literature we were creating public spaces for sharing stories around the value of dreams, family and self determination.  Myrtle had become a public performance!
 
We collected signatures from people who read or bought the book.  We wondered: how could we make Little Myrtle More than a local phenomenon?  And just how many signatures could we collect in six months?  A million? That's a stretch...but it's fun to dream big isn't it? That's what the Myrtle's Millions tour is about.

Please support our book project!

Your contributions will get us started in really distributing the book to the public.  We will be able to pay for a larger printing of at least 2,000 books (but of course we'll print as many as you order!). Contributions will also pay for promotional materials and transportation.  We will be able to travel with our family to create spaces where children and children's literature are loved.

By contributing to our campaign you get to become a part of Myrtle's story and a part our family's experiment in social entrepreneurship. 

Support for Little Myrtle is support for children's literature, independent publishing and distribution...it is support for one family's dream.

 

Other Ways You Can Help:

Even if you don't have children in your immediate family, books are a great gift for young friends, cousins, neices, nephews, grandchildren or other loved ones.  Children's books are great gifts for teachers, child care providers, therapists, and others who work with children.  And you know what? Some adults just love children's books.  We do! 

Not everyone can afford to contribute financially...We'd still love you to be a part of the campaign! 

Please help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign using the Indiegogo share tools!  If you know someone who love books, children and art, please let them know what we're doing.  

Contact us if you have a business or non profit that would like to sponsor our project or if you have any other ideas about getting involved with our adventures send us an email and of course send us well wishes!!!!

 

Thank you so much for all of your love and support,

Misty Sol

 

 

Links to other Art and Youth projects by Misty Sol and Paul Trefz

http://www.leeway.org/grantee-info.html?action=granteeDetail&GranteeID=831

http://www.leeway.org/grantee-info.html?action=granteeDetail&GranteeID=172

http://www.leeway.org/grantee-info.html?action=granteeDetail&GranteeID=214

Misty Sol and Paul Trefz are recognized for work with homeless youth

http://osaphilly.com/index.php?page=steppys

Misty Sol and Paul Trefz perform a the 2011 Philadelphia International Festival of the Arts:

http://www.kimmelcenter.org/news/index.php?id=253

Misty Sol and Paul Trefz perform music inspired by love of children:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y-B8M6IYBoE

Misty Sol and Davina Stewart perform at the Philadelphia Clef Club accompanied by Paul Trefz on guitar

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xsZxCo5QvCI

 

More visual art and collage by Misty Sol

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y1iCrwLngmc&...

Little Myrtle is our first children's book!
I've always wanted to illustrate a children's book...He always wanted to become a published children's book author.  Little Myrtle is a dream come true for both of us.
 
We love Myrtle! She is love and she's full of the beauty of life!  And, to our team, she's like family.  The book was certainly a family effort.  Paul Trefz is the author of the children's poem which I interpreted into collage based on the drawings of Paul's young daughter.  The children featured in the song are our children and god children.  Over the past year, we have worked on the illustrations, design and layout of the book. 
An amazingly positive response from the public!
We had a short run of the book printed this Spring and quickly sold them all!  In the process, we were able to get the feedback of more than 500 individuals in Philadelphia...And they loved Myrtle as much as we do!  We found that the book made people smile and even chuckle out loud; children were anxious to get their hands on it. 
 
Adults wanted to talk about the moral of the story or they were inspired to tell us about their own dreams of creating  a children's book.  Most surprising was that people we met while vending were so grateful for our presence. story:
Short Summary

Help us get the Acavallo Carousel to Burning Man this year!  We want to bring you and everyone else the chance to experience the Acavallo in all of its good time glory - she's in need of some new tires and some fuel, and she's ready to go!  Here's a highlight reel of past exploits!


The Acavallo Carousel is a dream-sketch of metal, wood, and rope ship, with life size horses that go up and down.  It's self propelled, with big agricultural tires and airbag suspension for lots of bounce and sway.  Its got a stage on the back, which doubles as a lounge, a catwalk above the deck for the brave, masts and ropes to climb for the braver yet.  The whole ship is interactive, is complete in it's piratical detail.  The hard edges of the horses, the soft curves of the ropes, the worn wood planking and the rusted patina speak to its hard-partying experience.  This ship rocks.  It's meant to.  It inspires, it amuses, it transforms.   It's so much fun!

You can read about the build of this project at www.acavallo.org - it's been years in the making.  We've brought her out the last couple years, and she's been wonderful - such a delightfully interactive ship, and such a wonderfully inclusive place to find yourself on the playa.  We're ready to go, we just need some help with the basic bills!

The crew: 

Quill Hyde is the artist and the engineer, but there are many many others who have helped and will help to bring this dream-ship to the world.  The ship is resting at the Hyde Brothers shop in Tonasket WA, and was rebuilt there in 2012, having been originally built in Brooklyn NY. The crew is national, with people from NY, CA, and WA, plus all points between.

What We Need  

Here's how the costs break down!

New trailer tires $1500
Fuel for truck & car on playa $850
Propane $850
Generator and power distribution : $300
Posters, shipping, perk funding : $250

This is just to get it down to BRC and back.  Of course there's always more that could be spent!  The dream would be a new generator, silent and strong, that would sip diesel quietly all week and never crap out - oh but that's much more ($7,500).  And a new mixer (a grand), some new speakers (another grand), a high-pressure air compressor for the back airbags, that's the dream list.  All in good time! It works great the way it is!  It's just a little loud, a little ramshackle, but still fun.  But! If we raise more, we spend more!

What You Get

First, of course, at any contribution, is ownership of the Acavallo experience - you made it happen, you own it. 

Pendants!  These are all unique.  It's true that the Hydemade plasmacutter cuts them out in bulk, but each one is hand-forged to give it detail and form the curl.  Each one gets heated to a glowing orange-yellow and smacked around on an anvil, ain't that life!

Posters!  Both images by Stephan Grimm - Acavallo in a duststorm, and Acavallo at sunset.

Playa Tour!  Book us for a three hour cruise, replete with refreshments and entertainments for you and your camp!

Horse sculptures!  You can have your very own Acavallo pony! 

    The Impact

    The carousel is a unique piece of burning man art, and much loved everywhere she goes.  We bring a special blend of joy, irreverence, and carefree honesty to the playa.   Our mission to set people free to have a good time, to stop thinking and just enjoy the experience of the moment, to express themselves as only they can.  The ship is a special place - graceful & serene on a sunrise tour, sexy, sweaty, and burning at night.   And open to all, any time of the day.  We stop for anyone, for everyone, we demand you get on! 

    We've committed to doing art tours Tues, Wed, Thur, and Friday, during the week, making it possible for people with impaired mobility to get a chance to see the art installations up close.  And anyone else who just wants a ride around in the hot sun!  We come to interact, to enable, to spread magic.  We're always up for impromptu celebrations and performances!

    The Ship

    The ship is completely custom, and designed and built specifically for the playa sea.  It's detail is 3 dimensional - there is no pretend, it's real.  The rigging, the mechanics, every bolt serves a purpose.  There are elements of whimsy, and fancy, but all in careful balance with raw functionality, ropes and cables balancing steel masts and crosstrees.  It's beautiful, and so satisfyingly strong as it bounces and weaves across the desert.

    The horses are wonderful - stark, ethereal, but up for anything - you can load 'em up with as many people as will fit.  You can stand on them, dance on them, they're sturdy!  

    And if you ever get bored with going up and down you can climb up on the catwalk and relax, take in the sights while the ship sways beneath.  Or climb out on one of the horse-poles and go up and down 17' off the ground.  And if you're braver yet, shimmy up the main masts and get a real look around.  

    Climb down the ladder or slide down the ropes to the deck - you can experience the ship on your terms.  If you're comfortable, we're comfortable, get your groove on.  But if you can't make it up the rickety, scary, twisty log-chain ladder, you better just find a pillow on the stage and chill out!  It's all good.  You can DJ!

      Risks & Challenges

      Every year the Carousel tests me to my upmost.  Tests me in my ability to plan, prepare, to troubleshoot on roadsides and in duststorms.  And of course, tests me and the crew financially.  I hope that you can help us with that test, as it's seriously stressful.  The rest of it, we got.  

      The roadside u-bolt is broken 2x4 wedge emergency fix?  The all night in line emergency trip to Reno for parts?  The days in the hot sun unpacking, unfolding, rigging, and putting it together?  The sideways duststorm generator troubleshoot?  We got it.  We've done it several times and can't wait to do it again.

      The fabulous early morning deep playa cruise?  We got that too.   

        Other Ways You Can Help

        If you're unable to give money, give us a good word to your people, and come ride the carousel anyway.  You can always moop the deck!  Or DJ a set!

story:
Who is Robaato?

Well, it's just my online alias. My real name is Robert Porter and I'm a freelance illustrator, character designer, comic artist, pin-up artist, colorist, game developer… the list practically goes on. I have been essentially drawing all my life and it is one of my biggest passions. I've done work for UDON Entertainment, Capcom, Marvel, Namco-Bandai, Dark Horse, and many other companies.

I decided to create a campaign after a lot of my fans across the globe have been wondering why I have yet to release a book full of my work. I've done small run books when I was starting off and I have a collaborative book I've done with my close artistic buds Chamba and Fooray, but nothing supremely personal. I noticed I do tend to draw a lot (maybe a bit too much), so I started contemplating actually pursuing creating a book of this sort.

I'm known for having a hybrid manga+westernized style, design sense, colors (and drawing gals). But I kinda wanted to make my first 'actually thick' book to be focused on my sketchy stuff. I have tons of imagery in my archive that I have yet to post online, from studies to characters to concepts to even rough and line-art versions of some of the finished illustrations you dig of my work the most. And I figured, "Hey, I can actually do this!" 


What Will This Book Be Packed With?

Skabrous Skratchwork Volume 1 will contain, well to put it simply,  a LOT of art! 

  • Softcover, 8.25x10.5 in., Black & White Interior, 200 pages!
  • Tons of sketches that you haven't even seen before!
  • A barrage of roughs and lines of finished illustrations!
  • A section of drawing tips that I use as a part of my workflow!
  • Artist's Commentary accompanying some of the sketches
  • Etcetera (meaning everything you've come to love about my work)!
At the base, I need $8,000 to produce 500 books in total. This includes fees incurred by Indiegogo, taxes, and third party fees. If for some reason I hit the limit of the run during this campaign and it's still in high demand, I will extend the threshold. Of course with Indiegogo's Flexible Funding, if I don't meet my base goal, books will still be printed and you will still receive a copy! But I'm really hoping we can crush it! (I would love to have a large first printing!)

The book is $30 flat! With 200 pages of art, I figured that would be a decent, accessible price. I am packing my best work thus far into this book.

Unique Perks!

I'm not having a lot of unique perks for this project, but I do have a couple!
  1. RAPIDLY PERSONABLE Perk: A small number of people can get a quick sketch in the back of the book, signed by moi also!
  2. PART OF HISTORY Perk: A select few can be able to have a full-page illustration of a character of their choice printed in the back of the book, personally appropriated to & signed by me as well!

This is yet another avenue that I can't rely totally on by myself. I need help to get this done from you, my fans! If it weren't for you guys, I wouldn't be where I'm at right now. Over the years, I've learned & discovered that I need my fans to fuel me, not just from a financial standpoint, but most importantly: creatively and supportively. The kind words that people continue to shower me with have been pivotal to my creative growth, and this is one way I can think of giving back to you. 

I initially Kickstarted (and I'm still working on slavishly) Cryamore, an action-RPG, which was my first crowdfunding project with a few others last year. I'm also in charge of a currently on-going Patreon project featuring Rat Rage, my baby webcomic. Quite frankly, I'm a busy guy. But I'm now very familiar with managing projects similar to this one.

This book is planned to be wrapped up by August and shipped out September/early October. I will also have copies available at NYCC in October this year, so if you're going, I suggest just grabbing one from me there! There will not be a ton of re-printings. This means probably one or two very small re-printings for future sales, not "always available forever".

Risks & Challenges

There aren't many challenges when it comes to printing. I'm very familiar with the process and I can assure you that I know what is needed to make it go smoothly. Granted, there is still room for error so I will keep everyone abreast of that if it happens!

As for the content, the art is all done. (Which is the easiest part for me!) I just need to lay the book itself out, which isn't difficult for me either, but will take a couple of weeks to do; which I plan to do during the campaign's run, so the book will be ready to go off to the printer by the end of it. 

I will also have a third party company fulfill, process, and ship the book to you. This takes the slack off my back as I have a lot on my plate already to focus on.

If You Can't Help~

Please share this around! I will extremely appreciate it if you shared this on Twitter, Tumblr, Facebook, and anywhere else to get the word out! You can use the handy tools right here on Indiegogo to help do that. 

That's about it! Thanks so much for reading, considering, and helping out! It's truly appreciated and I will continue to put my best foot (or drawing hand… well, my only drawing hand) out there!

Layout Previews

story:
PLEASE HELP ME TO REALIZE MY DREAM TO MAKE IPAD INTERACTIVE EDUCATIONAL BOOKS FOR KIDS


PRODUCT

Books for kids 3 - 7 yrs will feature World Fairy Tales series teaching kids about different countries, their cultures & customs. Books for kids 7 - 12 yrs will feature Shirlie Holmes fun, educational stories who learns exciting facts about the world through solving different engaging tasks.


COMPETITIVE EDGE

Each book features multiple tasks to move to next level & finishes differently depending on how you solve tasks. The goal in future is to make a Reading Social Network for kids around the globe where competitions on books are held, kids gain points for their loyalty, reading more books & can share/exchange books to their friends worldwide.


TRACKRECORD

The first book will hit Apple store in January 2014, & it is in 8 languages. I am investing about $20,000 of personal funds into the Project. 

BUDGET

1.  Concept design UK book “The House that Jack Built”, & the Yakut National fairy tale, & Tales of Africa fairy with teachers, early education specialists - US$ 750, 4 weeks

2.  Illustration of 3 books (at least 12 – 15 pages each) – US$ 7,500 – 9,000

3.  Animation of the movements, characters US$ 50 – 75 per 3D animation, US$ 25 – 30 per 2D animation – US$ 4,000 – 5,000

4.  Marketing via Facebook fan page, social networks, bloggers, give aways to fans, promoters etc. – US$ 1,500 – 2,000

5.  Publishing in AppStore through DemiBooks – US$ 250 per each book, US$ 750 total

Total US$ 14,500 – US$ 17,500.  So far I have invested US$ 4,500 into development of the first book, will invest about US$ 15,000 additionally into development of the reading social application for the books to be shared etc.

PRODUCT
Books for kids 3 - 7 yrs will
feature World Fairy Tales series teaching kids about different countries, their
cultures & customs. Books for kids 7 - 12 yrs will feature Shirlie Holmes
fun, educational stories who learns exciting facts about the world through
solving different engaging tasks.COMPETITIVE EDGEEach book features multiple tasks to
move to next level & finishes differently depending on how you solve tasks.
The goal in future is to make a Reading Social Network for kids around the
globe where competitions on books are held, kids gain points for their loyalty,
reading more books & can share/exchange books to their friends worldwide.

story:
Jack and Eric want to be part of the Pier 9 AiR Show

Jack and Eric both came from New York to San Francisco to be part of the incredible Autodesk Pier 9 Artist Residency. They had a kickass time making work and making friends and are excited to be part of the group AiR (Artist in Residence) show on January 22. Unfortunately they will be back in New York and have spent their travel budget already! Help them fly back to join the crew and be part of the experience in person.

  • We want to set up and break down our work for the show
  • We want to see everyone else's amazing work 
  • We want to celebrate with the Pier 9 family
  • We are both artists who don't make a lot of money


About the Artists and the Art

Jack Kalish uses software and new technology to create immersive interactive installations. He will be showing this kinetic sculpture that creates poetry using light and moving mirrors:


Eric Forman makes kinetic and responsive sculptures. He will be showing a series of illuminated wood lightboxes with "halftone" images formed by custom software into thousands of laser cut holes.



We only need enough to get on an airplane

The total goal is to buy two round-trip airplane tickets to San Francisco in time for the show. If only one of us can go, neither of us will go. Solidarity, kids. When we arrive, we will sing you a song at karaoke and/or eat a taco with you. 
Stretch goal: If we raise more than needed for airfare, we will also be able to eat! And possibly even not have to hunt for couches and floors to crash on.


Risks & Challenges

We could come back to SF and sleep through the entire show.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have money to spare for our ridiculous and admittedly selfish campaign, please ask other people to give us their money.


The Perks

$5 - High Five: Jack and Eric will each personally give you a lively high-five.

$10 - Cappuccino Club Card. Jack will personally make you a cappuccino at Pier 9, with a latte art image of your choice.

$20 - Name in Lights. Your name or text of your choice will be displayed using Jack's art installation. We will make a video of it and share it online.


$75 - A unique wood lasercut image made with Eric's custom software. The image is formed from thousands of holes and can be hung in a window where natural light reveals the image. The wood is finished and stained by hand and signed by the artist. 12" x 12" x 3/16". Limited edition of 10.


$150 - Brushed Aluminum and Stainless Steel Jigsaw Puzzle, one of two ever made by Jack Kalish. Measures 8" x 8". Finished by hand.


$400 - One of three wooden Light Panel images lit from the inside, made by Eric Forman during his residency. Finished by hand, signed by the artist. 16" x 12" x 2". Donor will be able to choose from several different images, here is one example:

story:
My friends! Ok, so I've asked for these opportunities, I've beg. Whomever; god, the universe, the fates... And over the course of a couple weeks some good stuff has happened. I make art, it's what I do, what I've always done. I've tried to do other things half-heatedly, and it's been ok, but when I'm making art I'm truly happy. It would be amazing beyond words to be able to represent myself in Miami when I have this once-in-a-lifetime chance to stand in solidarity with my art; which is essentially what I live for. What if everyone just threw $5 my way? As though you were all my patrons? I know it seems funny but now a days any things possible. My promise to you is that I will send you a personalized art gift by mail given you pledge 20 dollars or more. I'd love to. This is basically you buying art at a greatly reduced price! Lucky you! Send your snail mail to the_wooh@hotmail.com. It'll be there by Christmas ;)



Bio 

 Christine Lynes engages with her world through her profound visual sensibilities. The narrative of her life unfolds in pictures; people, places, things. Christine is an eclectic artist whose talents span multiple disciplines ranging from digital photography to traditional photography to painting, sculpture, and collage. Christine has been active in the art communities of Canada and Australia for much of her life. Having attended arts schools since she was 13, she has been immersed in the arts for as long as she can remember. Christine is an art specialist educator and artist continuing to show in and around Toronto, and expanding her presence through opportunities like Scope.

story:
Who We Are

With Food in Mind operates at the intersection of food, visual culture, and social change. Because food is relevant to every living person, we believe that it is uniquely capable of engaging many different audiences in learning about the arts. We develop drop-in workshops, afterschool programs, and other educational programs that dynamically combine the two disciplines, fostering art appreciation through food. As a nomadic organization, we partner with a wide range of other organizations and creative professionals to bring our programs to low-income communities and people of color in New York City and beyond.

What We're Doing

In addition to creativity and a healthful diet, regular movement and exercise are important to our well-being. By running the Mother's Day 10k race in Prospect Park, our team is setting an example for the children in our lives while also raising money for With Food in Mind's 2014 spring and summer youth programs, including our art- and soda-making pop-up, "The Fruity Pop Workshop," and "Wee Cezanne," our new afterschool program for children in grades pre-K through 5. Additionally, our individual race registration fees will support Prospect Park, a natural wonderland located just across the street from With Food in Mind headquarters.

What We Need

Our goal is to raise $3,000. Each runner on With Food in Mind's team is charged with raising a minimum of $300, which equals just $30 from ten sponsors. Your generous and fully tax-deductible donations will help With Food in Mind pay its teaching artists and purchase program materials.

More About Us

With Food in Mind was founded in response to high rates of childhood obesity and low rates of arts educations in low-income communities and communities of color. Nearly 40% of the children in African American and Hispanic communities are overweight or obese (compared to about 30% nationwide), placing them at greater risk for heart disease, cancer, diabetes, and other diet-related illnesses. And national data repeatedly suggests that the child groups most afflicted by obesity are the ones who also suffer disproportionally from cuts to K–12 public school arts education, which has been linked to social and emotional development, academic achievement, civic engagement, and equitable opportunity. Positive food choices begin with knowledge, which can be filtered through visual art—addressing two important issues at once.

(Artwork at top: Martin Creed. "Work No. 850," 2008. Runners at Tate Britain; dimensions variable.)

story:
IT's XXXX  birthday

LET'S BUY HER A BENCH !

XXX has been a major supporter of GROUNDS FOR SCULPTURE in Hamilton Township NJ,

This is an organization she believes in, and has spent countless hours supporting.

I thought that for her Birthday, and in recognition of what a special person Florence is we could all chip in and buy her a bench at Grounds For Sculpture which would have a lovely plaque with her name on it.

If you like this idea... it would be great if you could contribute before MAY 17th - if we hit our goal of $2,200  we'll present her with a card with your name on it.

Contributions of any amount are appreciated.. but if you give $1 to $2  for every year you have known Florence... I think we'll make our goal.

AND FEEL FREE TO PASS THIS ON.....  to anyone who loves XXXX!

 

IF you'd like to learn more about GROUNDS FOR SCULPTURE check out 

www.groundsforsculpture.com

story:
My name is Sandra Creason, and I live in a small southern town in Oklahoma with my wonderful fiance and my two beautiful daughters, ages 9 and 11.

Last Christmas, we discovered a few things that caused some major complications in our lives and changed my girls' outlook on the world forever.  I won't go into details, but suffice to say that my oldest daughter specifically developed a fear of going to daycare, and I promised her that they would never have to go again; I would be there when they went to school, and in the afternoons when they got home - no one else, ever.  However, that was when I was working and in a management position that allowed me to negotiate my hours around my girls' school schedule. 

Four months later, my company downsized and decided to close my store, two days before my oldest daughter's 11th birthday. Two weeks after that, my fiance was let go from his job as well. 

My objective is not only to be able to support my girls without having to break my promise of being able to stay with them outside of school, but also to help them learn to work through their emotional strife by expressing themselves through art.  Both have a blossoming talent, but in the town we live in, there are no art classes or projects that can help them build their skills and love for art unless I can provide them.  Not everyone agrees that art is that important - I think, however, that it is essential.  My aim is not to become rich, but to be able to spend my time doing something I love and to share that passion with others.

In the long term, I would love to be able to teach art to other children and people who have an interest but no resources.  My specialty is portrait art, but where I live, there is plenty of interest but not many people who have the extra money to commission it, even though my prices are far below what I've found anywhere else. 

So here is where the money is planned to go:

$500 buys me time.  Time to gather resources and build a network, to set up a shop and negotiate discounts or free art for those who would appreciate it but cannot afford it.

$500 would go to supplies and advertising:  pencils, papers, web advertising, and networking.

The last $500 would be delegated between the other two, as needed, also helping to fund donations (by contributing to resources such as supplies, gas, and other necessary things to get the job done) to people and places that would be brightened by artwork; nursing homes, counseling centers, etc.

You can view a partial portfolio on my Facebook page:

https://www.facebook.com/#!/screason/media_set?set=a.10151828474758153.1073741830.731843152&type=3

*EDIT 12-10-13* Check out the beginnings of the Life Itself Art web site!

http:// www.LifeItselfArt.com

Other ways to help:

If you share my campaign, I will share yours via Facebook.  EDIT:  I haven't been able to see who has shared my campaign, so if you share mine and wish for me to share yours, please let me know in the comments.  Thanks, and sorry for the confusion.

If you refer someone to me and they make a purchase, I will credit you $5 (after the project is completed and the total price has been paid), which you can choose to:

-have me donate to your campaign or to a campaign of your choosing;

-have sent via check personally to you

Just make sure they give you credit and that I have your information!

Thank you so much for looking at my campaign. Have a wonderful day!
