story:
Who is Yes Theatre?

A team of passionate artists and administrative people who run a nongovernmental organization that aims to improve the psycho-social well-being of Palestinian kids, pluse aware people about their rights and the importance to claim them . Since 2008 Yes Theatre team has reached more than one hundred thousand person, from different areas. Using drama and theatre as tools of self expression, relief, critical thinking, social change and development. Theatre and drama require teamwork, commitment, spontaneity, creativity, and openness to new ideas. We cooperate with the Ministry of Education, UNRWA, & other original bodies in Hebron.

We are going to be the facilitator who link between right holders, and decision makers (like Ministry of education, Ministry of transportation and  the different duty bearers) In Ghadeer case we will initiate an advocacy campaign so that those people will start to take action to increase girls' access to school. So we are going to work on the policy making level.

the tool we are using is puppet theatre and drama workshops.

through the medium of puppet theatre we are going to aware girls about the importance of education and their right to education, in addition to the importance to attain this right. Furthermore, to aware their parents of the inevitability of education either for their daughters' lives, or for their communities in general. At the same time, we are going to lobby decision makers, to urge them to take action in order to increase girls' access to school. Lastly, to sensitize local community in general about the problem of education in the marginalized communities. 

 

Being part of a LIFE changing experience?

If you know more, you can achieve more.Providing the chance not only  for Ghadeer, but also for all girls from those marginalized areas to be educated means paving the road for a brighter future for those girls. Be part of it, any effort you make may count. Donate Now! One dollar can make a difference! Or Donate your time, share those words. Small deeds but still  count! don't hesitate to share. 


Help us make a brighter future for girls who are less fortunate, help us in creating equal opportunities for those who don't have. Help us in increasing those girls access to school. Donate now, 2 dollars will not make your pocket poorer, yet it will make those girls richer. Or at least spread the word to others so they can contribute and help.

 

Please share this appeal on Facebook, Twitter, tell your friends and family and encourage them to contribute.

Together we can make a brighter future for marginalized girls.

 

Budget:

Proposed budget for production and performances "in dollar"

Budget item

Avarage

directing & Designing

300

Script writing and modification fees

300

Acting: 5 actors, technician for 40 performances

2100 (350$ per person)

Rehearsal Space

500

Fabrics and other supplies to make puppets in addition to (Sets & props), decoration

700

Transportation cost for 40 performances

1100

Total

5000

 

 

The Impact

This project is deemed necessary, as it's contributing to provide more justice for people who have no voice; More just world means more peace, more prosperity for others. It is not fair that sort of people are born with all opportunities, while others grow to be less privileged, ignorant and with less opportunities. We want to contribute to a peaceful world, may be we will not be able to serve all the world but this is the portion that we can contribute with.

successful stories:

Diana SUCCESS STORY 

Her petite steps started at the moment she joined Y4Y program; “I felt that this is the place where I belong to, the place where I can exploit my potentials, I was happy. I used to wait day by day to go to the training.” This is how Diana described her feelings towards drama and theatre which she knew about through the program of Y4Y.  As she was one among the outstanding graduates she was followed up with, by the theatre, and she had the chance to participate in drama workshops, and several productions with YT. In 2013 Diana surpassed the first societal boundaries when she played the main role of a play which its core theme –sexual harassment- is considered to be a taboo in Hebron. Her passion towards theatre and drama was stronger than any obstacle that might hinder her ambition.  In 2015 Diana was chosen to be the protagonist of YT grand production “Handala”. The decision of choosing Diana for this role was challenging for both YT and Diana herself. And  this is due to the high artistic quality of this work. However, challenge was accepted. Sweat and long hours of working were spent to create the character “Fatima” –the protagonist of the play “Handala”-

 

 Challenges

The challenges we might face is that the long time the Ministries will respond to this project. However, it will be only the begining for a bigger campaign that will tackle the policy making level.

Diana SUCCESS STORY 
Her petite steps started at the moment she joined Y4Y program; “I felt that this is the place where I belong to, the place where I can exploit my potentials, I was happy. I used to wait day by day to go to the training.” This is how Diana described her feelings towards drama and theatre which she knew about through the program of Y4Y.  As she was one among the outstanding graduates she was followed up with, by the theatre, and she had the chance to participate in drama workshops, and several productions with YT. In 2013 Diana surpassed the first societal boundaries when she played the main role of a play which its core theme –sexual harassment- is considered to be a taboo in Hebron. Her passion towards theatre and drama was stronger than any obstacle that might hinder her ambition.  In 2015 Diana was chosen to be the protagonist of YT grand production “Handala”. The decision of choosing Diana for this role was challenging for both YT and Diana herself. And  this is due to the high artistic quality of this work. However, challenge was accepted. Sweat and long hours of working were spent to create the character “Fatima” –the protagonist of the play “Handala”-
 

 Challenges
The challenges we might face is that the long time the Ministries will respond to this project. However, it will be only the begining for a bigger campaign that will tackle the policy making level.

story:
'Iris Turns' is a group exhibition of emerging artist designed to provide a platform after graduation. We wish to present a spectacle of a show, spanning various mediums including; film, sculpture, painting and performance that will engage with all members of the public.  Funding would allow us to realise our intentions and help promote our work within the art world.

Please donate anything you can as every little helps! We'd love to see you there, so please come and support our show!  

The private view is held on the 8th of March 6:30 - 8:30 and we have drinks!

story:
Short Summary

In 2016, Claudio Ranieri did what many thought was impossible: leading a team of underestimated players to become champions, putting Leicester at the heart of global consciousness and winning over the hearts of millions in what is already being hailed as the greatest sporting achievement of all time.

Claudio is already going to be immortalised in sporting history for this, but we believe he deserves a proper bronze statue in the city centre to commemorate what he's done for our city.

What We Need

All £100,000 (minus 5% for Indiegogo) will be offered to James Butler RA, the sculptor responsible for the famous Richard III statue outside Leicester Cathedral, to create a one-off commission.

 

What you get

Everyone who gives £20 or more will have their name engraved on a plaque at the foot of the statue.
 

Where it will go

Leicester city centre (precise location TBA).
 

Who we are

A die-hard Leicester city fan (Alan Weston) and a local poet (Tim Grayson). We previously worked together on a commissioned piece for BBC Radio Leicester, which was then featured as part of the 'Backing the Blues' exhibition in New Walk Museum.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't afford to donate but still want to help, you can:

    • Share this campaign among your family and friends to help get the word out!
    • Forward this to any contacts within the media!

    Quotes

    "Sacking Ranieri? They should be building a statue for him.' Jamie Carragher, Daily Mail
    'No arguments from me. They should erect a statue of Claudio Ranieri in the centre of Leicester, to stand alongside King Richard III, in recognition of what he's done for the city.' Robbie Savage, The Mirror
    'I think a statue would be well deserved. He's done a lot for the club [and] he's done a lot for the city. Yeah, would definitely support that.' Christian Fuchs, Leicester City FC
    'Surely Leicester should be building a statue of Ranieri - or am I just old fashioned?'  Tim Vickery, BBC


    Updates

    28/02/2017 Thanks to the Leicester Mercury for their support!

story:
We're Building an Interstellar Emissary!

Interstellar Emissary is an homage to the Golden Record on the Voyager Spacecraft. And the Desert Wizards of Mars are bringing it to Burning Man in 2015.

Interstellar Emissary is about space. It's about science. It's a place to sit and think. It's a place to talk and dance. It's a gateway and a beacon to Black Rock Observatory. It honors and celebrates the magnificent work that created the Golden Record.

Golden Record? What’s that?

The real Voyager Golden Record was launched in 1977 and is now out in space somewhere far beyond Pluto. Interstellar Emissary looks exactly like the Golden Record, except ours is way bigger, is made of lucite, and it glows with a rainbow of LED lights! 

The Golden Record is a phonograph record (ask your parents) containing sounds and images of Earth, and NASA/JPL launched it into space in hopes that intelligent extraterrestrial life, or possibly future humans, would find it and be able to learn about life on Earth.

Our Interstellar Emissary will include the same sounds as the original Golden Record. Yes, you'll be able to hear the very same sounds that aliens will hear! 

We're taking Interstellar Emissary to Burning Man 2015 where it will be a beacon in deep playa.  As you approach the Interstellar Emissary, sensors will cause the lights to glow more brightly. Continued motion will cause the colors to change -- you will be actively participating in the creation of the experience.

We've built a prototype:

And we've begun testing:


We even took it out for Yuri's night where a certain someone tried to strike up a conversation:

Now we need your help getting the project completed and ready for Burning Man.
*** Donations are TAX DEDUCTIBLE. ***

Interstellar Emissary is a project of the Desert Wizards of Mars -- the very same crew who built Black Rock Observatory and the Mars Rover Art Car.  So you know this will be epic. 

Technical details:

Interstellar Emissary will feature a 6' diameter lucite disc replicating the symbols on the Golden Record. Programmed LED lighting will make this an interactive art piece. The sounds of Earth will greet you as you approach the piece.

We'll have a 16' x 16' raised stage where you can interact with the piece and with other people, creating an adaptive lighting and sound experience.

Although it's a completely separate project, the Interstellar Emissary will act as a beacon to help you find your way to Black Rock Observatory, our sister project, using lasers to guide you across deep playa. And like all projects of the Desert Wizards of Mars, this will be an educational piece. Our goal has always been to create art that gets people excited about science.

Design concepts:

Our designs for the structure that supports the Emissary include a stage (yay dancing!) and shade structures (yay for daytime sun relief!). 

As you approach, you'll reach a swirling vortex of steps leading you to the stage where you can dance beneath the glow of the Interstellar Emissary.

These designs have been formulated so the structure can be scaled to your level of support. It will be tweaked to be in keeping with the vision shown in the video above as our funding levels increase. 

DISCLAIMER:
This is an art project that is 100% citizen funded and there is no official relationship with Caltech, JPL or NASA. Any employees of the above organizations participating on the project do so as private citizens of the arts and do so on their own non-work time.

What We Need & What You Get

We need funding to get this amazing piece of art built and transported out to Black Rock City and we'd love to have your help!

Funding Goal = $ 14,850.00

This will help us pay for a huge amount of awesome:

  • Laser cut disc, lighting, hardware, sensors, sound controls and speakers, a stage and seating, transportation, and power.

Stretch Goal = $ 23,930.00

If we surpass our Funding Goal, our Stretch Goal can help us make this even more amazing! We'll add a superstructure and more lighting. And some trusses, rigging, and wings!

We have some fantastic perks for our supporters!

  • OMG you can have a disc of your own! Various sizes! Check our perks list and be ready to pick your jaw up off the floor.
  • Tee shirts! Stickers! Patches! Sew your patches on your tee shirts!
  • Perks will ship in October 2015!
  • Did we mention your donation is tax deductible? It is!
  • Hint: Here are some photos...

The Impact

Interstellar Emissary is a beacon in the night for space travelers: a brightly lit disc hanging in the night sky. Like its predecessors, Black Rock Observatory and Mars Rover Art Car, it's our way to express our love of space while sharing our excitement about science with you. We love to come to Burning Man with big art, and know that we've inspired others to reflect on their place in the cosmos. We want to know that we may have encouraged a few people to glance up toward the heavens from time to time and be in total awe long after returning from Black Rock City. We want you to carry our excitement about space wherever you go.

Interstellar Emissary will inspire thought and discussion about unity of life on Earth, and hope for humankind’s future place among other spacefaring civilizations.

The Black Rock Observatory made its debut at Burning Man 2014, but we heard that it was difficult to find in the darkness of deep playa. The Interstellar Emissary is a companion piece, not only acting as a beacon to guide people to the Observatory, but also providing a place to sit, relax, and think about this big giant Carnival of Mirrors we're all living in.

Risks & Challenges

Building large scale art in the harsh desert environment is no easy task. The Desert Wizards of Mars have a proven record of making it happen, and we have a solid crew of builders and technicians. The critical component is funding.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Every contribution helps! If you can't help with funding, please help us get the word out by using the Indiegogo share tools, and sending the link to your friends.Follow us on Facebook and Twitter! Share and retweet our updates! Check out our website! Sign up for our email newsletter!

    And come see us on playa!

story:
Hello!

I'm Nicole Iredale, I run a jewellery business from my workshop in the Forest of Dean.

Every year I try to design and make a new jewellery collection, but this year I need a little bit of help with funding it.

I don't expect to be given money for nothing, so I have set up a variety of different perks, with each donation over £10.00 getting you an item of jewellery and many of the perks also come with a free gift! There are also exclusive items available which will not be for sale anywhere else, so you have a chance to own some very limited edition items! Each contributor will receive a public thank you via  my facebook page (or you can remain anonymous if you wish).

My new jewellery collection, "The Potting Shed", is costing more to produce than my past collections because I have designed everything using CAD (computer aided design), consequently, each item in the collection needs to be 3D printed and moulded, which is pretty expensive!

So far I have around 20 items ready to print, meaning that moulding will cost around £240 and the 3D printing bill will be approx £500.

If I do not meet my goal, then the money raised will still go towards getting as many items made as I can with the money available. With each item costing around £25 to 3D print, even if I just raise £50 I can still get two new designs printed, so all funding will be very much appreciated.
The finished jewellery collection will feature on my website and be sold online as well as in shops and galleries, and I am hoping to have the full collection ready in time for Christmas to help boost my sales and my business after a difficult year.
 
Once I have made all of the master patterns, I'll be able to turn them into rings, earrings, bracelets, necklaces, cufflinks... So many different items!

If you can't donate but would like to help, please share my campaign with friends and family or anywhere else you think might be worthwhile.

Thank you so much for reading my campaign.

story:
BronxArtSpace at 305 E. 140th Street

Who We Are & What We’ve Done

Started in 2008, BronxArtSpace is a cultural space for all that promotes the innovative ideas of underrepresented and emerging artists from the Bronx and around the world.


Located in the Mott Haven neighborhood of the Bronx, where startling few arts venues exist and many have come and gone, BronxArtSpace is a consistent resource for its community, providing an inclusive space for exhibitions, workshops, performances, screenings, discussions, and celebrations. All programming is free.


By focusing on topical issues that resonate within our community like identity, racism, displacement, immigration, and the environment, BronxArtSpace has become an invaluable hub for dialogue among people from all walks of life.



Throughout the years BronxArtSpace has had the pleasure of organizing celebrated exhibitions like Language and Identity, Faces from the Block, Turn Up the Volume, Narratives of Self-Exile, Bienal de Arte Latinoamericano, and Synthetic Zero with artists such as John Ahearn, Michael Paul Britto, David Antonio Cruz, Jane Dickson, Latoya Ruby Frazier, Joe Lewis, Tim Rollins, Alexandra Tatarsky, Xavier Figueroa, and Alex Mendoza.


Luis Stephenberg's installation in Transporting Home, 2010.


Join Us in Producing Our 7th Year of Programs

The next year of programs includes:

  • Expanded workshops with middle-school youth and collaboration with the Bronx Children's Museum, PS49, and other neighborhood schools 

  • Exhibitions include Hot or Cold? curated by BX200 featuring 9 Bronx artists, The 2% Precipice featuring the mobile Moss Lab by Marion Wilson, Synthetic Zero with all-new avant-garde new media works, Speak Out open-call exhibition addressing institutionalized racism, Tyranny's Tear remembering the tragic years of the Trujillo regime, and Charm & Vinegar with satirical soft-sculpture by women


Brazilian artist Izolag teaching summer workshop, 2015. 

Jessica Arsenau performing in Synthetic Zero, 2015.


What We Value

Where nearly 50% of our neighbors live under the poverty line, we understand the tremendous impact the arts can have in fostering confidence, widening perspectives and sparking conversations that can produce long-lasting change.


Summer Art Workshop taught by Lady K Fever, 2015.

Founded by Linda Cunningham and Mitsu Hadeishi, artist and curator who reside in the same 1904 garment factory that houses the gallery, BronxArtSpace has dedicated itself to exhibiting the highest quality artwork from the Bronx and beyond while furthering local arts education and opportunities.

Mural by Brazilian street artists Izolag and Ananda Nahu. During their exhibition "Faces from the Block" they completed 5 murals in Mott Haven, 3 in NYCHA Housing Playgrounds.


Join Our Family

Spread the news of BronxArtSpace’s campaign and programs through Twitter, Facebook, and Email.

BronxArtSpace has sustained itself thanks to the passion of its founders as well as the generosity of our volunteers, artists, curators, audience and donors like you! 

Funders have included NYC Department of Cultural Affairs, New York State Council on the Arts, The New Yankee Stadium Community Benefits Fund, Simon Bolivar, Citizens Committee for New York City, and Poets & Writers. All of these funders require matching funds.

Join us today and keep the arts thriving for our community.



Make Your Gift Today!

Your gift will allow BronxArtSpace to continue to be a pivotal space for artists, curators, and the public to present and experience art and performance in the South Bronx.

Remember no gift is too small or too big.

Thank you to Joanna and Mitsu Hadeishi who created the video.

And thank you!  

BronxArtSpace is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of BronxArtSpace must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.


Perks


Really excited about a specific perk? Receive any combination of perks by giving at a variety of levels.

Visionary Supporter, $5000
Be listed as a visionary supporter of BronxArtSpace! 
Be recognized for your instrumental contribution on our website and in all printed material for 2015-2016 programming. Plus receive this sculpture, Wen Yi  by acclaimed Bronx artist John Ahearn.  16" x 21" x 6"


Sculpture by John Ahearn, $2500 
Receive this life-size pigmented sculpture by John Ahearn. 


Painting by Ananda Nahu, $1500

Brazilian artists Ananda Nahu & Izolag created 5 murals in Mott Haven during their exhibition Faces from the Block this summer. Incredible feat! 

Receive a painting by Ananda Nahu that was featured in the show. 32" x 46"


Prints by Tim Rollins & KOS (Kids of Survival), $1000

Choose your favorite limited edition etching/chine collé by Tim Rollins and KOS (Kids of Survival)!

Receive 3 prints from The Temptation of St. Anthony edition 16 1/4" x 11 3/4" each.


OR one print from the The River by Duke Ellington edition 11" x 14", available in the US for the first time with BronxArtSpace.

This is a special gift to BAS from Tim Rollins and KOS! These editions are highly valued.

You will receive an email from art@bronxartspace.com confirming the availability of your chosen edition.


Drawing by Izolag, $750
Choose one of two large drawings by Brazilian street artist Izolag featured in Faces from the Block.  
Drawing No. 5  24 5/8" x 35 3/8"


or Drawing No. 7  24 5/8" x 35 3/8"


You will receive an email from art@bronxartspace.com confirming which drawing is still available. 


Ahearn & Lanzo Studio Visit, $500, 1/1 CLAIMED

Take a friend and visit two very special artists, John Ahearn and his wife Juanita Lanzo in their studio above the tire shop near BronxArtSpace. Meet these truly engaging personalities and hear about their work, interests and John's lifelong involvement in the Bronx.


Choice of Bronx Artists Limited Editions, $500

Choose among a variety of limited edition prints by BronxArtSpace's very own Co-founder and artist Linda Cunningham and Tim Rollins and KOS. 

Choose between Linda Cunningham's Origins 24" x 36", 


Tide Pool II 18" x 24",


orTide Pool I  18" x 24"--all early works by Linda Cunningham. 


Or receive a limited edition etching/chine collé of A Mid-Summer Night’s Dream  10" x 8" by celebrated artist Tim Rollins and KOS (Kids of Survival). 


This is a special gift to BAS from Tim Rollins and KOS! This edition is highly valued. 
You will receive an email from art@bronxartspace.com confirming which editions are still available. 

Choice of Bronx Artists Limited Editions, $300

Choose among a variety of limited edition prints by BronxArtSpace's very own Co-founder and artist Linda Cunningham, Mike Kamber, and Glendalys Medina. 

Receive a limited edition silkscreen of BlackDiamond 30" x 23" created by Bronx artist Glendalys Medina during her stay at the Wassaic Project in upstate New York.


Or receive a photograph of Darfur Women 13" x 19" by photojournalist Mike Kamber. Learn more about his work here: http://www.kamberphoto.com/ 


Or receive a limited edition sugar lift etching of View from the El 18" x 24" or Progress 18" x 24" by BronxArtSpace's very own Co-founder and artist Linda Cunningham! 



You will receive an email from art@bronxartspace.com confirming which edition is still available.

Dinner with the Artists, $250

Dine with fellow friends of BAS and the artists of our fall show 2% Precipice for a very special evening in the gallery on Monday, November 2. Hospitality will be sponsored by popular local restaurant Ceetay.

Dates to be confirmed via email.  

Choice of Bronx Artists Limited Editions, $200

Receive a small framed linocut by Rene de los Santos, Smithsonian-collected artist and member of the Dominican Print Collective in NY. This work was previously exhibited at BronxArtSpace in Narratives of Self-Exile. 


Or receive an iconic photograph taken in the 1980s by acclaimed photographer Ricky Flores. His work was also featured in Faces from the Block. 

Choose between Myrna  13" x 19"


orHealth Aids 13" x 19". 


Your Tintype Portrait, $150 
Have an intriguing tintype portrait taken in costume of your choice by artist Louis Riso. He uses restored 19-century equipment with which you can watch him develop your tin plate on site! Portraits are 5" x 7" for a gift of $150.
You will receive an email from art@bronxartspace.com to arrange your appointment to be photographed by the artist in November. 


Small Tintype Portrait OR "Photojournalists on War" Book, $100

Have your 4" x 6" portrait taken in costume by artist Louis Riso using 19th century equipment. Watch him develop your tin plate on site! You will receive an email from us to arrange your appointment in November.

Or receive critically acclaimed "Photojournalists on War: The Untold Stories from Iraq" by Michael Kamber. Published in 2013, it is a ground breaking visual and oral history of America's 9-year conflict in the Middle East.


Private Tour of "2% Precipe" and Art Mobile, $75

Take a private tour with a friend of BAS' fall exhibition 2% Precipe and its accompanying art mobile Moss Lab designed by artist Marion Wilson. Tours are available between October 14 and November 7. Please note that access to Moss Lab may have limited availability.

You will receive an email from art@bronxartspace.com to arrange your visit. 


Choice of Bronx Books, $50

Receive a copy of Bronx Artists Documentary Project published in 2015 as the culmination of a collaboration between photographers and visuals artists of the Bronx. This 272-page, hardcover, limited-print book with over 300 photographs documents visual artists at work in the Bronx in 2014. The book also includes a visual directory of all participants as well as arts organizations of the Bronx. 



Or receive "Bronx Boys" (2014) presenting over 100 photographs made by Stephen Shames that capture a group of boys from Fordham, Bedford, and Bathgate neighborhoods in 1977.


Artist Portfolio Review, $35

Have your art portfolio reviewed by distinguished curators Rocío Aranda-Alvarado from El Museo del Barrio, Christine Licata from Casita Maria, Krista Saunders Scenna from Ground Floor Gallery, Manon Slome from No Longer Empty, and independent curator Sarah Corona. 

Choose quick before slots fill up! Portfolio reviews are $35/20 min session, so contribute $210 to meet all 6! 

Tentatively Nov. 15. You'll receive an email confirming who is available to meet with you and when. 

Kids Summer Workshop Print, $25

Receive a small print of the mural our kids made this summer in the gallery with street artist Lady K Fever.

Thank You SHOUT OUT!, $10

Look out for our thank you on Twitter @BronxArtSpace!
story_txt:
BronxArtSpace at 305 E. 140th StreetWho We Are & What We’ve DoneStarted in 2008, BronxArtSpace is a cultural space for all that promotes the innovative ideas of underrepresented and emerging artists from the Bronx and around the world. Located in the Mott Haven neighborhood of the Bronx, where startling few arts venues exist and many have come and gone, BronxArtSpace is a consistent resource for its community, providing an inclusive space for exhibitions, workshops, performances, screenings, discussions, and celebrations. All programming is free.By focusing on topical issues that resonate within our community like identity, racism, displacement, immigration, and the environment, BronxArtSpace has become an invaluable hub for dialogue among people from all walks of life.Throughout the years BronxArtSpace has had the pleasure of organizing celebrated exhibitions like Language and Identity, Faces from the Block, Turn Up the Volume, Narratives of Self-Exile, Bienal de Arte Latinoamericano, and Synthetic Zero with artists such as John Ahearn, Michael Paul Britto, David Antonio Cruz, Jane Dickson, Latoya Ruby Frazier, Joe Lewis, Tim Rollins, Alexandra Tatarsky, Xavier Figueroa, and Alex Mendoza.Luis Stephenberg's installation in Transporting Home, 2010.Join Us in Producing Our 7th Year of ProgramsThe next year of programs includes: 
Expanded workshops with middle-school youth and collaboration with the Bronx Children's Museum, PS49, and other neighborhood schools 
Exhibitions include Hot or Cold? curated by BX200 featuring 9 Bronx artists, The 2% Precipice featuring the mobile Moss Lab by Marion Wilson, Synthetic Zero with all-new avant-garde new media works, Speak Out open-call exhibition addressing institutionalized racism, Tyranny's Tear remembering the tragic years of the Trujillo regime, and Charm & Vinegar with satirical soft-sculpture by women


Brazilian artist Izolag teaching summer workshop, 2015. 



Jessica Arsenau performing in Synthetic Zero, 2015.

What We ValueWhere nearly 50% of our neighbors live under the poverty line, we understand the tremendous impact the arts can have in fostering confidence, widening perspectives and sparking conversations that can produce long-lasting change. 


Summer Art Workshop taught by Lady K Fever, 2015.
Founded by Linda Cunningham and Mitsu Hadeishi, artist and curator who reside in the same 1904 garment factory that houses the gallery, BronxArtSpace has dedicated itself to exhibiting the highest quality artwork from the Bronx and beyond while furthering local arts education and opportunities. 


Mural by Brazilian street artists Izolag and Ananda Nahu. During their exhibition "Faces from the Block" they completed 5 murals in Mott Haven, 3 in NYCHA Housing Playgrounds.


Join Our Family
Spread the news of BronxArtSpace’s campaign and programs through Twitter, Facebook, and Email.
BronxArtSpace has sustained itself thanks to the passion of its founders as well as the generosity of our volunteers, artists, curators, audience and donors like you! 
Funders have included NYC Department of Cultural Affairs, New York State Council on the Arts, The New Yankee Stadium Community Benefits Fund, Simon Bolivar, Citizens Committee for New York City, and Poets & Writers. All of these funders require matching funds.
Join us today and keep the arts thriving for our community.

Make Your Gift Today!
Your gift will allow BronxArtSpace to continue to be a pivotal space for artists, curators, and the public to present and experience art and performance in the South Bronx.
Remember no gift is too small or too big.
Thank you to Joanna and Mitsu Hadeishi who created the video.
And thank you!  
BronxArtSpace is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of BronxArtSpace must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.PerksReally excited about a specific perk? Receive any combination of perks by giving at a variety of levels.Visionary Supporter, $5000Be listed as a visionary supporter of BronxArtSpace! 
Be recognized for your instrumental contribution on our website and in all printed material for 2015-2016 programming. Plus receive this sculpture, Wen Yi  by acclaimed Bronx artist John Ahearn.  16" x 21" x 6"


Sculpture by John Ahearn, $2500 
Receive this life-size pigmented sculpture by John Ahearn. 

Painting by Ananda Nahu, $1500
Brazilian artists Ananda Nahu & Izolag created 5 murals in Mott Haven during their exhibition Faces from the Block this summer. Incredible feat! 
Receive a painting by Ananda Nahu that was featured in the show. 32" x 46"



Prints by Tim Rollins & KOS (Kids of Survival), $1000
Choose your favorite limited edition etching/chine collé by Tim Rollins and KOS (Kids of Survival)!
Receive 3 prints from The Temptation of St. Anthony edition 16 1/4" x 11 3/4" each.



OR one print from the The River by Duke Ellington edition 11" x 14", available in the US for the first time with BronxArtSpace.


This is a special gift to BAS from Tim Rollins and KOS! These editions are highly valued.
You will receive an email from art@bronxartspace.com confirming the availability of your chosen edition.

Drawing by Izolag, $750Choose one of two large drawings by Brazilian street artist Izolag featured in Faces from the Block.  Drawing No. 5  24 5/8" x 35 3/8"
or Drawing No. 7  24 5/8" x 35 3/8"


You will receive an email from art@bronxartspace.com confirming which drawing is still available. 
Ahearn & Lanzo Studio Visit, $500, 1/1 CLAIMED
Take a friend and visit two very special artists, John Ahearn and his wife Juanita Lanzo in their studio above the tire shop near BronxArtSpace. Meet these truly engaging personalities and hear about their work, interests and John's lifelong involvement in the Bronx.
Choice of Bronx Artists Limited Editions, $500Choose among a variety of limited edition prints by BronxArtSpace's very own Co-founder and artist Linda Cunningham and Tim Rollins and KOS. 
Choose between Linda Cunningham's Origins 24" x 36", 

Tide Pool II 18" x 24",
orTide Pool I  18" x 24"--all early works by Linda Cunningham. 
Or receive a limited edition etching/chine collé of A Mid-Summer Night’s Dream  10" x 8" by celebrated artist Tim Rollins and KOS (Kids of Survival). 
This is a special gift to BAS from Tim Rollins and KOS! This edition is highly valued. You will receive an email from art@bronxartspace.com confirming which editions are still available. Choice of Bronx Artists Limited Editions, $300Choose among a variety of limited edition prints by BronxArtSpace's very own Co-founder and artist Linda Cunningham, Mike Kamber, and Glendalys Medina. Receive a limited edition silkscreen of BlackDiamond 30" x 23" created by Bronx artist Glendalys Medina during her stay at the Wassaic Project in upstate New York.
Or receive a photograph of Darfur Women 13" x 19" by photojournalist Mike Kamber. Learn more about his work here: http://www.kamberphoto.com/ 
Or receive a limited edition sugar lift etching of View from the El 18" x 24" or Progress 18" x 24" by BronxArtSpace's very own Co-founder and artist Linda Cunningham! 

You will receive an email from art@bronxartspace.com confirming which edition is still available.Dinner with the Artists, $250Dine with fellow friends of BAS and the artists of our fall show 2% Precipice for a very special evening in the gallery on Monday, November 2. Hospitality will be sponsored by popular local restaurant Ceetay.Dates to be confirmed via email.  
Choice of Bronx Artists Limited Editions, $200Receive a small framed linocut by Rene de los Santos, Smithsonian-collected artist and member of the Dominican Print Collective in NY. This work was previously exhibited at BronxArtSpace in Narratives of Self-Exile. 


Or receive an iconic photograph taken in the 1980s by acclaimed photographer Ricky Flores. His work was also featured in Faces from the Block. Choose between Myrna  13" x 19"


orHealth Aids 13" x 19". 



Your Tintype Portrait, $150 Have an intriguing tintype portrait taken in costume of your choice by artist Louis Riso. He uses restored 19-century equipment with which you can watch him develop your tin plate on site! Portraits are 5" x 7" for a gift of $150.
You will receive an email from art@bronxartspace.com to arrange your appointment to be photographed by the artist in November. 



Small Tintype Portrait OR "Photojournalists on War" Book, $100
Have your 4" x 6" portrait taken in costume by artist Louis Riso using 19th century equipment. Watch him develop your tin plate on site! You will receive an email from us to arrange your appointment in November.
Or receive critically acclaimed "Photojournalists on War: The Untold Stories from Iraq" by Michael Kamber. Published in 2013, it is a ground breaking visual and oral history of America's 9-year conflict in the Middle East.



Private Tour of "2% Precipe" and Art Mobile, $75
Take a private tour with a friend of BAS' fall exhibition 2% Precipe and its accompanying art mobile Moss Lab designed by artist Marion Wilson.   Tours are available between October 14 and November 7. Please note that access to Moss Lab may have limited availability.
You will receive an email from art@bronxartspace.com to arrange your visit. 


Choice of Bronx Books, $50
Receive a copy of Bronx Artists Documentary Project published in 2015 as the culmination of a collaboration between photographers and visuals artists of the Bronx.  This 272-page, hardcover, limited-print book with over 300 photographs documents visual artists at work in the Bronx in 2014. The book also includes a visual directory of all participants as well as arts organizations of the Bronx. 

Or receive "Bronx Boys" (2014) presenting over 100 photographs made by Stephen Shames that capture a group of boys from Fordham, Bedford, and Bathgate neighborhoods in 1977.Artist Portfolio Review, $35
Have your art portfolio reviewed by distinguished curators Rocío Aranda-Alvarado from El Museo del Barrio, Christine Licata from Casita Maria, Krista Saunders Scenna from Ground Floor Gallery, Manon Slome from No Longer Empty, and independent curator Sarah Corona. Choose quick before slots fill up!  Portfolio reviews are $35/20 min session, so contribute $210 to meet all 6! Tentatively Nov. 15. You'll receive an email confirming who is available to meet with you and when. Kids Summer Workshop Print, $25Receive a small print of the mural our kids made this summer in the gallery with street artist Lady K Fever.Thank You SHOUT OUT!, $10Look out for our thank you on Twitter @BronxArtSpace!

story:
Le projet Warma Suyus, dans le village de Quinua, région d'Ayacucho au Pérou, a pour vocation d'aider les enfants du village à découvrir diverses activités auprès des volontaires. Cette association est à but non lucratif. Aujourd'hui, nous nous tournons vers vous afin de nous aider à loger les bénévoles dans des locaux décents. Nous aurions donc besoin, entre autres, de matelas, de matériel de cuisine, d'une douche solaire, de chaises et de fournitures scolaires, pour les enfants.   http://quinuawarmaperou.org/

Page facebook : https://www.facebook.com/warma.suyus

OBJET PRIX TOTAL
8 : MATELAS 8 X 30 240
1 : DOUCHE SOLAIRE 10 10
1 : MARMITTE 10 10
2 : POELE 2 X 10 20
FOURNITURES POUR 4 MOIS 30 X 4 120
12 CHAISES 5 X 12 60
3 TABLES 3 X 15 45
TOTAL 505

story:
Le Projet



Après une première performance en 2015 avec «Brume- De la Légende au Mythe» (voir vidéo ci-dessus) qui regroupait 9 robes issues de travaux personnels réalisés par Clara Maeda lors de ces 5 dernières années, «Back to Pagan» se compose de robes entièrement réalisées autour d’un même thème, s’inspirant aussi bien des mythologies pré-chré- tiennes, que de mouvements artistiques tels le préraphaélisme, l’impressionisme ou l’Art nouveau.
Malgré tout, dans une démarche toujours proche de celle du costume, chaque robe a sa propre identité, son propre symbolisme, sa propre histoire à raconter. 

«Back to Pagan» est un retour aux sources, aux relations intrinsèques de l’homme avec la nature et sa spiritualité profonde.


Au commencement, il y avait la lumière, 

lueur de clair de lune entre les branches entremêlées du Grand Arbre.
Naissance teintée de pourpre, fluide filin de vie. 

Beauté éphémère d’un pétale aux joues rosées, 

relent de charogne drapée de sensualité,
la fragilité impalpable de l’être qui fut et qui devint. 

Car à l’aube du crépuscule, vie et mort entrelacent leurs mains.
Au couché du Levant, d’un cœur endormi s’envole l’âme papillonnant.



Plus qu’un simple défilé, «Back to Pagan» se veut proche du spectacle vivant, à l’attention du grand public et non d’une simple audiance de professionnels de la mode.

Chaque modèle incarne son personnage et la symbolique autour de chaque robe, dans des mouvements parfois proche de la danse, ou encore d’un jeu d’acteur.

10 robes défilent au son de la musique live sur une dizaine de minutes, comme une histoire mystérieuse contée aux spectateurs, une parenthèse hors du temps qui espère provoquer chez chacun et chacune des émotions pleines de douceurs et de poésie, tout comme des sentiments forts et fulgurants. 


Pourquoi ce financement participatif?

Depuis 1 an et demi Clara Maeda travaille sans relâche pour vous présenter des créations uniques, mises en scène grâce au travail bénévole de toute une équipe : modèles, coiffeuse, maquilleuse, photographe, musiciens.

19 robes au total, entre les créations de "Brume" présentées en 2015 et maintenant celles de "Back to Pagan", toutes inédites et non destinées à la vente. Tout ceci représente des mois et des mois de travail, des centaines et centaines d'euros de tissus.

Au delà des créations en elles-même, organiser des défilés représente de grosses dépenses. Si pour la deuxième année consécutive, l'évènement Magic de Monaco fait confiance à Clara Maeda en tant qu'invitée, emmener toute une équipe sur place demande un gros budget. 

De plus, cette année, le nouveau défilé "Back to Pagan" sera présenté à Paris le 1er mars prochain, et l'évènement est entièrement auto-organisé.

Vous l'aurez compris, nous aider à financer ce projet, c'est couvrir au moins une petite partie des dépenses matérielles ou logistiques déjà engendrées (location de salle, achat de fonds photos, matériel de mise en scène, tissus, frais de transport etc…), et nous permettre peut-être, si le palier minimum de 500€ est dépassé d'envisager de nouvelles créations, de nouvelles performances. Bref, de nous aider à faire perdurer notre passion au service du Beau et de l'Art.


Quelques mots sur les acteurs du projet


Suivant les pas de ses arrière-grands-parents, tailleurs et couturières de profession, Clara Maeda est une créatrice normande expatriée au Japon, un pays qu’elle a réussi à apprivoiser à travers sa belle-famille nippone et son immersion dans l’apprentissage du «wasai», l’art de la confection du kimono.

Forte de ces métissages culturels, de son savoir faire et son amour du détail, Clara Maeda navigue sur les traces du japonisme entre Europe et Asie, histoire et modernité, aime brouiller les lignes, dépasser les frontières.

Elle réalise depuis son atelier de Nara des créations sur-mesure et originales pour un public très varié : robes de mariées, costumes, corsets féminins et masculins, mode alternative et prêt à porter d’inspiration historique.

Entre lolitas historiques et paganisme cosmopolite, elle a su créer une mode unique, puisant son inspiration aussi bien dans l’imaginaire des hommes que dans leur Histoire. Des kilomètres de tissu qui font le trait d’union entre les époques et les cultures, entre le conte et le réel, entre la France et le Japon. 


Encore une fois, ces créations autour du vêtement seront appuyées par la musique live de Yuichiro, qui viendra cette fois-ci en solo accompagner la performance avec une musique originale.
Guitariste et compositeur japonais, Yuichiro Maeda a été élevé dans une famille à la fois respectueuse des traditions ancestrales et très ouverte sur le monde, deux notions qui marqueront sa vie personnelle et professionnelle. Nourrit de musique anglaise dès le plus jeune âge, il partira étudier à l’ado- lescence à la LIPA de Liverpool (école fondée par Paul Mc Cartney), avant de parcourir l’Europe vers de nouveaux horizons musicaux pendant une dizaine d’années avec son groupe yanéka. Il posera notamment ses va- lises à Londres, à Stockholm ou encore Paris, trois capitales marquantes de son itinéraire musical encore aujourd’hui.

Depuis plusieurs années il développe ses talents de compositeur, ingénieur et performeur en solo, travaillant un son sans limites ni barrières aux ins- pirations très diverses, à la fois atmosphérique, électro, moderne et rétro. Grâce à sa guitare et un parterre de pédales, il crée sur scène un tissu d’expérimentations sonores basé sur des loops qui se démultiplient et une guitare qui n’en est plus une, se changeant tour à tour en voix, cordes ou encore percussions.

Que ce soit dans l’animation comme dans la mode, ses collaborations sont toutes aussi diverses et enrichissantes, avec des créateurs établis depuis des décennies comme Issey Miyake, aux faiseurs de tendances actuelles avec Art Comes First. 


Alexandra Banti est une photographe Française, attirée tout d’abord par le dessin et le métier d’illustratrice, elle découvrit la photographie durant son BTS de communication visuelle. Elle entreprit alors d’exercer sa passion en parallèle de ses études, apprenant au fil des shootings et des rencontres enrichissantes. Elle met en scène, crée des tenues et des coiffes mais aussi maquille et coiffe ses modèles la plupart du temps. 

Elle s’intéresse donc aussi beaucoup à l’histoire du costume et de la mode (de la renaissance aux années 70), aux mœurs et coutumes d’autres époques et à la place de la femme dans la société. En effet, on remarque aisément que cette dernière tient une place très importante dans son travail. Tantôt femme fatale, tantôt éthérée, elle séduit ou émeu, mais toujours dans un soucis d’élégance et de beauté. Son but n’est pas de placer la femme en objet de désir, mais plus de jouer sur le côté « mystique » qu’elle peut avoir.

Alexandra fait partie intégrante du projet depuis le début, apportant son soutien et surtout de magnifiques images autour de ces performances.



Margaux Genest notre coiffeuse, et Vanessa Brooke Lopez notre maquilleuse nous offrent avec passion leur temps et leur talent pour créer un univers unique autour de chaque robe, chaque personnage.

Sans oublier bien sûr toutes nos modèles bénévoles mais non moins talentueuses, Julia, Nella, Johanna, Line, Tamara, Sirithil, Lanivia, Hana, Klara et Heima!


Les Contreparties



Parmi ces créations Clara Maeda réalisées à la main, choisissez un de ces colliers seul pour 15€ ou en set pour 25€ ci-dessous, avec une broche, une paire de boucles d'oreilles ou une bague! Premier arrivé, premier servi!



Tirages 10x15cm ou 15x18cm issus de la série "Brume - De la Légende au Mythe", par Alexandra Banti, à respectivement 10€ et 15€



Choisissez un tirage de taille poster parmi ces clichés signés Nicolas Meunier pour 25€, représentant différentes créations de prêt à porter Clara Maeda réalisées à travers les années! Encore une fois, premier arrivé, premier servi!



Si vous êtes prêt à offrir 50€ à notre projet, voici la contrepartie que vous pouvez vous procurer : une ceinture corsetée faite main par Clara Maeda, en doupion de soie rose pale, guipure et broderie.
Elle conviendra à quelqu'un ayant un tour de taille entre 60 et 75cm!


Pour le prix exceptionnel de 120€, offre-vous une séance photo d'1h30 dans une robe Clara Maeda, sous l'objectif d'Alexandra Banti. Vous recevrez par la suite 4 photos retouchées!

Si vous ne connaissez pas encore son travail, c'est par ici :

http://alexandrabanti.com

https://www.facebook.com/alexandrabanti.photography




On continue de monter dans les contreparties avec cette première robe "Alice", pièce unique crée par Clara Maeda. Pour 250€ au lieu de 450€ recevez cette robe unique, réalisée d’après les illustrations de François Amoretti.
Robe corsetée avec chemise, manches et tablier intégrés, en taffetas de soie bleu, coton fleuri blanc ton sur ton, dentelle anglaise, rubans de satin, boutons nacrés.

Jupe à 5 volants en dentelle anglaise.  Attention, le jupon donnant le volume à la robe n'est pas fourni.

Elle conviendra à une petite taille, maximum 85cm de poitrine, 65cm de tour de taille, et 28cm de tour de biceps.



Dans un autre style, nous mettons à votre contribution cet ensemble 18ème composé d'une jupe en doupion de soie ourlée à la main, et d'une veste en velours de soie ivoire et brocard mauve, décorée d'un galon argent et de mousseline de soie métallisée . 
Offrez-vous cette tenue tout en soutenant notre projet pour 350€ au lieu de 1050€!
Pour avoir une silhouette 18ème, l'ensemble est à porter sur un corps à baleine et une paire de paniers (pour l'achat de cette tenue, bénéficiez  d'une réduction de 25% sur une paire de paniers et un corps à baleine sur-mesure)

Taille maximum portée sans corset 86cm de poitrine, 68cm de tour de taille, 28cm de tour de biceps. Avec un corset, vos mensurations peuvent être légèrement plus importantes, puisque ce dernier affinera votre buste.


Toute l'équipe vous remercie d'avance pour votre intérêt et votre soutien, si vous ne pouvez contribuer vous-même, n'hésitez pas à partager ce projet autour de vous!

Il posera notamment ses va- lises à Londres, à Stockholm ou encore Paris, trois capitales marquantes de son itinéraire musical encore aujourd’hui.
Depuis plusieurs années il développe ses talents de compositeur, ingénieur et performeur en solo, travaillant un son sans limites ni barrières aux ins- pirations très diverses, à la fois atmosphérique, électro, moderne et rétro. Grâce à sa guitare et un parterre de pédales, il crée sur scène un tissu d’expérimentations sonores basé sur des loops qui se démultiplient et une guitare qui n’en est plus une, se changeant tour à tour en voix, cordes ou encore percussions.
Que ce soit dans l’animation comme dans la mode, ses collaborations sont toutes aussi diverses et enrichissantes, avec des créateurs établis depuis des décennies comme Issey Miyake, aux faiseurs de tendances actuelles avec Art Comes First. 







Alexandra Banti est une photographe Française, attirée tout d’abord par le dessin et le métier d’illustratrice, elle découvrit la photographie durant son BTS de communication visuelle. Elle entreprit alors d’exercer sa passion en parallèle de ses études, apprenant au fil des shootings et des rencontres enrichissantes. Elle met en scène, crée des tenues et des coiffes mais aussi maquille et coiffe ses modèles la plupart du temps. 
Elle s’intéresse donc aussi beaucoup à l’histoire du costume et de la mode (de la renaissance aux années 70), aux mœurs et coutumes d’autres époques et à la place de la femme dans la société. En effet, on remarque aisément que cette dernière tient une place très importante dans son travail. Tantôt femme fatale, tantôt éthérée, elle séduit ou émeu, mais toujours dans un soucis d’élégance et de beauté. Son but n’est pas de placer la femme en objet de désir, mais plus de jouer sur le côté « mystique » qu’elle peut avoir.
Alexandra fait partie intégrante du projet depuis le début, apportant son soutien et surtout de magnifiques images autour de ces performances.



Margaux Genest notre coiffeuse, et Vanessa Brooke Lopez notre maquilleuse nous offrent avec passion leur temps et leur talent pour créer un univers unique autour de chaque robe, chaque personnage.
Sans oublier bien sûr toutes nos modèles bénévoles mais non moins talentueuses, Julia, Nella, Johanna, Line, Tamara, Sirithil, Lanivia, Hana, Klara et Heima!


Les Contreparties






Parmi ces créations Clara Maeda réalisées à la main, choisissez un de ces colliers seul pour 15€ ou en set pour 25€ ci-dessous, avec une broche, une paire de boucles d'oreilles ou une bague! Premier arrivé, premier servi!






Tirages 10x15cm ou 15x18cm issus de la série "Brume - De la Légende au Mythe", par Alexandra Banti, à respectivement 10€ et 15€



Choisissez un tirage de taille poster parmi ces clichés signés Nicolas Meunier pour 25€, représentant différentes créations de prêt à porter Clara Maeda réalisées à travers les années! Encore une fois, premier arrivé, premier servi!



Si vous êtes prêt à offrir 50€ à notre projet, voici la contrepartie que vous pouvez vous procurer : une ceinture corsetée faite main par Clara Maeda, en doupion de soie rose pale, guipure et broderie.Elle conviendra à quelqu'un ayant un tour de taille entre 60 et 75cm!



Pour le prix exceptionnel de 120€, offre-vous une séance photo d'1h30 dans une robe Clara Maeda, sous l'objectif d'Alexandra Banti. Vous recevrez par la suite 4 photos retouchées!
Si vous ne connaissez pas encore son travail, c'est par ici :
http://alexandrabanti.com
https://www.facebook.com/alexandrabanti.photography







On continue de monter dans les contreparties avec cette première robe "Alice", pièce unique crée par Clara Maeda. Pour 250€ au lieu de 450€ recevez cette robe unique, réalisée d’après les illustrations de François Amoretti.


Robe corsetée avec chemise, manches et tablier intégrés, en taffetas de soie bleu, coton fleuri blanc ton sur ton, dentelle anglaise, rubans de satin, boutons nacrés.Jupe à 5 volants en dentelle anglaise.  Attention, le jupon donnant le volume à la robe n'est pas fourni.
Elle conviendra à une petite taille, maximum 85cm de poitrine, 65cm de tour de taille, et 28cm de tour de biceps.



Dans un autre style, nous mettons à votre contribution cet ensemble 18ème composé d'une jupe en doupion de soie ourlée à la main, et d'une veste en velours de soie ivoire et brocard mauve, décorée d'un galon argent et de mousseline de soie métallisée . 
Offrez-vous cette tenue tout en soutenant notre projet pour 350€ au lieu de 1050€!
Pour avoir une silhouette 18ème, l'ensemble est à porter sur un corps à baleine et une paire de paniers (pour l'achat de cette tenue, bénéficiez  d'une réduction de 25% sur une paire de paniers et un corps à baleine sur-mesure)Taille maximum portée sans corset 86cm de poitrine, 68cm de tour de taille, 28cm de tour de biceps. Avec un corset, vos mensurations peuvent être légèrement plus importantes, puisque ce dernier affinera votre buste.

Toute l'équipe vous remercie d'avance pour votre intérêt et votre soutien, si vous ne pouvez contribuer vous-même, n'hésitez pas à partager ce projet autour de vous!

story:
Hi. My name is Christopher Burk. I am an urban landscape painter living, and working as a full time artist in Columbus, OH, USA. I have been accepted for a month long artist residency, which will also be my first residency, to the Vermont Studio Center in Johnson, VT, USA for September - October 2016, and need your assistance in getting there. As a “Thank You," original artwork will be given for your generous donation.

VSC was founded in 1984 by artists, and has steadily become one of the top residencies for visual artists and writers nationally, and internationally. This residency is an opportunity that I have been looking forward to for quite some time, and I am very honored to have finally been selected. Due to the wide ranging demographics & nationalities of VSC's attendees, not only will this be a great networking opportunity but it'll also help in my growth as a creative thinker, seer, and maker.

                                                                          

How You Can Help

 The total cost for the four-week residency is $3,950, which includes studio space, lodging, and meals. I was given by VSC, a generous merit based artist grant, a financial aid package, and I’m participating in their work exchange program to help alleviate some of the residency fee, but that still leaves a remaining balance of $2,800 for the program - in addition to transportation, supplies, possible shipping costs, PayPal fees, and Indiegogo's commission to host this campaign. Being a full time working artist can be very difficult at times, and I am looking to raise at least $2,800 to cover the remaining balance. Any amount that is over the goal will be put towards much needed supplies, and travel expenses.

                                                                        

About My Work

 The search for something new; unique forms and compositions, in our everyday landscapes are some of the items that I am constantly searching for as the major elements to my work, and as a Midwestern painter, New England will add some freshness to new pieces while using Johnson, VT and it’s surrounding communities and environments as subject matter. One of the most important contributors to the work, are the archaic utility poles & wires that are intertwined into the landscapes, both urban and rural. Symbolically they are represented in my paintings, as the "connectors" of community's relationships, their news, and information --- even today in a technologically modern world that is rapidly going wireless, and some would argue that the technology has aided in society’s literal disconnect from each other. I would like to utilize the same concept yet in a different locale for some of the work that'll be produced while attending this residency.

During this experience, and as an addition to other work that will be made for the duration of the program, I will be documenting the trip by car and plane through paintings and drawings. With this project I'll be challenging myself to make at least piece of artwork a day for the duration of the residency. The mediums will range from gouache, watercolor, ink and oil. When all of the work has been produced during the month long residency, I will then find a venue to display the produced work. 

On average, the majority of my work, which can be viewed in the campaign’s gallery section, is very tight, and polished yet with the one painting a day exercise that I’ll be adhering to, the style will be looser, and almost study-like in nature.

If you’re able to help achieve this goal, not only will it be greatly appreciated but you’ll also be rewarded with some original artwork. I look forward to sharing my work and progress with you. 

Thank you for your assistance!

                                                        

Other Ways You Can HelpW

Facebook it, tweet it, email it --- share with others.

story:
Papasquiaro.
unedited. untitled. unmastered.

Juan Luis Guerra & Caetano Veloso, gracias por darnos vida! I join artist Alejandro Ghersi (Arca) as I remember emails in which we discussed identities and black canvases. And also join Rita Indiana's immediate response at a Harvard university interview, when saying she would fight for her queer family in front of her "latin" family on any given day.

I missed Club Fonograma so much.

Is it crazy that I think of myself as an artist, and not a journalist? "I wish I could paint our love" just like Miguel. I'm not that gifted, but one day I hope to make movies like those shot on the evening empire: when the worst of all loose ourselves at night, on a ballad of vampires, night crawlers, druggies, and Bob Dylan reflecting on existence.

How do I come to my dad (a 1st grade dropout who learned how to read and write in both English and Spanish in his late 40's so that my twin brother and I could become citizens of this country) and explain to him that there's a whole other world beyond Chalino Sánchez and Los Hermanos Almada. Are we in front of another allegory of the cave, or is this another case of Christianity vs Jackie Chan in the new spider web? When all my friends around me are stuck on the Coen brothers, I'm already surveying the Dardenne brothers for true transgression and growth.

Am I also the son of David Lynch, Carlos Reygadas, Apitchatpong Weerasethakul, Michael Haneke and Gus Van Sant? Godard? Dumont? T. Dreyer? Through the years, I keep re-visiting my favorite film of all time... Memorias del Subdesarrollo, what would I do without you. Thank you Kiarostami for acknowledging art dealers and the battle of replicas vs wearing your references well in Copie Conforme. And thank you Claire Danes for that ending in Beau Travail -makes me want to dance.

Let's not victimize ourselves. That has caused too many wars and creates vicious cycles of unfortunate leaders in both pop culture and politics. Here I'm asking for advice, and for your help. Sometimes I wear that badge from Tony Gallardo's "Líder Juvenil" (que sabes de mi vida, que mueves grandes masas), with a big smile on my face. Who do I talk to about rhetoric, hedonism, zeitgeist, and a new ideal/renaissance man? James Franco?

Juan Luis Guerra. God. Papi. No' ta llevando el diablo!

Everyday I sing along Guille Milkyway about love and becoming the new Yma Sumac, take advice on finances and patents from Doble Pletina, croon about the eloquence of alternative/parallel times (quantum physics) with Coiffeur, and make the relentless case that we are all the children of god through that masterpiece of a song by Dios-que himself: "me mantengo frágil, feliz, manchado de sangre, cura vaginal, hombre vivo soy - soy hombre vivo!"

Not to brag, but I've also had a bromance with Ezra (yes, the vampire), and we've been singing about our sophomore year with reggaeton and that inevitable moment where our ancestral lineages will intersect yet again.... "it's a line that's always running, I can feel it coming." Let's keep the sexual exploration within "Cousins." Don't make me turn around to Babylon, Israelites and the motherland with "Ya Hey" this early in the career.

It's hard to keep it going without a salary. Hey fellow hipster, if you know what a true hipster is (a music geek), can tell the difference between trends and revivalists... you, like us, are part of the true Rebeldes (yes, that album by Alex Anwandter). If you're still stuck on the loop of who did it first? Rebelde Way or Rebelde Güey. Then you ought to reflect on your scholarship and pedigree. Go back to "Daughters," "back when Kanye was sweet and innocent, and John had no filters." -- @dbchic, redditt.

I was around when P4K named "BOB" by Outkast as their number one song of the decade, but I much preferred Stylus' choice of "Ignition" (Remix) by R. Kelly as the track that merited the -song of the aughts- crown. Pitchfork has never reviewed our diva, Javiera Mena (they barely met Carla Morrison). But Stylus validated Club Fonograma's choice of "Al Siguiente Nivel" on their very own list. And that choice felt effortless and clean of the politics of diversity, integration, or assimilation.

So who do you go to when you need funding for your art and your craft? 15 years blogging now and I'm still feeling like this: taking two steps back, every time. Consulting you, my friends and sources. Hoping that you won't charge for your knowledge. Any other enfant-terribles out there? (I feel completely unapologetic about adding myself to the list). How did you do it? Why are there no sponsorships or grants for those new visceral, sharp, critical "pens" out there. No beers or sneakers have ever wanted to sponsor our pages despite dozens of meetings. "Too risky," they say. I'm quite optimistic though! The stuff that's coming.... as Matilda Manzana sighs in "Ciencias Natuales," "sensacional.. lo que vendra... no te imaginas!"

So, my Club Fonograma, Cahiers du Cinema, Slant Magazine & P4k kids.... time to evoke Luis Buñuel and Tomás Gutiérrez Alea. Too many times I've scratched my head and gasped, if Don Luis Buñuel only knew what came of his muse. Silvia Pinal, you have no idea how much damage you've done to us with your molding of La Guadalupana. That tear-jerking, overprotective, and suffered mother keeps aborting the authentic, visceral arts, to instead, subscribe to the norm of Televisa, Univision, and now, Pantaleon Films. Where is the progress of that last supper-turned orgy as a form of almost-absolute artistic freedom (Viridiana) And what about the final dance? La carne radioactiva (Simón del Desierto). You know, the kind of bravura that's so often tailored to a communist or fascist agenda. Sometimes, raw creations result in bloodsheds (Salò, or the 120 Days of Sodom), and sometimes it competes for the Golden Palm.

"Cuba libre e independiente.... quien iba sospechar todo esto, sin el aguila imperial... ¿Y la paloma que iba mandar Picasso?"

Why is it that most Academy-award winning films equate to child pornography in my scope? Yeah... I'm one of those extremists, but one that keeps integrity at every margin. Let's celebrate Year-End lists and not the Latin Grannys. Let's take those movies to Critic's Week and, unless you're inviting Cronenberg & Lynch for the ride, skip Hollywood altogether. Let's put those are you a Mexican or a Mexican't? clichéd, lazy-ass jokes to rest and make the Mexi-Cannes circuit real. Above all, let's put politics aside and look beyond our borders and margins of fear. Take a chance and put deadpan comedy and hubris on every conversation.But, for what it's worth, yes Louis CK, you are more Mexican than George Lopez will ever be.

Time to take on the advice of our friend, the great but never stranged Rafa Saavedra (you paved the way, and your work and passion!! lives with us). Time for "Otros Mundos, Otras Estrellas." Time to embrace a contemporary such as Cristóbal Briceño as poetry, and not catalogue his vernacular as another flavor of the month. Time to embrace the cultural input/output of names like Jorge Ayala Blanco, Ed Gonzalez & Patricio Guzmán.

Emilio Jose, Jace Clayton, Javiera Mena, Aldo Alvareztostado, Julieta (nuestra madrina), Julianne Escobedo Shepherd, Diosque, Coiffeur, Clauda Llosa, Grant C. Dull, Pablito Diaz-Reixa, Eugenio Polgovsky, Fernando Eimbcke, Juan Antonio de la Riva, Daniel Melero, Camilo Lara, Martin Crespo, Lucrecia Martel, Gael Garcia Bernal, Lynn Fainchtein, Ernesto Diezmartinez, Josh Kun, Engel Leonardo, Txema Novelo, Jaime Romandia, Everardo Gonzalez, Juan Carlos Rulfo, Cheky, Milton & Quesney, Moni Saldaña, Will Balooni Sulllivan, and so many others, you're not forgotten.

Enough with the name-dropping. I've hesitated to do the crowdfunding , indie-gogo route, but I'd love to at least make it to Coachella or Festival NRMAL one day! Any ideas or Public Relations people that can help us keep Club Fonograma alive? Let's start by re-designing the blog. And I can't wait to articulate about movies again. Did you know I had a blog dedicated to Mexican cinema before feeling that little breeze of blogstar glamour?

"Toda la corporación unida
Planeando futuros proyectos
La misión que nos imponemos
La conquista del reino de los cielos

Es una noche de paz y progreso
Canta el obrero engrasando su torno
Las fresadoras trabajan contentas
Mientras las radios emiten al cosmos"

- El Nacimiento de la Industria, Aviador Dro.

Dull, Pablito Diaz-Reixa, Eugenio Polgovsky, Fernando Eimbcke, Juan Antonio de la Riva, Daniel Melero, Camilo Lara, Martin Crespo, Lucrecia Martel, Gael Garcia Bernal, Lynn Fainchtein, Ernesto Diezmartinez, Josh Kun, Engel Leonardo, Txema Novelo, Jaime Romandia, Everardo Gonzalez, Juan Carlos Rulfo, Cheky, Milton & Quesney, Moni Saldaña, Will Balooni Sulllivan, and so many others, you're not forgotten.
Enough with the name-dropping. I've hesitated to do the crowdfunding , indie-gogo route, but I'd love to at least make it to Coachella or Festival NRMAL one day! Any ideas or Public Relations people that can help us keep Club Fonograma alive? Let's start by re-designing the blog. And I can't wait to articulate about movies again. Did you know I had a blog dedicated to Mexican cinema before feeling that little breeze of blogstar glamour?
"Toda la corporación unidaPlaneando futuros proyectosLa misión que nos imponemosLa conquista del reino de los cielos
Es una noche de paz y progresoCanta el obrero engrasando su tornoLas fresadoras trabajan contentasMientras las radios emiten al cosmos"
- El Nacimiento de la Industria, Aviador Dro.

story:
Espace habité / inhabited space Nouvelles perspectives du bijou contemporain au Québec réunit treize jeunes créatrices qui actuellement se démarquent par leur intention artistique. Depuis quelques années, le bijou québécois s’est fait remarquer dans le cadre d’événements internationaux. Cette exposition présentée à l’Institut national des métiers d’art à Paris du 27 septembre au 15 décembre 2017 souligne ce nouvel enthousiasme. Initié par Stéphane Blackburn et Noel Guyomarc’h, ce projet permet de faire découvrir en dehors de nos frontières l’impulsion créatrice de ces artistes qui composent une nouvelle génération au Québec. Les commissaires remercient l’association d’Un bijou à l’autre qui réédite la manifestation internationale qu’est devenue Parcours bijoux 2017. 

Espace habité / Inhabited Space brings together thirteen young Quebec jewellers whose artistic and creative approaches are remarkable. Canadian jewellery, for several years now, has been standing out in national and overbroad recognized events and manifestations. Initiated and curated by Stephane Blackburn and Noel Guyomarc’h, this exhibition aims at promoting that enthusiasm by highlighting the creative impulse of a new generation of talents and offering them a broader visibility. It will be presented from September 27 to December 15 at the Institut national des métiers d’art de Paris during Parcours Bijoux 2017 event.

Pour mettre de l’avant cette édition parisienne, nous désirons amasser 5000$ qui servira en autres à créer un carton d’invitation, des affiches ainsi qu’un catalogue d’exposition. Ces outils promotionnels sont indispensables à la mise en valeur des oeuvres de nos créatrices. Notre objectif est de valoriser leurs qualités artistiques et d’aider la diffusion de leur oeuvres sur la scène internationale. Votre soutien serait grandement apprécié. Nous vous invitons à suivre nos actualités sur notre page facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Espace-habité-Inhabit...

To promote this exhibition in Paris, we would like to collect $5000 to produce invitation cards, flyers and a catalogue of the exhibition. These promotional tools are essential to value the artistic quality of the work by our artists. Your help is much appreciated.

Ce titre Espace habité / inhabited space fait référence à la provenance géographique et à l’expression culturelle commune des artistes sélectionnées, chacune cependant avec son espace créatif distinct.  Le langage plastique des œuvres démontre la richesse et la diversité issues d’une région perçue parfois éloignée et habituellement illustrée d’images fantasmées d’espaces infinis et sauvages. Les intentions artistiques référent avant tout au regard que chacune pose sur son entourage, sur des préoccupations environnementales, sociales parfois politiques, personnelles, bref des thématiques universelles. 

Espace habité / Inhabited Space refers both to their geographical origin and to their share of a common practice, but also to how each of them have invested a very personal and distinctive creative space.  The diversity of their plastic language sheds light on the richness of a region often perceived as remote and fantasized as wild and distant lands. As to their artistic intent, it refers to how they perceive the world and relate to environmental, social, political or personal issues.

Mais avec ironie ou humour, et un goût prononcé pour la couleur, de nombreuses œuvres partagent un élan de vitalité audacieux dans un contexte souvent austère et dramatique du bijou de création. Les bijoux animés de Magali Thibault Gobeil reflètent une personnalité flamboyante et gourmande, les créations d’Aurélie Guillaume racontent des histoires ludiques avec des personnages étranges et caricaturés haut en couleur. Plein d’humour et d’ironie,  les bijoux figuratifs ou narratifs de Silvie Altschuler sont construits de matériaux contraires tant dans leur consistance que dans leur valeur inhérente. Marie-Maude Brunet, utilisant des moules acquis d’autres joailliers a commencé une série ou la tête de mort, symbole de puissance, de culte et de mysticisme, est associée à des fleurs, symbole de vie. Le paradoxe se retrouve également chez d’autres artistes.  Juxtaposant bois flotté et plastique transformé, les broches d’Anne-Marie Rébillard évoquent ses préoccupations écologiques en associant les rejets naturels et humains.  De son côté, bien qu’utilisant des couleurs vives pour ses bijoux en porcelaine, Catherine Granche transcrit la transformation naturelle des aliments abandonnés sur nos comptoirs, comme des artefacts du quotidien. Marie-Ève G. Castonguay, Émilie Trudel et Gabrielle Desmarais, par des esthétiques, des compositions et des attitudes différentes proposent des visions de l’espace, de l’environnement, de la nature. Emilie Dell’Aniello évoque les tangibles interprétations du  contenant, une forme modelée en bronze recouverte de peinture acrylique, l’élément central de sa collection. Katia Martel, par ses des matières, bas nylon, dentelles, broderies, invite à un questionnement sur notre rapport à l’intime par le bijou. Catherine Sheedy explore dans ce groupe d’œuvres l’idée d’accéder à nos rêves par une proposition métaphorique des rêves d’Icare. Et dans un tout autre ordre d’approche, Anne-Sophie Vallée  questionne les mouvements et l’interaction avec le corps par des bijoux méticuleusement conçus et articulés. 

With irony and humour, and a pronounced taste for colour, most of the exhibited pieces share a welcome and daring impulse for life in the often stern and dramatic context of creative jewellery. The animated creations of Magali Thibault Gobeil reflect her exuberant and lively personality. Aurelie Guillaume’s enamel pieces tell stories of caricatured and colourful characters born from her fertile and vivid imagination. Full of humour and irony, Silvie Altschuler’s figurative or narrative pieces are made with opposed materials in terms of both worth and consistency. Marie-Maude Brunet, for her part, has been using moulds acquired from other jewellers. She undertook a series in which the skull, a symbol of power, religion and mysticism, is associated with flowers, a symbol of life. Paradoxes of that kind can be found in other works. Using driftwood and synthetic plastic in her brooches, Anne-Marie Rébillard illustrates environmental concerns by associating natural and human waste. Catherine Granche’s porcelain jewels, despite their bright colours, are meant to be images of how food leftovers transform, as artefact of daily life. Marie-Eve G. Castonguay, Emilie Trudel and Gabrielle Desmarais, through different aesthetics, compositions and attitudes, offer new perspectives on space, environment and nature. In Emilie Dell’Aniello’s work, a bronze-made shape, covered with acrylic paint, stands as the central element of her collection to evoke different tangible interpretations of the content. Meanwhile, Katia Martel’s materials, nylon stockings, embroideries and laces, question our intimate relationship with jewellery and Catherine Sheedy, through a metaphorical rewriting of Icarus’ story, explores the idea that we may gain access to our dreams. Anne-Sophie Vallée questions movements and jewellery's interaction with the body through meticulously designed and articulated pieces.

Ces différentes collections proposées reflètent l’actuelle production du bijou de création au Québec. Stimulantes pour la génération à suivre, ces créatrices s’inscrivent dans le mouvement international du bijou contemporain.

Those different series illustrate the richness and diversity of the jewellery world in Quebec nowadays. Stimulating examples for the upcoming generation of jewellers, those thirteen artists are part of a broad international movement of contemporary jewellery. The curators of this exhibition are very proud to introduce them first in Paris’s Institut National des Métiers d’Art, in the context of Parcours Bijoux in fall 2017.
