story:
100% funded! We are on our way!

A big thank you to all my wonderful friends and fam who have contributed. My pallette knife and I are over joyed and deeply grateful for your help to make this dream come true.

 

In Sedona my mission is to paint at the gallery on June 17th. 

I have a personal mission but I’ll tell you about that in a bit. 

This exhibition in Sedona, Arizona is my 4th with Carré d’artistes. If you've never heard of them, let’s just say I love working with them. They have galleries all over the world and are one of the best I’ve worked with in the 30+ years of my artistic career.

On Saturday June 17th, come rain or shine, my palette knife and I will be at the Carré d'Artistes gallery in the Tlaquepaque Arts & Crafts Village. We'll be painting our hearts out.

In the next 8 weeks I have to finish 80 Arizona landscapes. Follow my instagram feed to see my progress. And please share.

Finally I can tell you why going to Sedona is personally very important.

Last summer when Carré d’artistes offered me a place in their gallery in Sedona I hesitated. I wasn’t sure I wanted to paint landscapes again. After 20+ years of painting Tuscany and then moving to Paris I’d developed a new series of urban paintings — cityscapes of contemporary NYC and Paris.

One day in my atelier, while I mulled over the idea of painting Arizona landscapes I began pulling books off my shelves. Can you imagine my surprise when a 1970’s copy of the magazine Family Health fell to the plank floor? I picked it up and saw that the mailing label was addressed to my great-grandmother. My great-grandmother lived close to  Sedona. 

I have no idea how the magazine came to be on the shelf among all my journals and sketchbooks. Talk about a sign from the divine!

Without hesitation I dialed Carré d’artistes main office. Signs of Arizona have popped up everywhere since then. My mother-in-law talked to me about a writer from Arizona and while walking through Luxembourg gardens I literally tripped into a sign about the Grand Canyon.

It occurred to me later that my father was born 20 miles away, in Flagstaff, and I’ll have the chance to visit my roots, in a way… He died when I was 13 and I’ve never seen his grave. Now I can. So, my personal mission in going to Sedona is to visit, my grandmother’s and my father’s grave.

Several people offered to write testimonials for me.

More than anyone I want to thank to Catherine Baker Stetson Stetsonlaw.com . She is not only an amazing person, but an art connoisseur who has supported many artists. She kindly took her precious time to write an endorsement. I am grateful for the trust she has shown me and for all the paintings she’s purchased to add to her vast collection.

While many can paint beautiful Tuscan landscapes and the distinctive beauty and colors of the American Southwest, few of those can also capture evocative Parisian street scenes, and fewer still meet the challenge of finding and translating the beauty of old industrial Hudson River Valle towns such as Cold Spring Harbor, NY. Angie Brooksby’s ability to understand these different beauties is breath-taking to me. I cannot imagine Hudson River painters understanding the palette of Sedona, or the typical Italian landscape painter with the ability to adapt to the shapes and colors of a big city, yet Angie has a way not only of seeing the beauty in profoundly different places and faces but of communicating the various beauties delightfully and effortlessly.

 

My goal...

To raise 750$ for my flights.

It would put me on cloud nine.

 

My basic costs will be over 2000$ for the four day trip

$1050

Flights to Sedona and back to Paris

$375

AirBnB  -  4 nights

$190

Cheap car rental

$100

Gas in my tank

$100

4 days of tacos in my tummy

$2180

Grand total

 

My gallery will pay 250$ of my funds. That’s almost 25% of my flights' cost. But yowza I need a miracle to find the rest.

Will you be my miracle?

This is me in Deauville, France. That's where they have the Festival de Cinema Americain. Robert Redford has been there but I never saw him. My toes are in the freezing Atlantic as I look West. I swear I saw a flying Vespa.

 

Here is what you can do and what you get.

 

  •   Buy Me a Taco Lunch

25$  Postcard sized Watercolor of a Sedona's magical Bell Rock—15 x 10cm  These postcards are drawn and painted by me on archival paper.   I’ll postmark them from Sedona, sent in an envelope, and I'll send them anywhere in the world with the words you choose in any language as long as you give me the words. Why not surprise a friend?  Delivery in June.

Here is an example. All are individually drawn so there will be small differences.

 

18 Years ago Tony bought one of my watercolors when I worked at Piazzale Michelangelo as a street vendor in Florence, Italy. Two months ago he sent me this email so I asked him if I could quote him:


Angie, I met you in Florence years ago. I was a teenager touring with a band ... anyway, I bought one of your paintings on the street for 15,000 lira because I loved it, and you were so beautiful. I look at it often to remember that time and place and you. Today, I don't know why, I thought I would go find you and tell you, after all these years. – tony- Website: http://thingsandflesh.com    (opens in new window)

Each time I gaze at the tiny painting I have from you it makes me feel so free, just the way I felt wandering around Italy in 1992. Half the time I was lost :-) but all the time I felt I was discovering something, it was the thing I most desired, which was to be a songwriter.

To be telling you how much it meant to me and still does, after so many years ... I just can't believe it.

  • Get me to the airport

25$  Postcard sized Watercolor of a Canyonlands— 15 x 10cm. These postcards are drawn and painted by me on archival paper.  I’ll postmark them from Sedona, sent in an envelope, and I'll send them anywhere in the world with the words you choose in any language as long as you give me the words. Why not surprise a friend?  Delivery in June.

Here is an example. All are individually drawn so there will be small differences.

  •  Some gas in my tank

18$ for the Olive Recipe Card — Illustrated by me are four delectable recipes by Judy Witts Francini, the Diva of DivinaCucina.com . Sent from Paris, France. Delivery in July.

 

Here’s what Judy says about me:

I have worked with Angie on several projects from my Culinary business in Tuscany.

She has been a pleasure and very professional, adapting my logo into her illustration and bringing it to life.

We did three projects, one on olive recipes, a Limoncello book and a Porchetta recipe card. All fabulous

Judy Witts-Francini

See my angel on the cover of her amazing cookbook : Secrets From My Tuscan Kitchen

 

  •  A Full tank of gas

58$  Braided GARLIC lithograph

An original, limited edition (99 copies) 5 color lithograph that I created at the Stamperia d’Arte in Florence. 20x60 cm, archival paper. Shipped from Paris France. Shipping included to Europe, North America and Asia. Customs and duties at backers cost. Delivery in July.

 

 

  •  A Night’s Sleep in Sedona

58$  Braided PEPPER lithograph

An original, limited edition (99 copies) 5 color lithograph that I created at the Stamperia d’Arte in Florence. 20x60 cm, archival paper. Shipped from Paris France. Shipping included to Europe, North America, and Asia. Customs and duties at backers cost. Delivery in July.

 

  •  Two Nights sleep

$99 Both lithographs:  the garlic and the pepper. The perfect marriage. Shipped from Paris France. Shipping included to Europe, North America, Asia. (customs and duties at backers cost) Delivery in July.

 

  •  Rent the car

$148 for a Painting workshop in Paris, France

Valid for one year from purchase.

Three hour painting workshop for age 16 and up in Luxembourg gardens in Paris. No painting experience necessary. All materials supplied. You come empty handed. I supply oil paints, 30x40cm canvas (approximate size) and everything else you might need. When your painting is dry I ship it to your home (free shipping to Europe, North America and Asia) Any customs cost in your home country are at your charge.

 

Here is what Janis Post, a former workshopper has to say:

In 2006, Angie Brooksby led an afternoon workshop for me and 3 other beginner painters in an olive grove and vineyard in Tuscany. Angie was thoroughly prepared, an excellent teacher, and extremely encouraging. Although none of us were experienced painters, and had never painted en plein air, Angie gave us structure to start painting, support and tips when we got stuck, and just the right amount of design and color theory. It was a joy to spend that afternoon with Angie, and I’ve followed her career ever since. That afternoon inspired me to continue painting. I hope to be able to paint with Angie again.

Janis Post’s paintings.

  • Baba au Rhum

$50 euro

This painting is half price the original, exclusively to get me to Sedona.

Original oil painting on wooden panel 20x20 cm.  This painting was part of the exhibition 100x100 Gourmandises that I had in a restaurant in Paris in  2010.

100 euro for each of the 100. That night I sold 54 of these little food paintings. It was a great evening.

Shipping included to Europe and the North America. All customs and duties at backers expense. See shipping details to other countries.

  •  No more Mud

$60 Painting Master class by skype: For age 16 and up. One hour skype conference on how to mix oil paints without making mud, valid for one year from date of purchase. Special attention to contrast, how to conquer green tones. This workshop is especially good for landscape painters using oil paint.

 

  •  Get Me Half Way There

$375 No Left Turn:  One of a kind, original oil on linen. Painting comes matted and framed in white. Painting size is 30x30cm but the total framed size is 40x40cm. Shipped from Paris France. Shipping included to Europe, North America, Asia. (customs and duties at backers cost) Delivery in July.

 

  •  Fly me All The Way

$2280 Sparkle: 60x120x4 cm – oil on canvas.

It’s like a cruise on the Seine that will last a lifetime. Completed in December 2016, Sparkle, is one of my all time favorite paintings.  Along with this painting you get a watercolor postcard sent from Sedona, plus the Braided Garlic lithograph, the braided Pepper lithograph, and an Olive Recipe card that will arrive with the painting Sparkle.

Sent in a wooden crate. Free shipping in Europe. $300 shipping to North America. Customs and duty at backer’s expense. Please contact me for shipping costs to other locations. Delivery in July.

...

A special thank you to Mario Cappelletti of La Bottega in Castellina in Chianti, Italy for the kind words he offered when I asked him to write something for my campaign.  

As a Tuscan art gallery that represents and exports the work of several local artists, we can only speak well of Angie Brooksby. We have collaborated with her for more than 10 years. Her paintings speak freshly of the warm light in which we live. Indeed looking at Angie’s paintings we have the impression of seeing light. We have followed her very personal evolution as a painter. We have seen her jump from the countryside to the city of light… all this whiles smoothly building our professional and human relationship.

Where to follow me:

My website

instagram

Facebook

Carre d'artistes

Here I am in my atelier in Paris with some of the larger paintings that will be for sale at the gallery.

___________________________________________

Today is May 4th. I want to thank all of you who have donated. In two days you've put me half way there.
Today I added the Canyonlands watercolor postcard. I need to get to the airport in Paris.
___________________________________________

My great-grandmother lived close to  Sedona. I have no idea how the magazine came to be on the shelf among all my journals and sketchbooks. Talk about a sign from the divine!Without hesitation I dialed Carré d’artistes main office. Signs of Arizona have popped up everywhere since then. My mother-in-law talked to me about a writer from Arizona and while walking through Luxembourg gardens I literally tripped into a sign about the Grand Canyon.It occurred to me later that my father was born 20 miles away, in Flagstaff, and I’ll have the chance to visit my roots, in a way… He died when I was 13 and I’ve never seen his grave. Now I can. So, my personal mission in going to Sedona is to visit, my grandmother’s and my father’s grave.Several people offered to write testimonials for me.More than anyone I want to thank to Catherine Baker Stetson Stetsonlaw.com . She is not only an amazing person, but an art connoisseur who has supported many artists. She kindly took her precious time to write an endorsement. I am grateful for the trust she has shown me and for all the paintings she’s purchased to add to her vast collection.While many can paint beautiful Tuscan landscapes and the distinctive beauty and colors of the American Southwest, few of those can also capture evocative Parisian street scenes, and fewer still meet the challenge of finding and translating the beauty of old industrial Hudson River Valle towns such as Cold Spring Harbor, NY. Angie Brooksby’s ability to understand these different beauties is breath-taking to me. I cannot imagine Hudson River painters understanding the palette of Sedona, or the typical Italian landscape painter with the ability to adapt to the shapes and colors of a big city, yet Angie has a way not only of seeing the beauty in profoundly different places and faces but of communicating the various beauties delightfully and effortlessly. My goal...To raise 750$ for my flights. It would put me on cloud nine. My basic costs will be over 2000$ for the four day trip

$1050
Flights to Sedona and back to Paris


$375
AirBnB  -  4 nights


$190
Cheap car rental


$100
Gas in my tank


$100
4 days of tacos in my tummy


$2180
Grand total

 My gallery will pay 250$ of my funds. That’s almost 25% of my flights' cost. But yowza I need a miracle to find the rest.Will you be my miracle?This is me in Deauville, France. That's where they have the Festival de Cinema Americain. Robert Redford has been there but I never saw him. My toes are in the freezing Atlantic as I look West. I swear I saw a flying Vespa. Here is what you can do and what you get.   Buy Me a Taco Lunch25$  Postcard sized Watercolor of a Sedona's magical Bell Rock—15 x 10cm  These postcards are drawn and painted by me on archival paper.   I’ll postmark them from Sedona, sent in an envelope, and I'll send them anywhere in the world with the words you choose in any language as long as you give me the words. Why not surprise a friend?  Delivery in June.Here is an example. All are individually drawn so there will be small differences.

 
18 Years ago Tony bought one of my watercolors when I worked at Piazzale Michelangelo as a street vendor in Florence, Italy. Two months ago he sent me this email so I asked him if I could quote him:Angie, I met you in Florence years ago. I was a teenager touring with a band ... anyway, I bought one of your paintings on the street for 15,000 lira because I loved it, and you were so beautiful. I look at it often to remember that time and place and you. Today, I don't know why, I thought I would go find you and tell you, after all these years. – tony- Website: http://thingsandflesh.com     (opens in new window)Each time I gaze at the tiny painting I have from you it makes me feel so free, just the way I felt wandering around Italy in 1992. Half the time I was lost :-) but all the time I felt I was discovering something, it was the thing I most desired, which was to be a songwriter.To be telling you how much it meant to me and still does, after so many years ... I just can't believe it.Get me to the airport25$  Postcard sized Watercolor of a Canyonlands— 15 x 10cm. These postcards are drawn and painted by me on archival paper.  I’ll postmark them from Sedona, sent in an envelope, and I'll send them anywhere in the world with the words you choose in any language as long as you give me the words. Why not surprise a friend?  Delivery in June.Here is an example. All are individually drawn so there will be small differences. Some gas in my tank18$ for the Olive Recipe Card — Illustrated by me are four delectable recipes by Judy Witts Francini, the Diva of DivinaCucina.com . Sent from Paris, France. Delivery in July.

 
Here’s what Judy says about me:I have worked with Angie on several projects from my Culinary business in Tuscany.She has been a pleasure and very professional, adapting my logo into her illustration and bringing it to life.We did three projects, one on olive recipes, a Limoncello book and a Porchetta recipe card. All fabulousJudy Witts-Francini See my angel on the cover of her amazing cookbook : Secrets From My Tuscan Kitchen   A Full tank of gas58$  Braided GARLIC lithographAn original, limited edition (99 copies) 5 color lithograph that I created at the Stamperia d’Arte in Florence. 20x60 cm, archival paper. Shipped from Paris France. Shipping included to Europe, North America and Asia. Customs and duties at backers cost. Delivery in July.   A Night’s Sleep in Sedona58$  Braided PEPPER lithographAn original, limited edition (99 copies) 5 color lithograph that I created at the Stamperia d’Arte in Florence. 20x60 cm, archival paper. Shipped from Paris France. Shipping included to Europe, North America, and Asia. Customs and duties at backers cost. Delivery in July.  Two Nights sleep$99 Both lithographs:  the garlic and the pepper. The perfect marriage. Shipped from Paris France. Shipping included to Europe, North America, Asia. (customs and duties at backers cost) Delivery in July.  Rent the car$148 for a Painting workshop in Paris, France Valid for one year from purchase.Three hour painting workshop for age 16 and up in Luxembourg gardens in Paris. No painting experience necessary. All materials supplied. You come empty handed. I supply oil paints, 30x40cm canvas (approximate size) and everything else you might need. When your painting is dry I ship it to your home (free shipping to Europe, North America and Asia) Any customs cost in your home country are at your charge. Here is what Janis Post, a former workshopper has to say:In 2006, Angie Brooksby led an afternoon workshop for me and 3 other beginner painters in an olive grove and vineyard in Tuscany. Angie was thoroughly prepared, an excellent teacher, and extremely encouraging. Although none of us were experienced painters, and had never painted en plein air, Angie gave us structure to start painting, support and tips when we got stuck, and just the right amount of design and color theory. It was a joy to spend that afternoon with Angie, and I’ve followed her career ever since. That afternoon inspired me to continue painting. I hope to be able to paint with Angie again. Janis Post’s paintings.Baba au Rhum$50 euroThis painting is half price the original, exclusively to get me to Sedona.Original oil painting on wooden panel 20x20 cm.  This painting was part of the exhibition 100x100 Gourmandises that I had in a restaurant in Paris in  2010.100 euro for each of the 100. That night I sold 54 of these little food paintings. It was a great evening.Shipping included to Europe and the North America. All customs and duties at backers expense. See shipping details to other countries. No more Mud$60 Painting Master class by skype: For age 16 and up. One hour skype conference on how to mix oil paints without making mud, valid for one year from date of purchase. Special attention to contrast, how to conquer green tones. This workshop is especially good for landscape painters using oil paint.  Get Me Half Way There$375 No Left Turn:  One of a kind, original oil on linen. Painting comes matted and framed in white. Painting size is 30x30cm but the total framed size is 40x40cm. Shipped from Paris France. Shipping included to Europe, North America, Asia. (customs and duties at backers cost) Delivery in July.  Fly me All The Way$2280 Sparkle: 60x120x4 cm – oil on canvas.It’s like a cruise on the Seine that will last a lifetime. Completed in December 2016, Sparkle, is one of my all time favorite paintings.  Along with this painting you get a watercolor postcard sent from Sedona, plus the Braided Garlic lithograph, the braided Pepper lithograph, and an Olive Recipe card that will arrive with the painting Sparkle.Sent in a wooden crate. Free shipping in Europe. $300 shipping to North America. Customs and duty at backer’s expense. Please contact me for shipping costs to other locations. Delivery in July....A special thank you to Mario Cappelletti of La Bottega in Castellina in Chianti, Italy for the kind words he offered when I asked him to write something for my campaign.  As a Tuscan art gallery that represents and exports the work of several local artists, we can only speak well of Angie Brooksby. We have collaborated with her for more than 10 years. Her paintings speak freshly of the warm light in which we live. Indeed looking at Angie’s paintings we have the impression of seeing light. We have followed her very personal evolution as a painter. We have seen her jump from the countryside to the city of light… all this whiles smoothly building our professional and human relationship.Where to follow me:My websiteinstagramFacebookCarre d'artistesHere I am in my atelier in Paris with some of the larger paintings that will be for sale at the gallery.___________________________________________Today is May 4th. I want to thank all of you who have donated. In two days you've put me half way there.Today I added the Canyonlands watercolor postcard. I need to get to the airport in Paris.___________________________________________

story:
I’ve been accepted as one of the Artists-in-Residence at the Vermont Studio Center during their February 2016 session. I will be there for four weeks, living, making art, and meeting fellow artists in Johnson, Vermont (while trying to stay warm!).

Some of you might not know what it means to be an “artist-in-residence” and how beneficial it is throughout an artist’s career. All residencies offer something a little different but essentially they give artists (and other creative types) time and space for reflection, research, and to make work that they wouldn’t normally try in their usual environment. It is an opportunity to explore and experiment with your practice while meeting new people (internationally and from around the country) and trying new materials, all while engaging in meaningful cultural exchange and critical thinking. At the Vermont Studio Center, I will be given a place to live, a studio to use whenever I want, and be fed daily (yay!).

As you can imagine for an opportunity this wonderful, it doesn’t come free. I did receive an artist grant and work exchange to help compensate for the tuition, however, I will need to come up with the remainder of the tuition, the flight and materials cost, plus rent for my apartment in San Francisco that I am unable to sublet. 

Instead of asking for donations, I have set up a fundraiser for people to purchase different art pieces, artist books, small paintings, and a postal notebook that will be sent from Vermont. All of the proceeds will go directly to helping me fund my residency!

If you are looking for unique, one-of-a-kind drawing sketchbooks that are handmade by a local artist, or want to add new work to your art collection, look no further (well, take a look at what I’m bringing to the table):

The Goods:

·  A Postal Notebook that is handmade by me that I will send from Vermont. Inside will include 4 small watercolor/gouache (one of a kind!) paintings that I will do at the residency as a daily warm-up practice. (approximately 5.5” x 3”)

  • $80

·  Small one-of-a-kind gouache painting (unframed):

  • 8"x8": $67
  • h:8"x w:3.5": $53
  • 6"x6": $53
  • 5"x5": $46
  • 4.5"x4.5": $34
  • 4.24"x5.25": $34
  • 3"x3.5": $27
  • 3"x3": $24



16” x 16” oil painting on panel

  • $400


·  Artist Book: “Chiyomi’s Miniature Book of Scanned Paint Swatches” (edition of 15)

  • $37
  • Image: three different views of artist book as you open it.


·  Hand bound drawing notebook (size: h: 6” x w: 8.5”, 18 pages, nice drawing paper)

$17


Funds breakdown:

Remainder Residency Tuition: $2,050

Rent in SF (studio and apartment) in SF: $1,750

Plane Ticket: $481.20

Shipping Materials (to and from): $120

Shipping artwork: ????(I have no idea what I'm going to make there yet!)

Total: $4,401.20

9% that Indegogo takes: 396.11

Total: $4,797.31

UPDATE: I've raised a total of $3,471.20 so far from your kind and generous donations! I'm almost there!!!!

Thank you for helping support a young emerging artist, I greatly appreciate it!

Here is a link to the Vermont Studio Center Residency website: http://vermontstudiocenter.org/ for you to check it out.


Chiyomi McKibbin

www.chiyomimckibbin.com

story:
WOOHOO!!! Julia and Lily have been invited to be a part of Difibrillator Performance Art Gallery's International Performance Art Festival RAPID PULSE!

The awesome folks at Defibrillator have got the whole family a place to stay and delicious meals for our five night stay, BUTTTT we need to find the airfare ourselves. 

John, Julia and Lily will be heading to Chicago on June 5th to share some of Houston's home grown performance art with a new city and a great international scene! We would be so so so so so honored if you checked out our perks and found it in your heart to support us in this endeavor. We have tried very hard to come up with some great items that will be super worth your while. 

HELP LILY PERFORM IN HER FIRST PERFORMANCE ART FESTIVAL! 

xoxoxoxoxoxxo,

John, Julia, and Lily

 

CHECK OUT A COUPLE OF THE PERK PAINTINGS!

The Cardinal- http://www.flickr.com/photos/juliaclairewallace...

The Mouse- http://www.flickr.com/photos/juliaclairewallace...

story:
We're C.U.T.E!


C.U.T.E. is a collaborative that draws on our mutual background in sculpture and social anxiety. Our work situates itself in the intersection of Social Practice, interactive art, and Relational Aesthetics, and counters art that we perceive as inaccessible. Our work assumes that people are fearful, because we are.

  • We assume that people want intimacy, and are lacking it.
  • We assume that people don't know how to approach each other, but want to.
  • We assume that, given the permission and proper framework, people will be eager to know each other.
  • We assume that something good comes from the practice of becoming intimate with people.
  • We assume that intimacy is something to be sought after.
  • We assume that if a person isn't seeking intimacy, it is because they already have "enough".
  • We assume that the only reason people wouldn't seek intimacy is fear.
  • We assume that there are environments, processes, and objects that we can create to quiet, distract from, and fool fear.
  • We assume that we are providing a needed service.


The Residency

We have an upcoming residency with the Miranda Arts Project Space, in Port Chester NY. We will be using the gallery space as a place to create an environment to foster interactions between disparate groups of people. We will start by creating a limited service coffee bar.  From this welcoming starting place, we will host a series of classes, workshops, discussions and fundraisers. 


Our Events:

Build-A-Bench - September 28th at 1:00pm

  • Build benches for public spaces in Port Chester.  See you work in public!  For ages 13 and up.

C.U.T.E. (Cultivate Uncomfortable Temporary Encounters) - October 5th at 5:00pm

  • Acquaintance making game (based on a speed dating format) and ceramic cup building with the help of the Clay Art Center to use at our coffee bar.

Faith on the Fourth Floor - October 6th at 1:00pm

  • Discussion based event guided by prominent figures from religious communities in the area.

C.U.T.E. (Come Up The Elevator) - October 10th at 5:00pm

  • A game in which we spend two hours un-alone, making friends and taking names.

Girls Night Out - October 12th at 9:00pm

  • Bring your heels and leave the kids at home.

Micro-Grant Dinner and Artist Talk - October 19th at 5:00pm

  • Bring proposals and an appetite to this micro-grant dinner, where the price of your meal will go toward funding a project of your choice.  Followed by artist talk with C.U.T.E.


What your money will go toward:

Materials

  • to transform the gallery space into a coffee house 
  • for the Build-a-Bench project
Facilitators 

  • We would like to be able to compensate our discussion and workshop leaders for their time and expertise. 
Food and Beverages

  • For the Micro-Grant dinner
  • We would like to keep our coffee free to everyone for the duration of the project.
Transportation

  • of people and materials to and from the gallery space

How you can help

If you are unable to help fund us please help by spreading the word! Share this with your friends and your non-friends. You can also join our mailing list to stay updated on our events, or like us on Facebook.

Most importantly, come out to our events. We would love to see you there!

You can find out more about our project at The Miranda Arts Project Space and our website. If you have any question feel free to shoot us and email at cute.collaborative@gmail.com


Thank you!

       C.U.T.E.

story:
Dear Funders, dear Followers, dear Friends, 

with your help we've raised $ 5822! Thank you very much for your contributions and your constant support during the campaign! 

We will use the money and the rich treasure of experience we've collected during the last 3 month to kick start our project. We will keep you updated about every progress and we hope to welcome you soon as guests and co-operators of the Seki Method Center!

Thank you!!! ありがとう！



Who are we?

Minako Seki:

I am a Berlin-based, Japan-born dancer, choreographer and teacher.

In the 1980s I brought the Butoh-dance to Europe.

I've created more than fifty solo and company pieces and also worked with many companies as a guest choreographer. My pieces are being shown all over the world: in Europe, in South & North America, in Arab Countries and in Japan.

During the last twenty years I've developed the Seki Method – a dance training and a self-care method.

The Seki Method is based on principles of physics and biology, and their transformation into the dancing body. Perception and imagination are likewise important aspects of this work.

The Seki Method is both rooted in Japanese tradition I grew up with, and verified by the recent somatic and neuroscientific research.

Together with my Power Team we are pursuing the dream to give the Seki Method a home, to cultivate it, to develop it and to pass it on.


Our Vision, our Mission


Our goal is to create an open and dynamic performing arts center aspiring towards a new balance between

Art, Science, Philosophy, Healing, Nutrition and Spirituality.

It will gather under one roof:

Dance, Performance, Qigong, Meditation, traditional Japanese Treatments and healthy Cooking.

The Seki Method Center is dedicated to performing arts in holistic vision. At the same time it is sharing tools for life.


Minako's inspiration is a daily routine of Zen-Monks. She and her students has experienced the deep impact the morning ritual – getting up early, keeping silence, cleaning the space, meditation and Qigong – has on our lives and our creative process. 

Our awareness and our connectedness are expanding. The art we are creating, is gaining depth and beauty as well as profound social and political dimension.


Who can benefit from the Seki Method Center?

Everyone interested in combing art and a holistic way of life shall find a space for creation, research and retreat in natural environment close to Berlin.

The Seki Method is beneficial 

for youngsters and seniors,

for dancers, performers, artists, musicians,

for health practitioners, therapists, nutrition experts,

for teachers and social workers,

for scientists and academicians …

Everybody regardless of age, state of health and movement experience is able to get from the very first encounter with the Seki Method a unique gift:

a lasting, solid foundation and some simple tools to continue the work on one own and to go further the path of self-care, self-healing, mindfulness, personal growth and creativity.


In order to fulfill its mission,

the Seki Method Center will

  • Host dance, movement and voice workshops, lectures and conferences for dialogue between art and science, performances, cooking classes, ceremonies and meditation retreats.

  • Provide space and other resources for art and science residencies to develop and stage new works while living and co-creating the special, respectful atmosphere of the Seki Method Center.

  • Provide space for meditation, self-care and self-healing and invite visitors to participate in the Seki Method as well as the daily routines of the Center.

As a visitor of the Seki Method Center you will be able to experience:

  • Dance to find natural and physical principles in your body, to reconnect and trust your instincts and to unfold imagination and creativity
  • Meditation for learning to be in the Here and Now and becoming aware of your patterns
  • Healing to give time and tools to support your self-healing and detoxification
  • Macrobiotic Food because how you cook & eat influences the way you feel

Join us! Be a part of this project!


What will happen with your 

money if you donate

 

(Artwork by Veronika Dobers)

If successful, this indiegogo campaign will cover the first phase of the Seki Method Center development. In this phase we are working as a "mobile" Center and offering workshops, intensive education program, lectures, info events and art&science working sessions.  At the same time we are setting the organizational structure of the Center, building up our international team, developing the specific program of the Center further and possibly finding partners to share the buildings.

Your backing will contribute to 

• founding and securing the non-profit status of the Seki Method Center as a limited liability company (about 5500 $)

• covering the rental, journey and material cost for the first year of our activity (about 10000 $)

• covering the personnel costs for assistance, administration, book keeping and guest teachers (about 10000 $); this will allow us to continue the work on developing the Seki Method Center and on securing the third-party funding to sustain it into the future and eventually to give it a home!

• covering the costs for advertising, PR-events as for example free taster workshops and publications (about 2500 $)


Why Indiegogo

By inviting the broader public to contribute to our early development, Indiegogo helps us to build the engaged community necessary for sustaining the Seki Method Center into the future.

Your contribution is both financial and ideal support. Through our perks you'll be already partaking in holistic experiences we hope to create.


The most special perk!

1000 $ RARE & BEAUTIFUL

The extremely rare collector's item. One of total   three prints of "Minako 02", a part of the legendary, artistically outstanding series of photographs by Ulrich Heemann. 


{Ulrich Heemann: Minako 02 · 2099 · Photography, montaged, processed, alienated · 48 x 38 cm on Hahnemühle Fine Art Paper 59,4 x 42 cm · Edition: 3 exemplars · catalogue raisonné 09-FB-09.}


How can you contribute besides

donating?

Spread the word! Take part in our events and bring your friends with you. Ask us - maybe there is something else you can do.

Join our mailing list and add us on Facebook. Stay tuned on our website at minakoseki.com/blog. Email sekimethod@minakoseki.com with questions.



Meet the Team of the Pitch Video

  Dr Jagna Anderson              Beatrice Möller                                               Writer and  Organiser                                  Lead Campaign Videos Creator & Director

  Johannes Hitzblech               Doreen Ignaszewski             Minako Seki's Set Coach                              Film Editor

Rasmus Sievers - Cinematographer

Roger Rossell - Photographer & IT Consultant

Sheela Royal, Radja von Viehbahn, Tayler R. Abramson, Kathrin Knöpfle, Mina Fuhr, Susanne Feld, Laura Pacheco, Miranda Markgraf, Antje L. Schmidt - the Power Team


Credits and Thank Yous

Main Video: Beatrice Möller {Director}, Rasmus Sievers {Director of Photography}, Johannes Hitzblech {Minako Seki's Set Coach}, Doreen Ignaszewski (Editor), Zam Johnson {Music}, Helen Neikes {Sound}, Roger Rossell {Computer Animation}, Jagna Anderson {Coordinator}

Photos: Roger Rossell, Ulrich Heemann, Beatrice Möller, Minako Seki, Jagna Anderson

Special Thanks to: Arche Naturküche GmbH, Ilona Brede, Christa Flaig & Tanzfabrik Berlin e.V., Pia Fischer, Ottmar Gendera, Ulrich Heemann, Clarissa Hurst, Mr Jeschke, Klunkerkranich, Professor Rudolf zur Lippe, Natural'Mente, Adam Palermo, Charlotte Stolz, Nils Willers,
story_txt:
Dear Funders, dear Followers, dear Friends, 
with your help we've raised $ 5822! Thank you very much for your contributions and your constant support during the campaign! 
We will use the money and the rich treasure of experience we've collected during the last 3 month to kick start our project. We will keep you updated about every progress and we hope to welcome you soon as guests and co-operators of the Seki Method Center!
Thank you!!! ありがとう！



Who are we?Minako Seki:I am a Berlin-based, Japan-born dancer, choreographer and
teacher.
In
the 1980s I brought the Butoh-dance to Europe. 

I've
created more than fifty solo and company pieces and also worked with
many companies as a guest choreographer. My
pieces are being shown all over the world: in Europe, in South & North
America, in Arab Countries and in Japan.

During
the last twenty years I've developed the Seki Method
– a dance training and a self-care method. 

The
Seki Method is based on principles of physics and biology, and their
transformation into the dancing body. Perception
and imagination are likewise important aspects of this work.

The
Seki Method is both rooted in Japanese tradition I grew up with, and
verified by the recent somatic and neuroscientific research.Together with my Power Team we are pursuing the dream to give the Seki Method a home, to cultivate it, to develop it and to pass it on.

Our Vision, our MissionOur goal is to create an open and dynamic performing arts center aspiring
towards a new balance between
Art,
Science, Philosophy, Healing, Nutrition and
Spirituality.

It
will gather under one roof:
Dance,
Performance, Qigong, Meditation, traditional
Japanese
Treatments and
healthy
Cooking.The Seki Method Center is dedicated to performing arts in holistic vision. At the same time it is sharing tools for life.

Minako's inspiration is a daily routine of Zen-Monks. She and her students has experienced the
deep impact the morning ritual – getting up early, keeping silence,
cleaning the space, meditation and Qigong – has on our lives and
our creative process. Our awareness and our connectedness are
expanding. The art we are creating, is gaining depth and beauty as
well as profound social and political dimension.
Who can benefit from the Seki Method Center?
Everyone
interested in combing art and a holistic way of life shall find a
space for creation, research and retreat in natural environment close
to Berlin. 
The Seki Method is beneficial for youngsters and seniors,for dancers, performers, artists, musicians,for health practitioners, therapists, nutrition experts,for teachers and social workers,for scientists and academicians …Everybody regardless of age, state of health and movement experience is able to get from the very first encounter with the Seki Method a unique gift:a lasting, solid foundation and some simple tools to continue the work on one own and to go further the path of self-care, self-healing, mindfulness, personal growth and creativity.

In
order to fulfill its mission,the Seki Method Center will



Host
	dance, movement and voice workshops, lectures and conferences for
	dialogue between art and science, performances, cooking classes,
	ceremonies and meditation retreats.


Provide
	space and other resources for art and science residencies to develop
	and stage new works while living and co-creating the special,
	respectful atmosphere of the Seki Method Center.


Provide
	space for meditation, self-care and self-healing and invite visitors
	to participate in the Seki Method as well as the daily routines of
	the Center.

As
a visitor of the Seki Method Center you will be able to experience:


Dance		to
find natural and physical principles in your body, to
reconnect and trust your instincts and to
unfold imagination and creativity

Meditation	for
learning to be in the Here and Now and becoming aware of your
			patterns


Healing		to
give time and tools to support your self-healing and
					detoxification

Macrobiotic Food		because
how you cook & eat influences the way you feel
Join us! Be a part of this project!What will happen with your money if you donate (Artwork by Veronika Dobers)If
successful, this indiegogo campaign
will cover the first phase of the Seki Method Center development. In
this phase we are working as a "mobile" Center and offering workshops, intensive education program, lectures, info events and art&science working sessions.  At the same time we are setting the organizational structure of the Center, building up our international team, developing the specific program of the Center further and possibly finding partners to share the buildings.

Your
backing will contribute to • founding and securing the non-profit status of the Seki Method Center as a limited liability company (about 5500 $)• covering the rental, journey and material cost for the first year of our activity (about 10000 $)• covering the personnel costs for assistance, administration, book keeping and guest teachers (about 10000 $); this will allow us to continue the work on developing the Seki Method Center and on securing the third-party funding to sustain it into the future and eventually to give it a home!• covering the costs for advertising, PR-events as for example free taster workshops and publications (about 2500 $)







Why
Indiegogo

By
inviting the broader public to contribute to our early development,
Indiegogo helps us to build the engaged community
necessary for sustaining the Seki Method Center into the future.

Your
contribution is both financial and ideal support. Through our perks
you'll be already partaking in holistic experiences we hope to
create.


The most special perk!1000 $ RARE & BEAUTIFULThe extremely rare collector's item. One of total   three prints of "Minako 02", a part of the legendary, artistically outstanding series of photographs by Ulrich Heemann. {Ulrich Heemann: Minako 02 · 2099 · Photography, montaged, processed, alienated · 48 x 38 cm on Hahnemühle Fine Art Paper 59,4 x 42 cm · Edition: 3 exemplars · catalogue raisonné 09-FB-09.}How
can you contribute besidesdonating?

Spread
the word! Take part in our events and bring your friends with you.
Ask us - maybe there is something else you can do.

Join
our mailing list and add us on Facebook.
Stay tuned
on our website at
minakoseki.com/blog. Email
sekimethod@minakoseki.com with questions.

story:
Hi everyone! I’m Deborah Monaghan an artist/designer currently in Montana via Massachusetts and California. My need for funding is two fold. At the end of June, The Danforth Gallery in Livingston, Montana will be including my wallpaper and textiles in their show titled, Implement (where household objects and art collide). Alongside this, I will be launching a small business so I can continue to produce these pieces, sell them to the general public - and my hope is, make more! I have so many ideas for designs and the commercial viability is endless - I just need a leg up - or two.


For about the last decade I have been immersed in all things design, branding, marketing, project management and business operations. From art school to running a design/technology studio my experience has primed me for this venture. The ThinkBody website can be found at www.thinkbody.co  and here is my linkedin profile if you would like to learn more: www.linkedin.com/in/deborahmonaghan/  

 

 

 

 

 

ThinkBody is a response to the increasing cerebral world we live in as we spend more of our lives engaged within the virtual world of our screens. The patterns are based on and/or inspired by anatomy and systems of the body. Imagine having wallpaper or pillows in our homes or offices inspired by the way blood moves through our heart, or the visual design of our nervous system. Might these objects prompt us to leave the world of the screen and return not only to our physical body and senses, but also to the physical environment in which we find ourselves. This project has been a labor of love for over a year and a half now, and I am so excited to finally see these designs move from zany idea to objects of art people can use and enjoy in their homes. 

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

I am asking for funding of $4500.00 and here is a bit about how the designs get produced and where the money will go.


ThinkBody is a collaborative effort that involves an extremely talented bunch of people found in the States (me), France (Imelda Picherit, colorist), and Ireland (Orlagh O’Brien, graphic designer). My forte is not working in the computer, so I take my sketches and ideas to my collaborators and together we turn them into computer generated designs ready for wallpaper and textiles. This process allows me to focus on what I am best at, dreaming up new patterns and concepts for new patterns, and tending to the production and business matters at hand.

 

 

 

 

 

From there we move into the printing production which involves ordering test runs of both wallpaper and textiles, tweaking the scale of the patterns and the color as we go. And then we are off! and it’s time to print rolls of wallpaper and make pillows or towels (and whatever else I can dream up), or print fabric for upholstery.

 

At this point, there is much infrastructure that I am working on that supports not only the gallery show, but the launch of ThinkBody as a small business. This includes postcard design and printing, copyrighting the patterns, getting a website together, packaging, production how-to’s moving forward, and pr and some computer equipment. For the June Danforth show I am producing pillows and two or three rolls of wallpaper - and maybe, just maybe, upholstering a chair. I am currently investigating working with local Montanan screen printers to produce wallpaper as well as seamstresses and leather workers to produce the pillows. I will be posting pictures of the samples as they come in along with other updates on the update portion of the campaign, so please be sure to check back regularly on my progress.

 

 

 

 

After the campaign is successfully funded, all contributors will be listed on the ThinkBody website once it has launched and you will forever have my gratitude. Other perks include limited edition prints, pillows that are made by seamstresses in Montana and custom design work. Whether in print or textile form, these patterns are functional art pieces that encourage a reconnection to the body and the spaces we inhabit; though the world of the screen can be vast, deep and engaging, let’s not forget our senses, the tactile, and the charms of the human environment that surround us.

 

 

Lastly, dollars aren't the only way to contribute - spreading the word is just as valuable. Please share the campaign and help get the word out!

 

Share the page (use the buttons at the top of the page to LIKE and SHARE) and leave comments, too. I look forward to hearing from you.

story:
Support WoCA Projects as we raise funds to sustain our operational and programming costs for 2013!

WoCA Projects' mission is to highlight contemporary art by women artists of color, and diversify the contemporary art landscape through exhibitions and community arts programming.WoCA had a successful grand opening in February 2013, featuring two exhibitions: Street Immersions: Drawings by Linda Lucia Santana and Entertaining the Life: Featuring artists Desha Dauchan and Joy Ude.

Our goal is to show at least 4-6 exhibitions a year as well as facilitate community outreach through community arts exhibitions featuring the works of local student artists, creative workshops, opening receptions, film screenings, and lectures/panels. But in order to build the quality programming that the community deserves we have to raise funds to make these exhibitions a reality.

WoCA has already established an awesome roster of artists to show in our gallery for the rest of the year and now we just need to funds to support our programming. Through the help of our fiscal sponsor, Fractured Atlas, we were able to raise enough funds in late 2012 to transform our space into a beautiful gallery and to throw an amazing grand opening, which featured two spectacular exhibitions that generated an enormous buzz in the community. Some of our upcoming exhibitions will feature artists such as Coco Rico, Joy Ude, Kubo Hiroko, Chesley Williams, and many more artists. 

WoCA Projects is located inside the budding Riverside Arts disctrict, which is slightly northeast ( 5 minutes) from downtown Fort Worth. WoCA is excited to be amongst a diverse group of arts venues in the Riverside Arts District that collectively organizes events and activities with the hopes of mobilizing a grass roots arts community of artists and arts professionals.

What's next?

Our next scheduled exhibition will open on May 11th, featuring two solo exhibitions by artists Coco Rico and Joy Ude. Additionally, WoCA Projects and other arts venues in the Riverside Arts District are also partnering with a local school to feature the works of over 300+ students between April 25-27th. So your support of this campaign will allow us to do this important work in the community.

 
About the Founding Director

WoCA Projects was created by artist and curator, Lauren Cross, whose work on this spectacular space earned her one of three 2013 Visionary Awards from the Fort Worth Weekly. See Cross' profile in the Fort Worth Weekly! 

Here are some of our awesome campaign perks:

 
For Contributions of $25–  You will receive a WoCA Cinch bag + a PDF copy of one of our exhibition catalogs + be listed as a "Supporter" on the WoCA website and receive invitations/postcards to upcoming exhibitions and events ( Amount over $10 is tax-deductible).
 
 
For contributions of $100– You will receive all lower-level perks + WoCA t-shirt + Your name listed under "Champions" in the exhibition catalog and on the exhibition wall signage.
 
Go to our Indiegogo page for a more detailed listing of our campaign perks.

Contribute early and receive artwork by local artists!
 
 
 Contribution of $150–1 of 1 perks available : A pair of 11" x 15" mono prints, "Traces," by Joy Ude 
 
 
 
 
 
Contribution of $150– 1 of 1 perk available: Wearable art by Chesley Williams. The above piece is a wearable hair accessory, materials Mylar removed from floppy disk, lace, and wire.
 
 
Contribution of $500: 1 of 1 perk available: 4 color lithograph, "Dramatic Performance" by Coco Rico (from edition of 21),

story:
Hello folks! Welcome to Regionopolis. This project is an effigy for Florida AfterBurn. AfterBurn is a non sanctioned regional Burning Man event. Burnt Oranges, the organization organizing the event, has selected us to build this year's effigy and has provided an art grant in the amount of $1000 towards this project. This is a $2500 endeavor and we must raise the other $1500. So we are reaching out to our awesome Burner community to make our vision a reality.

Our design crew:
Scotty Bizzle - visionary, artist, project lead
Tyler Simmons - visionary, artist
Dae Von Hoover - artist, engineer, creative designer


Regionopolis is a 15 ft, 2V Geodesic Truncated Sphere. It will rest on a
base fitted with ball bearings to create an interactive piece so that the citizens may rotate the globe. The exterior will be painted to represent the globe. We will place the logos for the Burning Man Regions and Regional events in the respective locations on the globe while lighting up these areas at night. We will be providing information on all the regions as well as the regional Burning Man events throughout the globe. The effigy will also contain a special surprise revealed upon burning.


What You Get

We accept any and all denominations of donations, but for these amounts below, you'll receive some special schwag!

For donations of $50 to $99, you will receive commemorative stickers.

For donations of $100 or more, you will receive an effigy crew t-shirt.


Our donation time frame is quite limited, so we must reach our goal within two weeks.


Other Ways You Can Help

We are looking for anyone with carpentry or painting experience that can help with the prefabrication and on site building of the project. We will be pre fabing in Tampa, FL and will be building on site at Maddox Ranch in Lakeland, FL. Tools such as nail guns, saws, and drills will also be needed to speed along the process. Please contact Scotty at scottyfromfla@yahoo.com if you'd like to be a part of the build team.

story:
Davis has a lot of murals.  Davis has a lot of bikes.  But Davis is missing one thing....

A Fantastic Community Bike Mural!

This summer, help me (Danielle Fodor) paint a monument to cycling in the heart of downtown Davis, at the corner of 3rd and F Street. This will be the inaugural mural for my new public art project -- Paint Bike Fun, which involves children and communities in making great public art about cycling.

This Bike Fun mural will be the first community-designed and painted mural in downtown Davis in over 10 years, and the first and only mural about cycling in Davis!

Location, Location:

The intersection of 3rd and F street is the heart of downtown Davis, known as the "Bicycle Capital of America". 3rd street is the main bicycle corridor that connects UC Davis campus with the city’s restaurants, cafes, and Davis Farmer’s Market. The wall, on the SW corner, is perfect, with architectural framing to make two wheel-shaped panels.

Why me? Why this project?

This project was born when my young son refused, for several months, to ride in his bike trailer. While in the car, he would talk about all the other "race cars" on the road, and begged us for "Cars" brand sunglasses and backpack. It made me think about all the powerful, fun images that children see about cars and trucks -- movies, books, clothing, TV shows, and more.  I wanted biking to be that FUN.  And I wanted to use the tools I knew -- working with kids and communities to paint great public art.

I have been painting community murals in Davis for about 8 years. I love to work with people to create vibrant images that showcase our values and collective imagination. Some of my murals can be seen in the UC Davis Arboretum and the Davis Art Center.

A Community-Driven Project:

This mural has included community input from the first moments. Davis children, youth, and grown-ups created nearly 200 art pieces about Bike Fun, in response to a public "Call for Ideas" and a free, public design workshop.  I did the final studio work, putting everything together and coloring it in.

Painting is also a community endeavor.  I have been painting for 5 weeks (July & August) and invitde the community to continue participating by joining me on a paint days, 5 days a week. Our painters are a wide variety of people -- children, adults, teens, professionals, retirees, students, unemployed folks.  The wall is a place for people to meet and work together as equals.   Get project updates at: www.facebook.com/paintbikefun. Email me for volunteer info: paintbikefun@gmail.com

Send some money! Get cool stuff!

This mural is happening! This mural has received amazing support from grants, the City of Davis, and local organizations that has paid for the original materials, printing, and the bulk of our costs. But we need a little more...

My fundraising goal is $2500.  This money will fill a gap to pay for the mural's equipment(signage, safety cones), materials (extra paintbrushes & palettes), and a small portion of my labor (4 months of participatory design, teaching painting, training volunteers, and doing community outreach), as well as for permits for the street party that we will hold on August 17th, to celebrate the mural's completion.

I will give you awesome stuff for your donation! Beautiful, high quality art greeting cards, a stylish bike coloring book, and/or a high-quality print of the mural.  If you give a lot of money, you could get your name on the mural plaque, or pick a piece of art from my studio!

Tell your friends!

  • Share this project with your friends to help us reach our goal. It's exciting!

If you give me more money, I'll paint more Bike Murals!

The Davis Bike Fun mural is the first in a series of mural installations that I am planning for cities throughout California, called Paint Bike Fun. Paint Bike Fun is a multi-city public art initiative that promotes cycling by creating large-scale public art that brands cycling as magical, joyful, and fun, especially for children and youth who are the transportation decision makers of tomorrow. Money helps me make murals.  Check it out at www.paintbikefun.com
 
Thanks for the Support!
 
This mural would not be possible without the generous finanical support of the Davis Art Center, the James Irvine Foundation, Genentech, the City of Davis' Street Smarts and Ride Walk Davis programs, and Davis Downtown. They paid for all the initial costs of the mural, and for that I am grateful.  This Indiegogo campaign will fully fund the remaining costs.
story_txt:
Davis has a lot of murals.  Davis has a lot of bikes.  But Davis is missing one thing....
A Fantastic Community Bike Mural!
This summer, help me (Danielle Fodor) paint a monument to cycling in the heart of downtown Davis, at the corner of 3rd and F Street. This will be the inaugural mural for my new public art project -- Paint Bike Fun, which involves children and communities in making great public art about cycling.
This Bike Fun mural will be the first community-designed and painted mural in downtown Davis in over 10 years, and the first and only mural about cycling in Davis!
Location, Location: 
The intersection of 3rd and F street is the heart of downtown Davis, known as the "Bicycle Capital of America". 3rd street is the main bicycle corridor that connects UC Davis campus with the city’s restaurants, cafes, and Davis Farmer’s Market. The wall, on the SW corner, is perfect, with architectural framing to make two wheel-shaped panels.
Why me? Why this project?
This project was born when my young son refused, for several months, to ride in his bike trailer. While in the car, he would talk about all the other "race cars" on the road, and begged us for "Cars" brand sunglasses and backpack. It made me think about all the powerful, fun images that children see about cars and trucks -- movies, books, clothing, TV shows, and more.  I wanted biking to be that FUN.  And I wanted to use the tools I knew -- working with kids and communities to paint great public art.
I have been painting community murals in Davis for about 8 years. I love to work with people to create vibrant images that showcase our values and collective imagination. Some of my murals can be seen in the UC Davis Arboretum and the Davis Art Center.
A Community-Driven Project: 
This mural has included community input from the first moments. Davis children, youth, and grown-ups created nearly 200 art pieces about Bike Fun, in response to a public "Call for Ideas" and a free, public design workshop.  I did the final studio work, putting everything together and coloring it in.
Painting is also a community endeavor.  I have been painting for 5 weeks (July & August) and invitde the community to continue participating by joining me on a paint days, 5 days a week. Our painters are a wide variety of people -- children, adults, teens, professionals, retirees, students, unemployed folks.  The wall is a place for people to meet and work together as equals.   Get project updates at: www.facebook.com/paintbikefun. Email me for volunteer info: paintbikefun@gmail.com
Send some money! Get cool stuff!

This mural is happening! This mural has received amazing support from grants, the City of Davis, and local organizations that has paid for the original materials, printing, and the bulk of our costs. But we need a little more...
My fundraising goal is $2500.  This money will fill a gap to pay for the mural's equipment(signage, safety cones), materials (extra paintbrushes & palettes), and a small portion of my labor (4 months of participatory design, teaching painting, training volunteers, and doing community outreach), as well as for permits for the street party that we will hold on August 17th, to celebrate the mural's completion.
I will give you awesome stuff for your donation! Beautiful, high quality art greeting cards, a stylish bike coloring book, and/or a high-quality print of the mural.  If you give a lot of money, you could get your name on the mural plaque, or pick a piece of art from my studio!
Tell your friends!

Share this project with your friends to help us reach our goal. It's exciting! 



If you give me more money, I'll paint more Bike Murals!
The Davis Bike Fun mural is the first in a series of mural installations that I am planning for cities throughout California, called Paint Bike Fun. Paint Bike Fun is a multi-city public art initiative that promotes cycling by creating large-scale public art that brands cycling as magical, joyful, and fun, especially for children and youth who are the transportation decision makers of tomorrow. Money helps me make murals.  Check it out at www.paintbikefun.com

 
Thanks for the Support!
 
This mural would not be possible without the generous finanical support of the Davis Art Center, the James Irvine Foundation, Genentech, the City of Davis' Street Smarts and Ride Walk Davis programs, and Davis Downtown. They paid for all the initial costs of the mural, and for that I am grateful.  This Indiegogo campaign will fully fund the remaining costs.

story:
The Short of It

We are a handful of Austin-based illustrators looking to put together a coloring book for children. Rather than illustrate the same tired old characters, monsters, and myths, we've decided to flex our imaginations and create some new ones. Our goals can be summarized as follows:

  1. We want to inspire kids to create. We grew up drawing Frankenstein, Dracula, and the Wolf Man, and we firmly believe that there’s a special magic when a child discovers a new monster. This coloring book harkens back to the days when we first started drawing - when we scribbled just to explore the furthest reaches of our creativity. We’d like to help ignite that spirit of discovery in the next generation of kids.
  2. We want to make something beautiful. It isn’t easy for young illustrators to find a platform for their work, and we want to start sharing our skills with the world. Whether you’re going to color in the book or not, we want you to be able to enjoy just flipping through the pages.
  3. We want to test the waters of self-publishing content for children. If we find success, this coloring book will only be the beginning of a whole new storybook world full of adventure and discovery. A broader children’s magazine is already in the works... but we have to make this coloring book a big hit first!

 

What We Need & What You Get

Getting this project off the ground requires us to get that first batch of coloring books mailed in from the printer. We can’t wait to open the box full of fresh, shiny coloring books, and every contribution from people like you gets us a little bit closer to that moment!

The actual hard item you’re funding is an 8,5” x 5.5”, 24-page coloring book, packed full with the imaginative work of great young artists. Every bit of funding will shorten the length between that imaginative work and the finished product. If our campaign reaches the full goal of $500, we’ll be able to print enough copies to start shipping out in full force! But even if we don’t quite make it all the way to our goal, every contribution - no matter how small - will help make this dream a reality even sooner.

What do you get out of it? Well, look to the right for a list of all the great rewards you can receive for your donation. But even beyond the prizes...

  • You will help to create something that is certifiably awesome, something that inspires kids to create and start building out-of-the-box creative thinking skills.
  • You will give a group of recently-graduated illustrators a chance to share their work.
  • You will make the world a scarier and more interesting place!

Us!

Here are few incredibly condensed bio's of the people involved with this project, along with a sample of their work:

Andrew Craft: FOUNDER, ILLUSTRATOR, FAVORITE ANIMAL: 2-year old. Also works as: swim instructor.

 

 

Edward Witlif: COPYWRITER, ILLUSTRATOR, FAVORITE FOOD: soil. Also works as: film-editor.

 

Pavel Nitchovski: ILLUSTRATOR, FAVORITE ARTIST: Edward. Also works as: data analyst.



Betsy Cooper: ILLUSTRATOR, DESIGNER, FAVORITE FACIAL HAIR: unibrow. Also works as: barista.



Jaclyn Skeans: ILLUSTRATOR, FAVORITE COLOR: light, light, light tan. Also works as: seamstress.



Hannah Bull: ILLUSTRATOR, FAVORITE MODE OF TRANSPORT: razor scooter. Also works as: ASL student.



Victoria Elliott: ILLUSTRATOR, FAVORITE MOVIE: "Lance Armstrong Rides to the Moon." Also works as: comic artist.



Kara Timmons: ILLUSTRATOR, FAVORITE PANTS: lace capris. Also works as: art student!

Push Goals

Believe us, if we can just reach our goal for full funding, there will be much dancing and excitement. But if you excellent people donate extra, you’re going to get extra in return! We’re talking more pages, which of course means... more monsters!

story:
Our Story

 Issue #4!

It's almost done and you can help send it to the printer! This time interviews get loaded, in depth and uncomfortable when artists such as La Chica Boom, Margaret Harrison, Lynne Chan, Cheryl Leonard, Tamara Kostianovsky, Adriane Colburne, Sita Kuratomi Bhaumik and The Beehive Collective divulge the sometimes gritty meat of process, share charged experiences of censorship and unpack relationships to identity,  politics and environment. Help us record history and the work of artists who are marginalized because of their genders and/or sexualities.


Aorta is a radical, queer arts magazine that serves as documentation and reference of and for artists, who despite and because of their circumstances, have developed their own performative, visual, written, analytical, and sexual languages. On our pages, the stories of women, gender-queer, and transgender artists, from different political, geographical and class backgrounds are written and visually portrayed. We feel it is of absolute necessity to ensure that the physically real, non- digital, paper- between- the- fingers world of media offers a space for these communities to be heard, felt, and known.


We started in early 2008, are a small and tightly knit collective of working artists, designers, writers, cultural producers and activists. We are self- produced, self- distributed, community funded, and we consider each copy of Aorta to be a work of art in itself.

 We will forever believe in the power of art and media to make radical transformations in the lives of its audience, just as we will forever believe in the power of the audience to make radical impressions on art and media.

Our goals are: to improve the visibility of a group of artists who are significantly marginalized on the basis of their gender and/or sexuality, to be a source of documentation for the extraordinary work this group produces, and to serve as a space for free artistic expression and a vehicle for social change through the avenue of independent publishing.


In 2009 we were honored to receive fiscal sponsorship from NYFA and a generous grant from Southern Exposure's Alternative Exposure program! We have thrown dance parties, sold cookies, and now look to you for support.



 The Impact

We've learned, as women and trans-folk, as immigrants, as people of color, as artists, as queers, as the working class, and as activists, that reliance on each other, our surrounding communities, and broader networks of other creative/social justice organizations is intrinsic to our survival.

We are creating context, developing room and growing awareness around socially pertinent sexual and identity issues that affect both our communities and the people who surround them.

Our commitment to keep the publication free of advertising keeps us directly responsible to our politics and also keeps us in direct need of your support! We love that we are community created and funded and this is what will enable us to continue producing and spreading the words and work of artists that directly relate to your communities and the thought provoking, critical work that comes out of them.

With your support, we get the message that you recognize the gap we strive to fill, find value in the documentation we work to create and share in our dedication to bring voice and physical presence to our communities in digital print and media.  Without your support, we would have no reason to create this publication at all, and wouldn't be able to. 



What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $3,500 to directly fund the printing costs for our upcoming issue and boy do we have some awesome things to offer you with our thanks and gratitude for your thoughtful donation!


Your tax deductible donations empowers us to keep recording queer art history! AND to encourage your contributions, we've come up with some awesome perks for you! 


Donate:

(with each increase in support you make, you will receive the item listed,  in addition to every item gifted to lesser dollar amounts!) 


$20 - get your very own copy of upcoming issue #4 and our undying love and gratitude!

$25-  + a hand written thank you note!

$50 -  + your name listed in our next issue as a donor!

$100-  + Aorta's new logo hand-printed onto your very own canvas tote bag!

$250-  + a print of a cover of issue #3, and a tote, and next issue, and a thank you note plus love!

$500-   + a lifetime subscription of Aorta!

$1,000- allll of the amazing aforementioned items PLUS if you live in the Bay Area we will take you out to dinner... or maybe even make you dinner. (and we are amazing chefs, let me tell you.) If you don't live in the Bay Area, we will send you an infamous batch of homemade gluten-free, vegan cookies that will leave you drooling for more...


Aorta is a sponsored project with New York Foundation for the Arts.  Our affiliation with NYFA allows us to offer our donors some of the benefits of an organization with 501(c)(3) nonprofit status.  To make a tax-deductible donation to our project directly, please visit: http://www.nyfa.org/level3.


Other Ways You Can Help

We are so grateful for the support we receive from our community members. Please let us know how you'd like to help and continue giving us your feedback! We like it!

We are always open to new volunteers and other arms of your support!

Help us get the word out! Share our project easily with the share button! Tweet! Facebook! Tell your friends, family, co-workers, long-lost relatives! Want to throw us a benefit party? Volunteer? Let us know!

story:
Our Story

We are excited that Lauren will graduate from college on May 8, 2011. She has worked hard in pursuing her studies in art and art therapy, and her family celebrates her achievement. As she has moved through her college experience, it has been fun to watch her discover her abilities. Lauren is a bright young adult with a promising future. We support her love of art and want to help her continue to grow in her artistic skills.

Recently her mom Jamie and step-dad Bill visited New England. Passing through the quaint town of Grafton, Vermont, they stopped by a working blacksmith shop. Adam Howard is a master blacksmith who teaches people how to do his historical art. He provides week-long residencies for artists and craftsmen to show them how to work the forge and anvil. To learn more about his work, click here.

Lauren was excited to hear about this learning opportunity, but her face fell when she heard the price. She is a college senior, after all, looking at loan repayments and the start-up costs of getting out on her own. Bill and Jamie would love to send her to Grafton Forge, but with two other kids in college, this seems like an "extra" expense that they simply can't meet in its entirety.

But what if we were able to ask you to help out? Have you ever wanted to encourage a young adult to reach for her dreams? That's what we hope to do: to send Lauren to Blacksmith Camp on May 21-27, 2011.


The Impact

Every gift and donation will be helpful. These are tight times for many families, and young adults are feeling the financial pinch more than many. This is especially true for young artists, who learn quickly that other people do not immediately value their work. 

Therefore the greatest impact of this campaign is encouragement. Through your gifts, you are able to assist a young artist in developing her skills.

Sure, we can encourage her with words. But if we send her to this camp, we can make our encouragement into a tangible experience that will shape her life for many years to come.

Plus - and this needs to be said - she will learn how to make really cool iron sculptures that could end up on your front lawn . . . or in a famous museum!


What We Need & What You Get

The total cost for the one-week residency at Grafton will be about $1000. This covers tuition (500), room and board (400), and gas money (100). Her immediate family will make an initial gift, and we are inviting friends and other members of the family to pitch in as they are able.

As you might know, it can difficult to pick out a gift for Lauren. She lives modestly and never wants to put people out. Jamie and Bill want to lead the effort to do something special for this extraordinary young woman. We think this is a fresh and fun idea with lots of practical benefits for Lauren.

While every gift is important, we want to provide special premiums for those who can help us out. Please be sure to note the perks provided by Lauren's family. Everyone in the household will be helping out in some way. The family is offering special perks for special donations. Can you help support this dream?

We invite you to make an online gift through this IndieGoGo site. If you wish to contribute by cash or check, you can send the contribution to her at her home address.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word about this cool idea. There are tools on this site to share the campaign with others.  You can send a special e-mail, post a click-to picture, or post this on your Facebook page. Thanks for telling others about this opportunity. Together we can send Lauren to Blacksmith Camp.

Thanks for telling others about this opportunity. Together we can send Lauren to Blacksmith Camp.

story:
Short Summary

Catch the Bus is the dream of two artists to create a Mobile, Sustainable way of existing and bringing Art to the world.

Our plan is to obtain a  school bus to renovate into a mobile live-in studio. We believe that art and ideas should be shared.  The digital realm provides a platform on which to share and communicate which is unprecedented, but is a supplement not a replacement for human contact.  In search of this human contact, we embrace a nomadic life of constantly sharing and being shared with.  

In this age, we are all aware that some resources are finite, while others are constantly renewable. Catch the Bus is a dream of existing in balance.  We know the power of technology, the bus will be a roving smart-house allowing us to publish our creations and our unique existence for the world. At the same time, we respect that the power for that technology needs to come from sustainable sources; we plan to power everything from the lightbulbs to the tablets with solar and wind energy.

As we travel throughout the country, everyone who gets to Catch the Bus will get to share in the process of artistic creation and observe a fully-functioning example of a modern, sustainable existence that they may take away ideas of what is within reach.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $12,000 to get and renovate the bus.  That may seem like a lot, but if only 120 people give $100, we will have met our goal!  Literally every dollar counts.  

The money will be used for:

A SCHOOL BUS - $3,500 

POWER - $3000 - Solar panels, Wind generator, Deep cycle batteries, Inverter, Controller

WATER - $1,500 - Rain collector, Filtration, Piping, Grey water collector

SPACE - $2,000 -  Renovation, Smart-system, Compost toilet

MOVEMENT - $1,000 - Biodiesel mixing station, Vespa

FACADE - $1,000 - Exterior Paint, Interior Details, Cockpit

 

The Impact

Catch the Bus will be a mobile showcase of a sustainable existence.  Obviously, not everyone wants to live in a bus, but the ideas and solutions that we use, find, and develop will be transferable to every day living in a technlogical age.  The Bus will be a touring showcase of those ideas and solutions.

Finally, one of the things I have enjoyed on my travels is meeting those people who have never traveled more than 50 miles from where they were born.  Their unique view on life and space is always an inspiration.  Catch the Bus will bring art, our art and the art of others across the country, to those people in a way they might never see otherwise. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Get the word out.  

    • Share Catch the Bus on Indiegogo on facebook, twitter, G+, email or whatever thing the kids are using these days!  IndieGoGo has tools to help you get the word out

  • Give materials, not money

    • Listed above are some the things we need to make this happen, if you have any of them and would like to send it to help Catch the Bus, message us to make arrangements.   Based on the value of your materials, we will send you the appropriate reward!
